He also prefers to teach advanced statistical concepts in a purely theoretical framework, so I feel like I can apply very little to real life, and I LOVE sports analytics. He IS very nice, as a small saving grace.
In terms of grading, there's literally 4 assignments this semester (3 smaller ones, and one bigger project). They're all group work, so find a good group who knows how to code, as that's what you'll be doing for 90% of the questions. They're pretty time-consuming, but since they don't happen that often, this class was an off-on class, where I forgot I was enrolled in it when we didn't have assignments, and when we did, I spent time on it. Also, he doesn't release grades until literally the end of the semester. He made it sound like it's an easy A if you show dedication though.
Do I recommend this class? Kinda? It's good if you have a busy semester, but it's a pretty dull class overall.
#tCFfall2021

3280 Professor Ross and 4996 Professor Ross are two different people. He's overequipped in helping teams make their project a reality and puts in the time and effort in being a good facilitator. He will also call out your group if you're falling behind but will also get his hands dirty to help groups with certain functions of the work. No complaints besides the class being served MWF instead of MW. That's Ross for ya! Good guy tho fr
Take Capstone with Rodu. He is the man and is super helpful throughout your research process. His feedback is helpful but not overbearing and allows you to work without stress.

Overall, this was a very interesting course that was not too difficult to perform well in.
Lectures: Overall, the lectures tend to be very heavy theory wise with complicated derivations done by Professor Yu during most of the lecture, followed by some applications in R towards the end of each lecture. However, the theory certainly comes in handy during the homework at times when code examples have not been provided, so I would try to grasp the foundations of many of the algorithms which will be presented to you over the course of the semester.
Grading: 30% HW (3 of them), 30% Midterm, 40% Final Project
Homeworks: While there are only 3 homeworks over the course of the semester, they do take a bit of time to do well on-- I would say each one took me on average 10-12 hours to complete. Fair warning: the first homework was graded much more harshly than the latter two, so if you do poorly on the first homework assignment, don't feel as though the rest of the course will be impossible. Overall though, the code that Professor Yu uses during lecture and makes available on Collab are very useful for the homework problems. I would certainly reccomend finding a group early on which you can work on homeworks with, and attending Professor Yu's office hours if you have any questions.
Midterm: The midterm was pretty straight forward and is very similar in content and difficulty to the practice midterm which Professor Yu releases. I was extremely nervous going into the exam as I had performed poorly on HW1 (which was our only other grade in at the time) and ended up getting an A on the exam.
Project: The project is composed of 3 parts: data processing report (10% of grade), presentation to class (10% of grade), and final report (20% of grade). The project was a Kaggle competition which was scored based on your group's ability to minimise RMSE from a training data set provided onto a test set. Both the data processing report and presentation were graded very easily (in essence completion). The final report took a bit of time (really just trying to construct an adequate model), but wasn't too bad especially if you have a good group.
Overall, Professor Yu was very accommodating and willing to meet with you during office hours or at other times to go over homework questions or any other concerns you may have with the course. When there weren't any assignments due, there really wasn't much to do in the class, but keep in mind that homeworks really do take a while to work on so make sure to begin them well ahead of the due dates if you want to do well on them.
#tCFspring2021

I was so excited to take this class. However, Minh is a horrible lecturer which makes class time a complete waste. He is not at all helpful outside of class time. That being said, he is a really nice person! The exam is very hard, and some of the homework problems are extremely difficult (although most are fair). The final project is pretty fun. I would recommend this class with Professor Holt, but not with Minh as the professor.

Mr. Pham is a terrible teacher though he is a nice person outside the class. The class is poorly constructed and badly taught. There are too many mistakes in his slides and it seems he can not explain the stuff he is teaching very well if we assume he understands it. Besides, he even changes the grading system at the last minute,making the grading extremely unfair and himself not professional at all. I Definitely don't recommend this class with him. It's a total waste of time. Take it with Professor Jeff Holt if possible!
Martinet is really an ok professor teaching a class on an ok subject.

Professor Tang is a king! Literally one of the nicest professors I've had in the stats department: I literally don't know anyone who took the course who didn't like him.
Breakdown: 30% HW; 30% Midterm; 40% final project (so fairly standard grade breakdown for a stats class).
Lecture: Lectures were usually highly theoretical. The content is pretty interesting and intersects well with other graduate stats classes (especially 6190). Overall, I don't necessarily know if attending class was super necessary. I kinda stopped going towards the end of the semester (after the first midterm). HW can generally be done without going to class, but the midterm is based heavily off of lecture material so I would at least try to attend frequently for the first half of the course.
Midterm: Super easy if you paid attention during class. You get a cheat sheet front and back you can make and bring to the exam which was definitely helpful. The hardest part was honestly the T/F at the beginning which was mostly questions he talked about during lecture not on the slides which is why I recommend attending lecture for the first half of the course at a minimum.
HWs: He said there would be 5-6 HW but we barely had enough time to get 4 in lol. They're all pretty straight forward. The first two take MUCH longer than the latter two in my experience as the first ones are way more proof based than the other two which rely much more on computation in R. The slides will be your best friend for these homeworks so make sure to use them if you get stuck.
Final Project: 5% 1 page draft of project outline (basically completion); 15% presentation; 20% final written report. Pretty standard project. He just asks you to find a dataset and analyze it using the methods we learned during the course. The written report is supposed to be 10-15 pages single spaced which at first seemed daunting but wasn't really that bad (plus me and my partner literally basically wrote the entire report in one sitting and did fine on the project).
Overall, this is a great stats elective to take. Great professor, interesting content, and not hard to do well in.
#tCFfall2021

This class wasn't that great overall. Prof. Tang is a nice guy, but he didn't plan the class very well and he felt like he was unable to adapt to the needs of his class.
We only had one short homework assignment before the midterm, which left most of the class feeling unprepared for the difficulty of the exam. When we asked him to give us more practice assignments, he agreed that we did not have enough practice assignments and then gave us 2 short assignments between the midterm and the final. The homework was graded on completion and our lowest score was dropped, so effectively we only had 2 required assignments throughout the semester. It is a little strange to basically beg your professor to give us more work so that we can engage with the material and prepare for the exams, but that is basically how this semester felt. Lectures were fairly dry, and since there were so few assignments, there was not much of an incentive to pay attention even if I wanted to, which I couldn't.
Another strange moment of the semester was when Prof. Tang told us halfway through the semester that he had been contacting the wrong TA. I'm not sure how it took him 7 weeks to realize that the TA that he had been contacting was not assigned to his class, but it did.
The content in this class was actually pretty interesting. He just needs to take the time to design this class better. Give more assignments and give students a way to engage with and practice the material. I think this class has great potential, but as it is I can't say that I would recommend the class.

Denny is a terrible instructor who has no idea how to lecture, grade, or write a test. His lecture slides consist of incomprehensible, poorly-scaled screenshots of equations. He wastes multiple lectures talking about absolute nothingness, like how good it is to study statistics. He makes you do advanced statistics on a graphing calculator for tests, which are ridiculously difficult, but he doesn't realize this because he deludes himself by giving extremely generous grades. The final project barely related to the course content. He is unable to keep himself organized, and only assigned three homework assignments the whole semester despite promising one approximately every other week. He at least acts like a nice instructor who is willing to help, but he won't help you due to his deep incompetence. You will learn nothing in a class with Denny, but at least it's not too hard to get an adequate grade by taking advantage of how little he cares.

Wendi is an amazing teacher. Half of the class is mandatory  (the classes she gives group assignments) while the other half is not.   She records all of her lectures. This is a perfect class if you are trying to finish off your QCDAs. Not incredibly easy/boring math, but definitely very doable and understandable. I really recommend.

I am only halfway done with this class, but I wanted to post for anyone who is course searching. I am a gov major with a decent background in high school math (pre calc/AP stat). It is a 1000 level course and I have never struggled more. The instructor does a poor job explaining the concepts and providing appropriate level work. Since I was struggling I decided to go to office hours and I left in tears. I would strongly advise that you do not take this class with Mark.

Class is more challenging than expected. Work outside of class is necessary in order to do well (obviously). Go to office hours. He drops lowest online and written hw. But do hw well because it adds up.

A bit too easy for those of us who have spent any time with higher level mathematics. Class material was fairly simplistic, but very useful if you haven't encountered it before. Professor was excellent, although a lot of time was wasted repeating things and re-writing notes on the board. Take this class if you need a fun, less-challenging math course to round out a busy schedule. It serves as a good primer for Stats, Prob, Discrete Math, and a whole host of other classes.

She's the definition of bland. Had no personality whatsoever, or command over her class. She rushed through examples instead of actually explaining the process. Definitely bad at explaining in a way that makes sense to a group of non-major students (which 99% of us were.) However, she does make herself as available as possible for office hours.

very solid class, easy to follow. doesn't assume any prior math knowledge so a good class for non-STEM people needing to fulfill requirements. Kristina is always available to help and grading was fair.

I took this class in Spring 2025 (it just wasn’t available as a selection when writing this review). Overall, it’s a very manageable and is the definition of an easy A, though you should expect to spend around 3 hours per week on homework.
The class moves at a fairly slow pace, and most of the concepts are straightforward - especially if you’re comfortable with basic math. Kristina genuinely cares about her students' success and did an excellent job preparing us for the midterms and final exam.
There are weekly quizzes every Friday, so regular attendance is important. However, the quizzes are quite easy and often include bonus riddles that can help boost your score.
I’d recommend this class if you have a solid grasp of foundational math. Some of my peers struggled a bit, especially those who didn’t feel as confident in math, but I personally found it very easy. It’s a great option if you’re looking to fulfill a math requirement or raise your GPA with a low-stress course.

Very strict and particular with grading; TAs grade not the professor and she provides no leniency or grace with deadlines outside of a 10 minute late extension for homework assignments past 11:59pm. A very "if I offer it to one student, I must offer it to everyone else" professor. Don't recommend if you're a chronic skipper, this class heavily relies on in-person attendance. If you're committed it could live up to its "easy" reputation, but if you don't stay consistent with coursework, it's really easy to fall behind and hard to catch back up. Take advanatage of office hours if you're struggling, professor is kind and willing to help, but a stickler for policies.

Professor Cernekova is awesome! I had no prior knowledge of financial math and was really only taking this class because I needed to fufill my computational gen ed and didn't want to take calc. I will say this class was not a walk in the park. You have to be attentive in class and stay up to date with everything, but professor cernekova is very helpful with any questions you have. Exams are very reasonable but you have to put in the work, and when they say she's a fair grader it's true, but not in a forgiving sense. Overall I thought this was a good class, but if you want an A, you're going to have to put in the work.

Professor Nabb was an amazing professor! Everyone in the class was loved him and always had a great time. He explained the material very clearly and was so engaging. There were three exams and biweekly quizzes. He collected homework one Friday and had a quiz the next and so on. He is a professor at the community college, so he explained the material clearly and slowly and wasn't too full of himself to help us like some tenured UVA professors are. I highly recommend taking this class as your math requirement. I found it to be very easy and useful in the real world (we learned about stocks/bonds, mortgages, credit card payments, investing).

Nabb is a dawg. Great guy, pretty solid teacher. The course itself is pretty easy, but nabb definitely helps clear up any confusion. You don't need much background in math as it is all pretty simple equations, but if you have taken Calc 1 or 2 you will find it incredibly easy. There were hws every other week and quizzes on the opposite weeks. Neither were very difficult or time consuming. He uses the book, but it's mostly for the hw problems. I'd recommend going to class but if you miss he teaches more or less out the book so it's fine to make up but his lectures are definitely better than learning from the book. I found the exams to be pretty easy as you are provided with the equations, so as long as you know what's going on its a bit of plug and play. I didn't feel like I learned that much about financial stuff as it was more math and less concepts (more or less), but nonetheless a great course.

Nabb was an amazing professor and a very chill/ nice guy (he even brought us pies on national pie day. He really cares that you're doing well in the course so always ask questions if you have them because he'll genuinely take the time to go back through and explain it to you (doesn't make you feel dumb for asking). Exams were easy if you did the homework and did some studying, but hours on end is not necessary. As a psyc major, I found this class to be pretty easy and highly enjoyable. Everything we learned was relevant to our lives and i feel like this is one of the first classes i've ever taken that has prepared me for life after school. Overall, super interesting, low-stress, easy A course with a great prof.

I am genuinely NOT a math person and I got an A in this class. You are allowed to have notecards during exams. Every other week you have homework/quiz (alternates). Practice exams are posted (with answers) before quizzes and exams - everything you need to know is in there. If you put in a bit of effort, you'll be good. IF YOU ARE LIKE ME AND DIDN'T WANT TO TAKE ANY MATH CLASS TAKE THIS ONE. Liles is a little disorganized at times but she's really sweet and understanding. Also it's relevant stuff (credit cards, mortgage, loans).
Dat's Right! The GOAT of Professors! If you hate math, enjoy random and incredible tangents, and want a solid grade take Ala's class. Doesn't get any better than Professor A!

Professor A is a nice guy and a fun lecturer, but it's hard to get in touch with him via email and follow-up with him.  If you study, you'll do fine.  If you don't study and aren't a math person... good luck.  I am not a math person and took this class because I heard it was pretty easy and was unpleasantly surprised by the difficulty (I studied pretty hard).

Ala is the absolute man. The class is very easy but still worth taking, because it is good stuff to know in whatever career you have.  Unless you are just plain bad at math, the class requires very minimal studying to get a good grade. Study a reasonable amount (2.5 hours) before the test and getting above a 90 will be a breeze. Most importantly, Ala is very interesting guy to listen to and he goes off on very cool tangents. He's been a great guy to get to know.

Mojdeh was a good instructor for this class who taught the material clearly in a way that was pretty easy to understand. This class is definitely one of the easiest math classes you can take at UVA, and one of the most applicable too. Although the curriculum varies by semester, the class covered lots of basic financial topics that are very applicable in daily life - interest, annuities, mortgages, retirement planning, credit cards, etc. Unlike most of the math classes I had taken in high school, I actually felt like I was getting something out of this class that I could use and apply in the future - not just learning math for the sake of completing credits. Calculators were needed for all aspects of the class, which was welcoming given calculator rules in other math classes at UVA.Assignments consisted of biweekly homework assignments and quizzes (alternating weeks), neither of which were too challenging. Group work was encouraged for the homework assignments and quiz studying. The two midterm exams were not cumulative, but did include a bit of information from previous concepts learned in the class (lots of the material builds on concepts from earlier in the class). The final exam was cumulative and a formula sheet was allowed. #tCFspring2022

If you're looking for an easy A math class and wondering if Christopher Lloyd is a decent instructor to take it with, he is!! I will say, he is SUPER smart and obviously passionate about mathematics, so when I took the course he sometimes struggled to dumb it down enough for us non-STEM/ non-math folks. It's also just generally a pretty boring topic, so it is not at all an exciting class and can be hard to sit through lectures sometimes. But, he definitely knows what he's talking about and is willing to help you if you ask him for extra help. Generally, I would recommend you form a little study group with 1-2 other people in the class and work through old quizzes and homework/classwork before quizzes and tests if you can. Questions you've already seen/ solved will DEFINITELY show up again, and it sucks when you know you've seen it before but just can't remember how to solve it. So look over previous quizzes and assignments! When I took it (pre-covid) there were weekly quizzes, but they were usually pretty short and not too bad. He also dropped the lowest 2 quiz grades, which was a huge help. We had a few homework assignments but most of the work was done in-class when he gave examples, so take good in-depth notes to look over and you should be fine! There is a midterm exam and a final exam.

As a guy considering finance as a potential career path for later, I'm glad I took the opportunity to enroll in Financial Mathematics with Mark last semester.  Much of what you will learn is completely applicable to typical questions you encounter every day regarding your personal finances.  Among the topics we touched on included annuities, interest, mortgages, and stocks.  The course itself is pretty straightforward and manageable if you put about two hours in every week to understand the material, and Mark offers a plethora of office hours if you have any questions about it.  If you have even a passing interest in finance, I highly recommend you enroll in this class.  If not, the skills you will learn will still be very useful down the road.

There is not many ways to make Financial Math interesting, but Mark Lewers tried his best. He made himself available to his students during office hours, which were especially helpful before exams. The only homework was weekly problem sets, but they could be confusing and therefore time consuming. The material is not hard, and I work recommend this for anyone who is not a math person but needs to fulfill the requirement.

Pretty straightforward and easy class. You learn a lot about the time value of money, and it's pretty useful. There is weekly homework and quiz every other week. Willis is a good professor and does a good job of conveying the information. Also helpful via email or office hours.

not as easy as people say it is. dont be fooled by the first two tests because the material gets more complexed and there is no partial credit even though there is no multiple choice (which i thought was ridiculous). i went to office hours before every exam, which were awkward, and still did poorly because of the grading. overall, dont take this class and think it is a guaranteed A.
Prof. Pollo is the most akward, boring professor I've had. The class is by no means easy and the final is particularly difficult.

The class was at least twice the size that it should have been. This did not make it any easier for Mr. Pollio to teach the course; however, sitting through his class was about as engaging and effective as listening to a math textbook being read aloud. As was said before, the material for the class is deceiving as it becomes complicated very quickly. No partial credit on exams, which I feel is absurd for a math course of any kind. If you need a lower-level math course for the sole purpose of fulfilling College of Arts and Sciences' area requirements, DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. I found it to be miserable.

I took this class as an alternative to retaking calc, and to fill my Math/Science requirement in the College.  Overall, it wasn't a bad course, the material is much easier than calculus, and the workload is not bad- 1 homework assignment and 1 quiz a week, 2 midterms and a final.  Slinker was not the best professor; he always made mistakes while doing problems on the board and wasn't always clear, but he was ok  I'd probably recommend taking this class with another professor if possible.

The class itself wasn't that hard but Slinker is terribly awkward. Friends who took this class other semesters with a different teacher had much better reviews and did better overall. Weekly homework and one question quiz, plus two midterm tests and the final

This course was great as a non-stem major looking to fulfill my math requirement. Assignments are super straightforward and easy, it's basically geometry but thinking more about the "why" behind formulas and whatnot rather than just asking you to memorize them. Lectures and assignments felt a bit tedious at times since the content was pretty simple, but if you just go along with it and participate on occasion it's easy to get through. #tCFS25

Professor Choi is really nice and understanding. The work seemed a bit tedious sometimes, and some questions were worded in an unnecessarily complicated way, but as long as you show you are trying, you'll be fine. You can get exempt from the final, which is nice. There are responses to the lecture, weekly assignments, at home quizzes here and there, 2 projects, 3 unit tests, and a potential final. All unit tests are open note. #tCFfall25

First of all, Irina is great! I am not a math-oriented person. She was patient and never made me feel like I was inadequate because of my inability to understand. Instead, she often helped me after class or during lessons to actually be able to UNDERSTAND the material. I never had a problem with tests, which is hard to believe for me; I feel like I learned a lot, despite little to no interest! Sometimes the amount of homework can be annoying, but she grades very liberally and only twice per semester in what she calls "journal checks." She is funny and approachable, and responded to emails quickly and efficiently! You will need the book and you will need to show up to class every day (there is a 2% deduction if you don't), but I truly enjoyed this course and Irina!

Professor Feeley is the most kind and caring Professor I have had here at UVA. He is so clear about EVERYTHING and his study guides are the same as the tests. He is so passionate about his job and made me love math. As someone who absolutely hated math throughout high school, I am telling you that this class will change your perspective. If you get above a 90 on all 3 exams you are exempt from the final. Professor Feeley really just wants all his students to succeed and gain an appreciation for math. If you need to take a math class, TAKE THIS!!! It is the best class!!

I loved this class. Professor Feeley truly cares about his students. He made me like math again. You can tell how passionate he is about math. I highly recommend this class or any class with him. I'm surprised there aren't more reviews praising this class. Overall, it isn't much work, is not hard, and is not something to stress about BUT don't take this as you won't learn anything, you will! #tCFfall25

Professor Choi is pretty great- she is probably one of the nicest profs I've had at UVA. It is definitely an easy math class to take for any math requirement. Some people did struggle a bit, but I am not a math person at ALL and was able to easily finish with an A. I would highly, highly, recommend paying a lot of attention during lecture and writing down all examples, as well as doing all of the homework and reviewing the homework in-depth before quizzes or exams, because a lot of the same stuff shows up. She definitely gives you the material to get A's on every quiz and exam, as long as you actually do the assigned homework and ask questions if you don't understand. Sometimes class can drag on and on because she focuses on easy concepts for too long, but even this didn't bother me too much since it just shows that she really wants to be sure that everyone understands the concepts. She did assign a bit too much homework when Covid first hit and we had to abruptly go online, but I think this was just her confusion with the online format and hopefully by now she has figured out how to make the homework more manageable. BUT, some concepts are challenging and won't be the easiest thing to grasp. She always offers office hours though, and as I said, doing the homework and actually studying it before any exam/quiz is the best way to do well in this class.

AMAZING MATH CLASS!! If you just need to take a math class for the requirement, take this class. It is so easy to get an A in. First, you only need to get above a 92 to get an A. Grade is 30% tests, so each of the 3 tests is 10% of your grade. Then another 10% is participation, which is just showing up to class. Another 10% is the homework, which is completion. Then another 10% is weekly quizzes, which are 5-6 questions, very easy. Then 20% is 2 projects and the last 20% is the final, which you can exempt. I did 1 hour of work MAX each week for this class and was able to get an A in the class. The topics for the course were - addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, fractions, and various visual representations of base ten units, positive and negative numbers, and topics similar to these. Professor Choi is so understanding and nice and base the 8 am lectures better. SHe responds to emails so quick and is very kind with stepping through material in class when someone has a question. I loved this class so much that I am taking another one of her math classes next semester!

Professor Beamer means well but he makes the class a lot more complicated than it has to be. This class is dedicated to students who are wishing to go into the teaching field; specifically, it is oriented towards potential elementary school teachers. The classes are extremely boring but required because not attending entails a 2% deduction on your grade. Moreover, he gives a lot of homework that comes off as busywork as it is never graded for correctness but rather completion. The exams are really easy but he is super picky about things like diagrams, pictures, and explanations. Overall, it is a GPA-padding class but it is super boring; be sure to get work for other classes done while you're in this one. As much as I love Zack, I think that this class and its material is too dry. As a prospective teacher, I do not think I learned anything meaningful for real-world applications. All the subject matter is stuff that a good algebra student should intuitively know.

This class was both easy and frustrating. It was easy, because Thomasey did not really teach the material in the right way (which I admit is difficult since it is elementary-level content). It was frustrating, because I actually wanted to gain something from the course since I plan on teaching elementary school students. I think Thomasey should have used the textbook a lot more than he did. The textbook does a great job of combining easy content with more challenging modes of understanding that content. If you are taking the class for an easy A/math credit, I would say don't get the textbook at all. If you want to teach elementary school, I would absolutely recommend the textbook. While I do think Thomasey was not the greatest instructor, he was very enthusiastic and receptive to feedback.

One of the easiest courses I've taken at UVA. However, I have a few warnings: (1) Thomasey will take off a ridiculous amount of points for small errors. The top of your papers will say -2, but that -2 will be out of 10, for instance. (2) He loves manipulatives, so take careful notes on those.
The material itself was pretty easy, in my opinion. I got an A+ with minimal effort, and it got one of the dreaded math/science requirements out of the way.

Professor Daniel James is very kind and really wants everyone to succeed in the course. I was in growth based and I did not receive many 4/4's until the end of the course so I basically had an F until the final exam. Since growth based is graded more harshly than standard grading it is very difficult to get a high score under that syllabus. However, if you work hard and ask questions in growth based you can succeed. I would encourage you to look at the feedback you get on each exam and the rubric for what they are looking for in order to do well. I did this towards the end and it helped me a lot. I ended with a B after having an F the whole time so I'm glad I pushed through. You can do it if you study and ask questions!

I took Math 1190 with Professor Kurtz and she is by far the best professor to have. Definitely take Calc with her if you can. She made the class enjoyable, was funny, and would walk through all the steps needed to make sure that we understood what we were learning. She also wrote the 1190/1210 quizzes and exams so she would explain what to expect. Because she wrote the exams, Prof. Kurtz would take student feedback into consideration when writing the next assessment. Prof. Kurtz was always super prepared and cared about you as a person. She is very down to earth and made it clear that perfection is not expected and that no matter what the outcome of your performance in Calc is, you will accomplish what you want in life. The class was very laid back and after going over the first problem, we were often then told to work and teach people around us. I wasn't a fan in the beginning, but as the semester progressed, I liked it more. It was also a great way for the class to bond. Assignments consisted of classpreps (due before each class), Webassigns (every week (access through the textbook)), Friday attendance (the only main difference between 1210), and quizzes and exams. I was in the Standard section so quizzes made up 5% of your grade but each exam was worth 20% and the final was worth 25% (1190 has the same quizzes and exams as 1210 and is not given "easier" exams). MATH 1190/1210 Growth-Based had a different grading system based on the mastery of each learning target. Though I don't know for sure, I was told that Growth-Based has slightly harsher grading and not as much partial credit because they get retakes whereas Standard gets one try but much more partial credit. I found partial credit to be a huge lifesaver. They made it completely possible for you to get full credit on some questions even if you got the wrong answer. One of their main goals is to asses whether or not you understand the process you are supposed to complete rather than focusing on getting the correct answer (on assessments, write down the steps you would take and any important info from the question, even if you don't know which numbers or expressions to use :).
If you aren't sure if you should take 1190 or 1210 I would say that if you have any background in calc and have done decently, take 1210 and leave room in the class for those who have not had experience in calc. The only difference between 1190 and 1210 is that 1190 meets for a longer time and has a Friday session. All 1190/1210 student share the same Canvas page and are expected to complete the same assignments. 1190/1210 quizzes and exams are the exact same and you will test together. Quizzes and exams are all graded the same (they aren't even looking at who they are grading when they are grading and each professor takes a question or two and only grades those questions for all 1190/1210 students- so don't worry about being graded differently based on what section you are in). #tCFS24

I took this class with no prior experience in calculus and received an A- this is due to Professor Kurtz. She has a straightforward and streamlined way of explaining problems, which makes the material easier to understand. She taught 1210 and 1220 before, and she is certainly an effective professor for both of them. I barely had to put any work outside just lecture time, since lectures were enough to understand what I needed to do. I was in the growth-based section, so I did get re-takes, but there was not as much partial credit. However, I prefer the standard-section grading and would not do growth-based again if I had the option. This class doesn't have any trigonometry in it (which I consider to be difficult), and the problems are mostly basic. MATH 1190 is for those who are entering without any experience or want to have an algebra review.

I just want to say, Professor Demers is one of the best professors I've ever had. He is so (and I can't emphasize this enough) SO good at explaining concepts and you can tell he loves what he does. He never makes you feel stupid for asking a question or getting an answer wrong; he actually seems excited by it. He treats it like an opportunity to learn. If you get a question wrong, he'll say, "Ooo! Interesting. I see where you're going with that. Lets see, if we plug in that number here what would we get? ... Yeah, see, it seems that number wouldn't work. What other numbers could we try?" He's truly the sweetest professor I've ever had and I cant recommend him enough. Other students who come to his open office hours always remark on how good he is at explaining things. I was very luck to have him as a professor!

Wendi is an amazing Professor. Has office hours around the clock. Also had Bennett R. As a TA and the guy is a legend. This class is a bit easier than 1210 since you get a better curve but take the same exams.

The way that the course is set up is not the best in my opinion. A lot of it is self-taught rather than having the professor teach you how to actually do the math. I'm not sure why they believe this is the most conducive. We pay them for a reason.

Professor Bourdon is an amazing teacher with a profound love for math. He is very passionate and makes class enjoyable with his wacky personality. Generally lovely guy. However, this class is also quite difficult, though not impossible . It is absolutely necessary to attend class and very helpful to work with other classmates (which Prof Bourdon also encourages). I found office hours to be useful because he teaches at a quick pace in class and it can be difficult to keep up for less math inclined minds. Can be a tricky class but also enjoyable because of Professor Bourdon’s passion and personality.

I took this in Fall 2020 #tCF2020
Prof Bourdon is the best teacher I have  ever had, and not just at UVA. I have never before taken a math class where i felt confident in what I was learning. He was always very generous with his time, and gave an insane amount  of extra credit opportunities. If you put  in the work, you will learn so much from this class. I am a humanities student all the way, but this class made me excited to continue studying math. I could not recommend Bourdon enough
Horrid professor and abysmal class.  Unless you have no choice but to take this class I suggest you look for your math requirement elsewhere.

this class was absolutely horrible and perhaps the most confusing grading system I have ever witnessed. If you are not adept at calculus you will suffer as you only gain credit for getting everything correct on a problem set. getting a single mistake on a single problem on a page with multiple problems will cause the entire section to be worth 0. make that make sense. Also these grad students are genuinely incompetent. My instructor said in class "sometimes I get 2+2 wrong" like bro what do you mean. I am about to get a c in this class because I make a single mistake on a problem and then the entire page is worth 0 even if you get eveyrthing else correct. Do not take this class it genuinely should be abolished from the school.

This class was really hard and took up a lot of time. The grading was super strict, and it felt like no matter how much effort I put in, it didn’t help my grade much. I’ve taken calculus before, so I thought I’d understand it better, but a lot of the topics didn’t make sense. The teacher didn’t always explain things clearly, and the assignments were really long and confusing. Sometimes it felt like we were expected to know things that weren’t even taught. There wasn’t much help when we had questions, and the tests were really tough. I spent so many hours trying to figure things out on my own. Overall, I highly would not recommend this class unless you absolutely have to take it. It was stressful and frustrating, and there are probably better options out there that actually help you learn instead of just making you feel lost.

My instructor was Susan Mitchell and she was a good teacher. I took both calculus 1 and 2 in high school but needed to take this course to get credit for my major so it was very easy. There are weekly homeworks and 2 group assignments. There are pre-class assignments which are kind of annoying especially if you know the material already but most get posted a lot ahead of time so i would just speedrun through them. I was a growth-based student and i found this structure to be very easy because i could retake questions i did not do well on during the next exam. #tCFS25
Prof. Sherman is an excellent instructor.

If you have to take this class, take it with another teacher. David Sherman was unnecessarily sassy pretty much all the time and frankly wasn't a very good teacher. I had already taken a calculus class so I knew everything we learned, but I found during group work I would be the one teaching my partner because he didn't. He had a rule for group work where every single time all semester we did it, we had to pick someone we had never worked with before. Towards the end of the year it took ridiculously long to find someone to work with, time that could've been spent working problems. He also said "minus" instead of negative, which are two completely separate things and caused confusion. Weekly webassigns, some random written homework, 2 midterms, and a final. The first midterm wasn't curved, the second was, and I think there's a curve at the end of the class as well.

He's pretty much your run of the mill math professor. Very intelligent, a little condescending, but and moves pretty quickly. He's a pretty nice guy though, and he doesn't have an accent like a lot of the teachers which is a huge plus. If you haven't taken calc before you should definitely read up a bit before the class no matter what professor you have. Not an incredably hard class to get an A in, just do the weekly homework and study for the exams and the curve will carry you home.
He's sassy but an excellent teacher of the actual material. Take his class if you need help learning the material, everything is taught very simply.

Professor Sherman may have been a not so interesting lecturer, and can appear as sassy in class, but he is very helpful during his office hours. There were a few hand written homework on the history of math, book problems and graph drawings, but the homework that took a long time was the online work. It may be the same for every applied calc class though. If you do take this class, I would suggest in finding a partner to help each other on the online work; you would finish it faster and learn better. I would recommend Prof. Sherman because he's more experienced. I took two classes with a graduate before switching to Prof. Sherman's class, and I could obviously see the difference between the two.

I actually took this Summer of 2023 (wasn't a drop-down menu option). I love math so I didn't think this class was too bad. Taking math in the summer is the best way in my opinion because it is consistent and is a fast pace which is how I thrive. I also took AB and BC calc in high school so I found this class to be more review than anything. The content is EASY. The hardest part of this class is appealing to what Prof. Sherman wants when you turn in daily homework/exams. He wants people to write out all of their math in English sentences and only turn that in on some problems (requests NO other work shown). This was very frustrating for me because my past calc teacher would always tell us to just write out our work because he could follow along. This was very annoying because I was always chasing a good grade based on his own expectations that had nothing to do with the difficulty of the content. If you need to take it in the summer, just do it because I still ended with an A, and had fun being in a smaller class (getting to know other people). Just be prepared to be annoyed for 4 weeks until it is over.

Professor Kurtz is a really good Professor and makes the material really easy to understand. She holds office hours right before the exams and will go over any material. I am not the best at math so I wasn't sure what to expect going into this course but it's not hard at all to get an A in her class -- just go to class and ask any questions you have. Definitely the easiest, best, and most fun Professor to take for this math class.

Professor Kurtz is so amazing. If you're going to take calculus and its not really important for your major (bio for ex) take it with her! She is so understanding and makes class enjoyable. She gives partial credit on tests and she's also super flexible I've had so many office hours with her and each time I feel better about what we learned. It's still a difficult course but if you need to take it shes probably the best professor to do it with!

Professor Kurtz is phenomenal. This class is perfect for non math majors, so if that is you, I would recommend taking this class with her. I am not the best at math and I managed to get an A- in her class. She cares a lot about her students, and is more than willing to help and answer any questions you may have. She is VERY kind with grading, and gives partial credit where partial credit is due. I took this class during the summer, so the material was much faster paced than it would have been in fall or spring semester, but overall, professor Kurtz made the material pretty understandable. She has a great and fun personality as well, so she made the class much more enjoyable than any other math professor would have. If you want a good grade in calculus, do yourself a favor and take it with professor Kurtz!

I took this in my first semester as a first-year. If I hadn't just taken calculus in high school a few months prior, I probably wouldn't have done as well. There are a lot of resources for extra help and practice but sometimes it's overwhelming because the pace of the course is fast. It also feels tedious to do the homework (which is the best form of practice). Yaolong is an average-good teacher, he's open to questions and his work is easy to follow. The course takes a lot of self-initiative if you don't follow what's going on. Don't take this class unless you really need to fulfill a pre-req. #tCFfall2021

Ok, I took this Fall '22, but it wouldn't let me select that. Sonkin is a very nice professor, but the way he teaches is almost unbearable. He starts class usually by introducing a theory or process we'll need that day, then goes through several examples. However, the classwork that is supposed to correspond to his lesson is often barely applicable. There is a huge disconnect between what he teaches and what is actually needed to be successful in the course. If you take this class, I highly recommend attending regular P2L sessions, watching Organic Chemistry Tutor on Youtube, and luck sometimes. I am not a math person, and this class really affirmed it. Even in the assessments we had to take (3 quizzes and 2 exams, plus the final), the questions were much more applied than the basic homework questions we were given. Be prepared to put in a lot of extra time for this class if calculus doesn't come naturally to you, or try to take the pilot course, which seems much more focused on learning and growth.

Michael is a grad(?) student, so not a professor, but he's really smart and does a great job of teaching this class. If you have to take this for a prereq or something else, try to get him as your teacher. I took 1210 because there's no discussion section, but there are multiple P2L (peer tutoring) optional sections you can attend every week taught by students who have taken the course before if you need more practice or have random questions. You can also go to his office hours if you want some better-informed help/advice. Grades are based off "minute" papers which are just quick one-question sheets you fill out at the beginning of all classes, WebAssign/Gradescope assignments, and like 5ish assessments. It seems like a lot but is very doable and the assignments are quick. You do have to pay like $100+ just to access the webassigns though which is really annoying imo because there's no way around it (you can't just find a pdf of textbook). I took calc in high school but never took the AP test so did not get credit, and I've gotten 100% on every test so far this year. I think it might be a bit difficult if you have absolutely no experience or background with calculus, but the style of the class is very similar to one in high school (no laptops, worksheets handed out every class, and you follow along with teacher/work with classmates) so it's chill.

Susan Mitchell is amazing! If you have the chance to take her class, do it. Her classes meet three times a week for 50 minutes, which is so much better than two 75-minute sessions. She’s patient, understanding, and so kind. she really cares about her students and makes an effort to ensure EVERYONE in the class understands whats going on.

This guy isn't the greatest. It seems like the UVA math department has a vendetta against the rest of the world. He teaches straight from the book, but somehow manages to make the book more confusing than it is. They also run the class as if you already took calc before you came here. He's not exactly helpful, but at least he let us know straight in the beginning that we "only take 2% of my time" and that he really doesn't care.

I had a good experience. Willing to help. Writes relevant formulas on board. it goes without saying but don't procrastinate on weekly homework. its easy to forget about the written portion.survey of calculus is quite comfortable for a calculus class overall.
*apparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limitapparently I'm under the word limit*

I enjoyed this class. The work load was very doable. It consisted of a few online homework assignments 1-3 times a week, along with a longer weekly assignment we were required to work on throughout the week. The homework assignments are graded, but you are given instant feedback and are able to fix your answers until you get it right, a feature that I enjoyed. There aren't many quizzes maybe 2-3 throughout the whole semester. Also, there are only 2 midterms and 1 final exam. The midterms were very doable. If you took calculus in high school, you will be fine. But if you didn't it may be hard, because she kind of just reteaches the material to us, rather than teaching. But, it isn't impossible and the textbook would be your friend if so.

Professor Kristinia is an okay professor. It is just really frustrating to spend 45 minutes of class learning the basics of a concept and reviewing basic problems. Then, there is no time left to tackle the difficult problems where everyone in the class needs help. The class design sucks, and you barely learn anything in-class.A big problem with the course is the lack of correlation between the HW assignments and the exams. Every exam is a bit of a shock if you don't spend a significant amount of time prepping on your on. My high school Calc experience kind of saved me since I already felt good on most of it.The grading was very frustrating. All semester I got large amounts of partial credit taken off and it accumulated quickly because my work was deemed "unclear" or I didn't explain it using words. I hardly ever knew why I got points off constantly because there is no explanation and I copied my professors notation from class.

I took this class in Fall of 2023 and I had a lot of friends in the class which helped me enjoy it more. Kristina is a very sweet and wholesome person. She is very understanding about your problems and is always willing to help outside of class. She does check attendance with PollEverywhere and assigns the same homework and worksheets as all of the other Calc 1 teachers. I don't think her teaching is the best and I did fine because I knew most of the information before I took this class, but she is willing to help if you have questions and office hours are super easy to attend. I was in the Growth-Based Section of Calc 1, which I was not a fan of. In growth-based, each learning target on the test (so each question) is graded out of 4. You essentially need to get as many 4/4s as you can get. You have the opportunity to retake each learning target 2 more times to get 4/4. The only issue is that the retakes start to add up and you can end up spending 2+ hours on these tests (there are 6 including the final), working on material from months ago. Its a lot of work and its more beneficial to get 4/4 on some questions and get 0/4 on the others than to get all questions with a 3/4 because you have to redo them all if you don't master it (if this makes sense). The non-growth-based sections simply take the class as normal and the tests are a simple percentage out of 100, without any retakes. You have no choice of which section you will be in, its all random. The material isn't hard and there is a lot of study help, but understanding the way the course works can be super confusing. In the end it probably doesn't matter if you want to take this course because it is required for a lot of majors but take Kristina. A lot of the professors are the same teaching style, at least she is nice and you'll mostly know what she is talking about. She pushes you to talk to people around you and I made a lot of friends this way.

I was in an experimental section of this course, which graded us based off of achieving mastery through retakes. I found this actually discouraged studying, and made it difficult to attain a high grade. Hasan was nice enough but clearly isn't suited well to teaching.

This class is really easy if you've already taken calculus, but I know a lot of people who haven't and most struggled. It's kind of hit or miss with which instructor you get, but mine was really chill and made sure everyone understood the material (not every instructor was as good). Most of the grade is three big tests, two midterms and a final, and there isn't two much homework besides Webassign outside of it. Again, a little hit or miss, but it is required for a lot of majors and programs, and I've heard it is easier than regular calc.

Do not take this class with Professor Sonkin. I did well in the course, but no thanks to this professor. Thank god that the homework and tests are all done departmentally. He did not prepare us well for the tests at all. You must go back through the book to learn if you have this professor because his lectures will not teach you anything. Honestly, you'd probably be better off not even attending his lectures. Otherwise, if you have taken calculus before then the webassigns are easy and the tests aren't too bad.

Do whatever you can to take this class somewhere other than UVA if you aren't coming in with a very strong background in calculus. The department is really not great and the tests are the same for every class so if your teacher isn't good you will not do well.

I had Prof Sonkin, but for some reason, he wasn't listed. He's a  pretty good professor, but he's very quite and kind of hard to understand. He's much better in office hours if you really need the help. As far as the course is concerned, it's fairly easy to understand material, if you've taken any calculus in high school, it's essentially the same material, but the individual questions on exams are much harder. Good luck.

If you have taken calc before this class is super easy. even if you havent its not bad. there are 2 midterms and a final, your TA could give written hw and quizzes or not, we convinced our instructor to stop giving them and to restructure the class half way through the semester. If you need to fill a math/calc requirement this is the one you shuould take. The grading on exams is super annoyingly strict and is not communicated well but the exams arent terrible.

This class is taught by a variety of grad students, so depending on who you get it can matter a lot. Everyone is given the same test, but if your teacher sucks then it's way much harder. I had taken calc before, so I didn't have to do too much work, but if I hadn't then I would have definitely struggled a lot more. I would be  wary taking this class without any calc experience, because it really depends on the teacher. Also, the are several online homework assignments a week that can be a little tedious, but manageable. The midterms were not too difficult, but the final was very much unlike what we had learned in some ways. I would not take this class if you dont have calc experience unless you have to.

IF YOU DIDN'T TAKE CALC IN HIGH SCHOOL DO NOT TAKE 1210! I would highly recommend taking 1190 if you didn't take calc before. The reason why I didn't take 1190 is because I found out after the withdraw date passed that the comm school would accept 1190. I had Rostislav Akhmechet. He would try to make jokes to lessen the awkward silence in class. He taught as if everyone in the class already took calc. There were a couple of students who were in the same boat that I was. I tried going to office hours but when I asked a question I felt as if he was giving me "DUH" answers as if I took calc before. It didn't matter how many times I would explain to him that I did not calc before, he would still answer my questions with more math terms that I didn't understand. I know that he is very knowledgeable about the material but he is just not a very good teacher.  For assignments, we had to do about 2 or 3 webassigns before quizzes and tests. There were also written homework, which he was more lenient towards. There are 2 exams and the final. Good luck if you take this course in general.

Fast paced calc class with lots of homework and quizzes. Definitely don't take this unless you've taken calc before. Grade averages depend a lot on the TA, but mostly the tests average is a C+. If you do the homework and go to class, it is definitely possible to get an A

I had Kristina King as my instructor. She is a grad student, like most of the Math 1210 instructors, and pretty nice and a solid teacher although a little boring. This is a pretty straightforward class with easy quizzes and homework but somewhat obnoxious tests. There are often questions that never appeared on homework or quizzes that you have to sort of figure out for yourself. They are certainly not impossible, but made me irritated that we never got an opportunity to try something like them before. I would, however, highly recommend this class for people who need to satisfy a math requirement, especially if it's specifically Calc I (I personally needed it for Batten). Take this class over normal Calc I if you can, EVEN if you've taken Calc I in high school, because it is much easier and geared towards social science majors.

I had Aron Daw, and he was a great TA. Definitely very enthusiastic about math and gave really good examples in class. The homework and quizzes were easy. There are two "midterms" and a final. You get 3-4 previously administered exams to practice for each, but the exams prove to often be unpredictable. The first exam was pretty good, the second was a bit harder,  but the final was an absolute joke. There were a lot of questions that had no business being on that exam and they ended having the curve the final, so it worked out. Overall, as long as you put in time pulling off an A is not difficult in this course, and you do not need to have taken Calc before to do well.

😐. Took AP Calc AB in high school. I wish I could go back and bully myself into paying attention more. This is supposedly the easier of the calc I courses at UVA but the way it is taught is so gosh darn frustrating. Classes are taught by grad students, who know the material, but sometimes struggle with conveying it to students. My advice if you have to take this class is to find a group of people in your section to check homework with and go to office hours. P2L sessions kind of helped but more often than not we only got through like 2-3 problems. It was a lot of definitions of math rather than equation and applications, which isn't bad itself but I really just wanted the equations and do my work without writing proofs for everything. They like to see work done in a specific, methodological manner and it shows when they grade your work. Good luck.

I would not recommend taking this course to fulfill any requirements unless you already have some experience in calculus and are just trying to refresh yourself. Even then, there are probably better and less stressful alternatives out there. Quizzes will constantly throw tricky questions that were not properly explored in class. Piazza contributions are also graded, and in order to receive full marks for it, you will have to submit around 50 posts. I took this class with Wu and, while I have nothing personal against her, I found her classes boring at best and extremely confusing at worst. It was not even that the content was particularly difficult, the explanations were just very poor and dry. She is not very good at getting the class to participate, and group work was often awkward and drawn out.

The math itself is easy, easier than my high school calculus AB class. So I did come into this class knowing pretty much all the material. Even so if your teacher is OK then you should be fine. All that said, the profs are grad students that are great at math and not so great at teaching unfortunately and it makes the class more difficult than it should be. Webassigns are easy (I recommend taking notes on these as I learned more from these than I did in class). Exams 1 and 2 not too hard but also slightly more difficult than expected. Final also not bad. Ended with an A-. Overall, this class wasn't bad, however, I think with prior knowledge the class is A LOT easier.

Whatever you do run for the HILLS before you take this class. UVA has grad students teach the course. We are supposed to "learn" the material on WebAssign during our homework before, but the web assign did not teach anything and I was so confused always.
Yangxiao (Howard) is the sweetest teacher. However, he is simply a grad student like all the rest of the "professors" with no experience teaching. This makes it EXTREMELY difficult to learn anything in class, so much to the point where I just stopped attending because it actually made me more confused.
Webassign homework is nice because you can try until you get 100. That's the only good thing about the class. Seriously this class was the bane of my existence and my friends'. The quizzes were pretty horrid - we all got 60s on the first one. They do curve though, so a 78 became an A-. The exams- DO NOT GET ME STARTED. They are unreal and unfair. The curve is literally 55 becomes a C because they are so bad. And it's so frustrating because we get worksheets on the topic we are learning every class, yet we would start them at 10 am, have to do them alone in our group before learning the content, and then Howard would start checking the worksheet literally at 10:48 am when the class ends at 10:50. it is seriously so unorganized and caused me distress. I would not recommend taking this class at UVA unless you need calc. If you need a math requirement, take something else. Everyone hates Math 1210.

Throughout my life I have been misled by this ridiculous notion that the derivative of people like you and me is zero, because people are constant and they can never change. But Howard (Yangxiao) proved this wrong because he changed and transformed me for the better. Best calc 1 class ever he's such a standup guy #howardgang4life

I took this Fall 2023. Math is not my favorite subject nor am I good at it. If you're debating between MATH 1310 and 1210, this one doesn't cover any geometry so it is significantly easier. Howard is a really nice guy. He just mainly goes through each worksheet during class. I went to his office hours once but didn't find it as helpful as the MCLC in Clemons Library. #tCFF23

This course is easier if you come into it with some Calculus (such as AB from high school) but I think it's very manageable either way. My instructor was very helpful in office hours and holding extra review sessions and he also responded to emails/questions quickly. Assignments are manageable and there are lots of extra credit opportunities.
he was a good professor, funny and very competent and helped a lot when I went to office hours. if he's teaching again in the spring I'd recommend him

Professor Liles was very disorganized and hard to learn from at times. She did a decent job at teaching the content, but overall, she made a lot of mistakes and rushed through some questions that were necessary for learning. This class overall is hard because you have to teach yourself before you actually get taught the content. The class has a lot of opportunities to get help outside of class which was very helpful which is very recommended because it is hard to understand most of the content from the class. Liles was great at communicating via email to the students. Attendance was not required and some classes were not necessary to go to.

The structure of this course fit with my learning style. In class, we worked through a worksheet problem-by-problem, practicing many types of problems. Our TA would then work through the problem on the board and explain how he solved it. Students could interrupt at any time and ask questions. In this way, the basis of this course was hands-on learning. Short online assignments due before each class were very helpful in warming me up to the material before we learned about it. It forced me to practice what I had learned frequently, which promotes learning. In the same way, longer homework assignments due weekly were helpful opportunities to synthesize all that we had learned throughout the week and work through problems we might see on the exam. A few quizzes were given periodically throughout the semester to gauge our understanding. In addition, we had two midterms and a final. Exams were on paper, were a fair difficulty, and well put-together. Overall, the structure of this course was done very well. Our grade was calculated in the following manner:
WebAssign homework (short assignments and longer ones): 10%Quizzes: 5%Written HW (uploaded online a few times throughout the year): 5%Classwork: 5%Midterm Exam 1: 22.5%Midterm Exam 2: 22.5%Final Examination: 30%
I enjoyed this course. I think it was structured in a way that promoted efficient and effective learning of the material. Our TA, Yaolong Shen, was kind, knowledgeable, engaging, and helpful. All students had the ability to ask questions for him to answer. He explained problems very well, and wanted to make sure all students understood the material.

It's Calc 1, but without the trig. It's a very honest class that doesn't have a lot of tricks up its sleeves. He curves individual tests, but not the final grade. You probably already know how this class is going to go before taking it tbh

Ms. Shalotenko was always very helpful inside and outside of class! Her office hours were during one of my other classes, so I often could not go, but she was always willing to meet outside of the class at other times! The class is pretty easy to do well in, so long as you do the homework and the Collab Discussion (that adds up to 25% of your grade right there), and do ALL of the practice tests because those will test your knowledge before the test (similar questions from the practice test are often on the real test). Good Luck! :)

I did not take calc in high school and still managed to get an A. Although the exams can be rough, if you properly go over classwork and the practice exams you should be able to not fail them. The exams and quizzes are definitely the worst part, but carefully read the syllabus and make sure you do everything else (piazza posts, webassign hw, polling questions) and you should be able to get 100%'s on that part of the grade which can really help you if you bomb some of the quizzes/exams. Overall it's definitely not an easy class especially if you have no prior experience in calc, but it's definitely doable.

The absolute  WORST class I have ever taken in my life.  If you are planning to take this class with Morgan, RUN.  He does not speak English well, is horribly disorganized, and doesn't help when help is needed.  Office hours were a pointless waste of time.  My worst grade my first semester because I was completely lost.  He made his "own" website for homework that was frustrating and did not work.  I repeat, if you sign up for Morgan, drop, withdraw, or run.  DON'T TAKE.

Morgan is such a sweet guy. The math department made this a harder class than it needed to be but Morgan constantly held office hours and review sessions that he didn't have to. He really cares about his students and tries to help you learn in the best way possible. Class may seem slow but he really explains the concepts well.

Pros:- flexible with office hours, tries to put in an effort in helping us learn the material with extra review sessionsCons:- Does not explain the material well; often loses his train of thought and teaches us often how NOT to do something rather than how to do it- No sense of difficulty; his graded review sheets before the exams were much harder than the actual exams and the practices.  They were often too hard to be beneficial- Disorganized; literally gives us assignments in the middle of an email that would appear to be irrelevant, for example, I once missed an assignment because he assigned it in the middle of an email with the subject line "Office hours for next Tuesday".  Also did not email us the review material for the final exam and does not seem to acknowledge that collab exists for a reason.Verdict:- Would not recommend at all.  Unfortunately all of his efforts into being available don't translate the slightest bit into being a decent teacher.   If you are in this class, transfer out.

Pros:- flexible with office hours, tries to put in an effort in helping us learn the material with extra review sessionsCons:- Does not explain the material well; often loses his train of thought and teaches us often how NOT to do something rather than how to do it- No sense of difficulty; his graded review sheets before the exams were much harder than the actual exams and the practices.  They were often too hard to be beneficial- Disorganized; literally gives us assignments in the middle of an email that would appear to be irrelevant, for example, I once missed an assignment because he assigned it in the middle of an email with the subject line "Office hours for next Tuesday".  Also did not email us the review material for the final exam and does not seem to acknowledge that collab exists for a reason.Verdict:- Would not recommend at all.  Unfortunately all of his efforts into being available don't translate the slightest bit into being a decent teacher.   If you are in this class, transfer out.

Alright, here goes. Let me start by saying that Aleksander is a very nice guy and he means well. He's incredibly intelligent, but one of the most socially awkward people you may ever meet. If you did not take calculus in high school I really recommend finding another professor. If you have not experienced Calc before he will confuse you and you will be lost. His reviews are much, much more difficult than the actual exams. Anything the Calc coordinators give you, make sure you take advantage of it. Webassign is a pain but it's an easy 10% of the grade and Aleksander integrates his own web assignment from a website he created (like I said, brilliant) but if you don't know Calc your best bet is will another guy in my humble opinion. MATH and STAT are not too great at UVA in general.

Really caring and nice guy, but very difficult to understand. If you have taken calculus in high school you will be okay, but sometimes his teaching differs from AP Calc in High school. If you have never taken calc, I suggest another professor. You really get to bond with your classmates over how weird the class is. As a student who got a 5 on the BC Calc exam, I still find this class difficult. Also, his worksheets before exams are MUCH more difficult than the exam.

This course really depends on the TA you get, as they teach the course and there is no professor. Morgan was very willing to help, but sometimes struggled to communicate his knowledge in to students. This next piece of info is more about the course in general and not specific to Morgan, but I would not reccomend taking this course without having previously taken calculus before. The pace is incredibly fast and not much instruction is given on the basics, so if you fall into this category, take applied calc with algebra.

Professor Morgan was an absolute beast. Lectures are fairly easy to follow and he explains the material very well.  If you have any troubles at all, he has regular office hours and if you cannot make the scheduled office hours, he is happy to meet your schedule so you get he help you need. He wants his students to do well and bumped me from an A- to an A at the end of the semester. Great man and a great teacher.  If you are taking MATH 1210 I recommend you take if with Aleksandr!

I was required to take Math 1210 because I am planning to declare my major as bio during my second year. Anyone who is required to take MATH 1210, I suggest that you do not take it with Ian. Ian is very knowledgeable about the material; however, he lacks interpersonal skills. He does not engage with his students. Also, he comes into class very dull. On the other hand, I had to watch youtube videos to really understand the material that was taught or go to a math tutor in Gilmer Hall because the way he teaches the material was confusing to me. Sometimes, he does not even write how he got certain steps on the board, which I felt was not helpful at all. I guess he expected us to know it. For his quizzes, it was difficult to know what material I should really study for because he does not specify. He would merely say "you will be quizzed on the material that I covered last week and this week." It turns out that is false because there are only specific sections that he covers on the quiz. By the way, his quizzes are usually only four questions. Another thing I would like to point out is how he rarely responds back to his emails, which my classmates have told me this whenever they had a question on the material taught. I highly suggest that you take this class with a different professor.

Definitely don't take this class if you don't need it. If you do need it (a lot of people do), it's bearable and you'll get through it but it's super important to do all of the homework and attend class. The majority of the TAs suck so your grade is pretty dependent on how much work you put into the class. It's not necessarily a difficult class, but it's definitely a pain in the ass. If you took calc in high school it shouldn't be too bad, but that's not to say it will be easy. I managed to get a B, so if you study and do your homework you should be fine, but it's gonna suck either way.

All of the "professors" for these math courses are actually just grad students who don't know a thing about teaching math. I feel like this class is pretty unavoidable if you want to do anything pre-med or pre-comm or really just most majors so sorry that you're going to have to go through this misery. My piece of advice would be GO TO OFFICE HOURS!!! You are assigned written homework every week that is about ten times harder than any of the webassign homework you are given and they are graded out of 100. If you go to office hours the teachers will practically just give you the answers and you'll get good grades. I made the mistake of not going to office hours for the first few weeks and my grade definitely suffered because of that. The webassign homework is alright. The tests on the other hand are also very difficult unless you go over the practice tests inside and out. The final was impossible honestly. I think I'll get a B for this semester and I did not have prior Calculus experience. Have fun :)

Literally the worst person to teach math at UVA. Mathew Feller is a seemly shy graduate student. One the first day of classes he rushed into the classroom almost late and he doesn't even introduce himself to the class. The class is very tiresome and his explanations are more complicated that what they actually should be. He doesn't quite smile, but I saw him smile once during office hours. There are times where he messed up during his teaching and students have to correct him. He often says "um."  Feller doesn't seem like a bad person outside of class, he just needs more trying when trying to teach college students. He's pretty fair about homework being turned in after the due date as long as you as for an extension before the due date.

Okay the two people below me need to chill the class isn't that hard, especially if you have prior Calculus knowledge, which I think most people do. Feller isn't a bad teacher, he is a little awkward, but if you want something explained to you he does a fine job. If you take good notes in class he explains everything you need to know and you don't really need to read the book unless you are very unclear about something, but I found him to be a better teacher than the book.

Peter is the best MATH1210 teacher by far, surpassing his peers in terms of accessibility and teaching ability. He is super willing to work with students and help them succeed, opening up extra office hours for weeks of exams, giving lots of extra credit opportunities on written homework etc.
One thing that is a bit annoying is his pickiness with notation, but I assume that this has to do with the Mathematics department and he's preparing us for their exams (he doesn't make them, the department does). From firsthand experience and testaments from friends who have other calculus teachers, Peter is the best.
Overall, this course is super easy if you're familiar with calculus in any way. There is no trigonometric function integration or differentiation which increases the ease of this course. With Peter, you will do well if you put in the effort on Webassign and do the homework thoroughly.

Peter is a decent teacher and a nice guy, but the math department at UVA is terrible. The tests (which are most of your grade) are created by a coordinator rather than your professor so it is not always representative of what you learned in class. If you have to take this class, I would recommend taking it with Peter, he is really receptive and will work with you if you need extra practice.

From the very first class, Professor Eisner makes it clear that he does not believe many students will succeed in his class. Most lectures consisted of him going on tangents on material we did not need to know, and it appeared that this was done with the intention of proving his superior intelligence.  I never felt very comfortable asking questions or seeking help during office hours. Students who did well in this class mostly succeeded because of having taken calculus in high school.  I was able to get through the class by teaching the material to myself by reading the book or watching videos online. If math is not your strong suit and you genuinely want to learn, I would not recommend Professor Eisner.

Joe is super helpful during office hours, extremely kind, and very excited to help you learn.
