He may not be the greatest lecturer and sometimes his class is difficult to follow, but he is extremely willing to answer questions and even come in during his out-of-office times to sit down and answer all of your questions. Definitely recommend Joe out of all of the grad applied calc teachers.

The course itself is pretty hard, especially if you don't have a calculus background from high school.  Zach Bradshaw is a good professor, really knowledgeable and helpful for the most part if you reach out to him.  The tests are hard and I definitely recommend doing the practice tests and going to see him for office hours to prepare.
Chill and helpful professor, but makes the class a lot harder than it has to be.
Zach is cool and super helpful and approachable. The class is a little harder than it needs to be though.

Prof. Wang makes an easy mathematics course quite difficult. It is also quite hard to understand his English at times. His explanations are not the easiest to understand, and are more often than not, very unclear. When questions are asked in class about how a certain formula works, he often just points at the board, and utters "like this. Make sense?"
He iis somewhat hard to understand, but a good teacher. The material in the course was super easy. It is easy to get points on the test for showing your work even if you get the answer wrong.

If you're coming out of high school having only gone up through pre-calculus, this class will be ridiculously hard with Bo. He is difficult to understand and doesn't get that he needs to teach. All he does is do math on the board in front of you, he doesn't give anyone time to actually practice/understand. If you get stuck in this class ask TONS of questions, odds are no one else understands either.
DONT DO IT
Mark went to Tech, I would advise teaching yourself before taking this class. Which is virtually the same thing

Mark is a funny guy He is really available outside of class and very helpful during his office hours. If you can't make it to his office hours, he responds pretty quickly via email to answer your questions. Helpful guy that cares about his students' success.

If you are not a math person but need a class to fulfill your math/science requirement this is a pretty good class to take. Its not extremely difficult-- if  you took calculus in high school, you will not learn anything new. Homework is somewhat tedious and can be difficult though. Exams are extremely predictable and your given the past exams to practice on. Lewers is a really nice guy (a little bit of a nervous lecturere though) and helpful when you go to his office hours #tcf2016

Mark was a great TA! I entered the class extremely late (the day right before the enroll deadline), and was behind on a lot of material. However, Mark was very accommodating and helped me catch up on the material in no time.
If you copy down the notes Mark writes on the board and use his practice problems, you will do well on the exams. Likewise, if you have questions about a certain problem or concept, he will explain them step-by-step for you during lecture or in office hours.
Mark also replies back super quickly to e-mails (he always replied back within the hour to mine, even at night). Also, if you complete your WebAssign homework early (he has an early deadline and a regular deadline), you get extra credit on your HW. Highly recommend.
Brian Thomas is a good TA, the exams were just really hard but he is a lenient grader and his quizzes and WebAssigns are easy.

Brian is a really nice TA and is easy in the sense of quizzes and webassign, but I was completely unprepared for exams. The exams are created by multiple TAs and everything I learned in Brian's class didn't feel too applicable to the exam. Nonetheless, very nice guy.

I really liked Brian because I felt like he effectively got to the material. He is very organized with his lectures and teaches you what you need to know for the exam. I entered his class with absolutely no previous calculus knowledge and did fine!

Kind of an awkward guy and can come off kind of judgemental, but he's a pretty good teacher. I took calculus before so it wasn't hard for me but he emphasizes that he is available during office hours every class. Would recommend.

I loved Jim and applied calc 1. Many people complained about their professor, but I thought Jim was great. Class sometimes got boring though and I never paid attention. I took this course in high school, so the information did come more easily to me, but he also taught the information in a way that was easier to understand. I'll give a 3 for difficulty just because some people found it a bit trickier. Many people in the class had taken some form of calculus before, but our class usually had an average higher than the average of the 600 students who take applied calc 1. He really wants everyone to do well, as you can get a 110% on all the online webassign homework. He also drops your lowest homework and your lowest quiz. There are only a few quizzes, and homework counts more than quizzes, anyway, so it's easy to get all the homework points. He's always available for extra help. Also, tests usually had some difficult questions, so make sure you know how to do the easier topics so that you can guarantee points from that. Always do the practice tests, and to study don't focus on homework questions that required a calculator. Def recommend!
Chris did a great job of teaching this. He is always available during office hours and is very willing to re explain things and work with you.

Chris was a great professor. He is very fast-paced and can be difficult to keep up with, but he ALWAYS gives the opportunity for questions and is ALWAYS available outside of class. Tips for success: Go to his office hours/extra review sessions, go to the math tutoring center at Gilmer because they help a lot, and do the Webassigns and worksheets, but don't spend too much time on them because they don't really translate well to the exams. The webassigns are too easy for the exams and the worksheets are too complicated and never show up on the exams. Use your notes (don't really need the textbook), QUIZZES, and the biggest one: PAST EXAMS. He always gives those out so be sure to do those, write down what kinds of questions show up on a separate sheet of paper, and just google practice problems of what you find. Overall, not too terrible of a class, just be sure to keep up with the class, NEVER skip, and do practice problems all the time. I never took calculus coming out of high school, started the year with a D, followed these tips, and ended with a B.

Gabe is a good teacher!  He's super nice and he will always provide help!  Don't be fooled into thinking that the class will be super easy or that you're guaranteed an A.  I took Calculus in high school and this was still not a cake walk for me or anyone else I knew in the class.  This is definitely a class you should take to fulfill your requirements though.  Unlike other Applied Calc I teachers, Gabe recognizes that most people take the class simply because they are trying to get their math/science requirements out of the way, so I would recommend taking this course with him as the teacher.

Gabe is one of the best Applied Calc 1 teachers in the department. He explains topics really well, is extremely helpful during office hours, and most of all truly cares about his students. Also, he's pretty funny, which is definitely a perk!

Kristin Courtney does a really good job of explaining all topics. If you pay attention and attend office hours when you need it, her class is pretty easy. A lot better than most of the other Calc 1 teachers from what I've heard.

Kristin Courtney does a really good job of explaining all topics. If you pay attention and attend office hours when you need it, her class is pretty easy. A lot better than most of the other Calc 1 teachers from what I've heard.

Mr. Bourdon is extremely likable, approachable, and passionate. The class does move very quickly, but the quizzes and tests shouldn't be too difficult if you keep up with the homework and go to office hours (Bourdon is good at clarification during these!!) This is likely a class you have to take if you take it, so choose Bourdon if you can.

I took this as an intro Calc course because I didn't get AP credit from the exam. A lot of it seemed like review of my AP Calc AB class senior year, and so this was a fairly easy course for me. Bourdon is a good teacher and is always open for student questions and study opportunities. Very manageable intro math class for non-science majors, and this should be an easy class for anyone with a calculus background.

Professor Abdelbaki is extremely nice and a very considerate and effective teacher. He prepared us well for the exams, and he also has a great sense of humor. Likes to relate the history of calculus to math, which made explanations interesting. Really the best math teacher that I have ever had.

Ala was one of the best math teachers I've ever had. He's super funny and knowledgeable and does his best to  prepare you for exams. Homework was all online which could be frustrating but Ala was always flexible and reasonable with deadlines. I definitely recommend taking this class with him.

This is a challenging course, especially if you haven't taken calc before. However Ala is awesome and you will love that you took his class. Just make sure to go to class and ask questions. The most important thing is to work out the practice tests until you pretty much have them memorized

This class sucks. Why are we paying tens of thousands of dollars to be taught by people who are learning to teach? My instructor was knowledgeable about Calculus but was a terrible teacher. Literally every class he said "I don't know" every time when illustrating examples or when he lost his train of thought. DO NOT take this course with Aron Daw by all means.

This class sucks. Why are we paying tens of thousands of dollars to be taught by people who are learning to teach? My instructor was knowledgeable about Calculus but was a terrible teacher. Literally every class he said "I don't know" every time when illustrating examples or when he lost his train of thought. DO NOT take this course with Aron Daw by all means.

As someone who did not take Calculus in high school but needed it for an economics major, I was really disappointed by the quality of teaching. The concepts were not explained well and I was left confused and now need to retake the class. I suggest taking the course with another professor
Not a lot of work but Leitermeyer does not know how to teach. Students are mostly left to learn the material on their own.
Leitmeyer is a very bad teacher. If you've had calculus, that shouldn't affect your ability to do well in the course.
Terrible teacher and barely speaks english. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH PROFESSOR XU!!!!!!!

I ended with a B by the grace of God. The class was okay. Luckily my TA gave my class extra credit points for turning in homeworks early and he even gave me extensions on some homeworks I missed. This class really depends on your TA and whether they are good teachers or not. I would recommend getting an outside tutor if you did not take calc in high school.
Nice person, tries her absolute best to make the class fun. She seemed pretty new to teaching, but was always available and understanding of students in need of any help.

Probably one of the kindest professors I've had all year. She clearly outlines the material and is always happy to answer questions. Overall, of all professors, she's definitely the one to get if you struggle in math.
Nice guy. Go to class and to office hours.

Took this class to fulfill a requirement.  He was a really good instructor and made everything easy to understand.  Applied Calc 1 isn't difficult in general, but the Web Assign homework's were occasionally frustrating because they could be picky on the format of answers.  There are 2 midterms and a final.  Practice exams are available and with my experience, completing them made the exams simple.  Not a bad class.

This class was the bomb. Aaron's a great teacher and very kind and helpful during office hours. I got an A+ in the class (my one one at UVA) and am soooo glad I took it. it was a good refresher of my calculus from high school and didn't require much effort  on my part to ace it. There's a massive curve that definitely helped.

This class sucks. Why are we paying tens of thousands of dollars to be taught by people who are learning to teach? My instructor was knowledgeable about Calculus but was a terrible teacher. Literally every class he said "I don't know" every time when illustrating examples or when he lost his train of thought. DO NOT take this course with Aron Daw by all means.

Go to class. Gates is a great person, but he's a math major first. If you aren't familiar with Calculus, than you will have to work hard, especially on the written homework. Also, if you don't understand something, go to office hours. Passing won't be hard, but if your goal is to get an A, you're going to have to work for it.

He knows the subject very well but has trouble teaching the students so they understand it easily. Attending office hours definitely recommended - he is more than welcome to help. All in all, he is ok as a teacher but you might need to teach yourself some concepts if you don't understand them or go to office hours.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH Z. GATES IF YOU DO NOT HAVE PRIOR EXPERIENCE WITH CALCULUS. He's a pretty nice guy, somewhat awkward and shy but approachable. 1. He's a student so he does not have the skills to teach, he's just a really smart kid. 2. He "taught" the class as if we already knew the material. 3. The test were impossible compared to the online homework, the written homework  is a better reflection of exams. 4. THE FINAL IS IMPOSSIBLE.
If you want to do well pick another teacher!!

Zach moves pretty quickly, but he's a really great guy. If you haven't taken calc and don't want to go to office hours, you won't do well. That being said, he is absolutely willing to help and meet you on your schedule outside of office hours. He is awkward at first, but once he warms up he's pretty funny. I took AP Calc in high school and got a 3 on the exam and have done very well in this class. We don't have weekly quizzes like some other Applied 1 classes. If you find yourself getting bored with a slow pace, take Zach.

I was extremely disappointed with this class.  The language barrier with the professor is extremely frustrating, grades on the two midterms averaged in the 60s, classes were extremely frustrating and made students feel lost and disengaged, there was little correlation between the homework, lectures, and exams, and you have to teach yourself from the textbook. I strongly recommend that you do not take this class with this instructor.

Terrible TA.The language barrier makes this course much harder than it should be, and her teaching style is awful. All that she does is re-write her notes from the textbook on the board during class, whilst reading aloud, almost inaudibly and certainly unintelligibly, what she's writing as she writes it. She then pauses to ask if there are any questions every few minutes, giving responses that either don't help to explain the ideas whatsoever, or responses to questions that were a direct result of the students being unable to read her awful handwriting or understand her incredibly poor command of the English Language.
In short, she is the worst teacher I have ever had, not just at UVa, but in my entire time as a student. Why anyone in their right mind would ever have allowed her to teach a class is beyond me, I can only assume there is no screening process for these positions, otherwise anyone with half a brain would realise within 10-15 seconds that she is incompetent in the extreme and completely impossible to understand.

I never took calculus and did fine in the class. From what I have heard, Sue He is one of the better grad students teaching the class. She explains things very well and is willing to work with your schedule if you need extra help.
Good class, but would be easier if you had taken calc 1 before

He explains problems well in class, but gives a lot more homework than other sections! The written homework is always very tricky and due every week, and then we also have online problems due every week. This class takes up all my time! On the plus side, there are no quizzes. He is also usually helpful for the written homework during office hours if you're very confused so its alright in the end. And he doen't have an accent so that's good.

Do not take this class with Stephen Hardy. Just don't do it. He may explain things well at times, but he is simply not a good teacher. He makes absolutely no eye contact with the class and talks in a flat tone. He doesn't ever stop to see if anyone has any questions and actually would get irritated sometimes if someone dared to have a question, because why would you be so rude to interrupt his teaching? Homework took up so much time. Like the other reviewer mentioned, they were always overly tricky, and for no good reasons because though I did find the exams difficult, I found the homework even MORE so. I didn't do well in this class because it ate up all my time and I had to focus on my other classes as well. It is possible to do well in Applied Calc I with Stephen Hardy if you are good at math, enjoy math, or have other classes on your plate which are easy so you can devote all your waking hours to this. It is also possible to do well in Applied Calc I if you simply don't take it with Stephen Hardy.

This course is not that bad. If you've already learned calculus in high school, you won't need to read the book at all. And if you're new to calculus, he teaches you everything you'll be tested on and he teaches reasonably well. Sure Hardy is a little impersonal and can sometimes over-complicate basic concepts, but you only need to show up to take notes. Online homework is easy, written homework is excessively challenging- though it definitely makes the tests seem easy. (If you get stuck on the written homework, you can just go to his office hours and he'll basically tell you the answers) The tests themselves are fair, though you can lose a lot of points on small errors. The class has a decent curve, so it is not that difficult to do reasonably well with minimal effort. From what I have heard of the other teachers for this course, Stephen Hardy is a solid choice.
this class has too much work, but hardy was really good :)

Peter was a funny guy. He knows his stuff and grades fairly. The weekly WebAssign wasn't difficult, however, written homework due every Friday was tricky. Almost cost me my grade, but utilize his office hours and you'll be fine. He really preps you for the tests which make up a huge chunk of your grade and aren't terribly difficult.

Peter is a great teacher and very willing to help. The web assign is usually a breeze but the written homework due every Friday is pretty difficult so GO TO OFFICE HOURS and you will be golden. I never looked at the book but attended every class.

I only took this class because it was a prerequisite for my major. I did not really enjoy it, but the tests were not too hard and he only takes the top 10 highest homework grades. Sometimes the lectures are a little disorganized and confusing, but if you ask a question Professor Lai is pretty good about trying to explain everything.

This is the worst class I have ever taken. Mr. Weaver does a horrible job at explaining concepts. It is extremely boring, and there is no point in going to class because you will not learn one thing. If anything, going to class will make you more confused than if you didn't go at all.

Mr. Weaver isn't a great teacher. I'm sure he's just TAing becuase he has to for grad school. He rushes through concepts on the board, mumbling, and his handwriting is barely legible. Also he grades extremely harshly, but that doesn't make much of a difference as your course grade takes that into account. That being said, the course itself is really quite easy. I recommend buying the physical book because it basically walks you through how to do the problems. I stopped going to class after about 3 weeks except to take quizzes. Going is pointless if you can just learn from the book. If you can't then get a tutor because Weaver isn't going to be much help there. For the 2 midterms I literally looked at the material for the first time the night before the test and got 20 pts above the average on both. Same thing for the final, but that was cumulative. The curve was a lot lower than I was expecting. Overall this is not a hard course if you pick up concepts quickly/can teach yourself. If you can't do either then pick a different TA. Also you can't use a calculator at all in the course which sucks.

Would definitely not recommend taking this course with Weaver. He's a horrible lecturer and you will have a lot of issues on the homework and exams if you haven't taken some sort of calculus class before.

If I could rate this lower than 1 I would. I had Andrew Will as my prof and he was awful. (I had to select a different prof on the drop down because it is Andrew Will's first semester teaching... and it shows) Concepts and ideas weren't explained in class clearly, and I struggled in this class much more than I should have, given that I took calculus for two years in high school. I found the course load somewhat manageable, but the test reviews did not fully reflect the tests, so I felt unprepared when exams rolled around. Further, he was incredibly rude to students and was wholly unhelpful when I wanted to try and meet with him (blew me off and didn't address my questions whatsoever). He shouldn't be a teacher or be around students.

He spoke english and was generally interested in teaching.  For a class with mostly foreign TAs, Daniel was a relief to get as a TA.  He also was very fair and answered questions, and made calc as fun as it could be

Daniel is a great teacher and a funny dude himself.  He brought in donuts and other pastries through the year and is very fair with grading.  He also makes sure that everyone is well prepared for quizzes and tests and he never throws you curve balls.

I am not a math person in the slightest and this was a mandatory requirement for me for McIntire because I hadn't taken calculus before.  Daniel got decent reviews but we weren't prepared for our first test at all with a class average around 70 and a high score of 90.  The test questions were harder than most problems on the practice test or homework assignments, and he used a question that referred to something we barely glanced on for a minute in lecture.  So far I haven't been very appreciative of him or his teaching methods.  Also, webassign (the homework system) is evil and he only allows five tries per question, which can kill people because the site is picky about how you put your answers in, which wastes lots of tries.  You could have the answer right and be told you're wrong anyway.
Also, this class is a target for those who really don't like or want math, so there were a lot of embarrassingly stupid and annoying people in this class who preferred to talk about the parties they were going to than actually learning the material- after being given an example problem to try, and i quote, a *third year* girl near me whined, "Why doesn't he just put it up on the board for us?  I don't like to thinkkkkkk..."  I would consider her average for the class.
This class was very boring. If you go to class and do the practice exams, you'll be prepared.

Daniel was a very good math professor.  At the very least, he is a good choice as a professor because he is a native speaker.  He understood and could explain the material well.  His grading was a bit subjective but seemed pretty fair.  I'd recommend him.

Reed was not a helpful TA at all. He was unclear in lecture, going over simple problems then failing us all on the tests with more complex problems. When asked to do more complex problems in class like ones that we would be tested on, he would say it was unneeded. Class average for each of the tests was between a 50 and 60. If you want to take this class, don't take it with him!

Josh Campbell the man the legend. He looks like a caveman which is kinda cool. Not the most clear and he's more than a bit socially awkward but overall he's a pretty swell guy if you get to know him. Maybe 10 AM isn't my prime because this class was kinda a struggle but Josh is a straight up dude.

This class is ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE. Taught by grad students (I had Reid Booth) with absolutely no incentive to do well and no prior teaching experience. The classwork and homework only account for 5% of your grade *combined* and are nothing like what is on the exams. The exams count as ***95%*** of the grade and are incredibly difficult. Students are horrible under-prepared for them. Also, what kind of calculus class doesn't let you use a calculator? It's literally impossible to do the math without a calculator, and the lack of one makes the course so tedious and difficult. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.

Fall of 2009 was his first time teaching, which I didn't know/couldn't tell until he said so at the end of the semester. He was very helpful and made himself available especially the day of the tests. He was a physics major, so he sometimes gets excited about concepts and goes into depth.
Great guyLearned a lot and he is there to help you

Polillo was a nice guy but painfully literal in how he followed the rules. He was the only GA not to curve the grades for calc 1210 when i took it. not too difficult of a class especially if you took some calc in high school.

Worst TA imaginable...tough grader and can't teach at all. His lectures are scattered all over the place with sometimes useless information. If you have to take this class, take it with another TA for sure. Don't waste your time.

I had to withdraw from this classs halfwya through. It's taught like a review course and since I had zero backround in calculus I found it impossible. Timothy is very smart and a nice guy, but he cannot explain things in simple terms that a non-math person would understandThe only assignments (other than exams) were webassign and were "the bare minimum" of what we should be able to do. If you have to take it and aren't a math person, get someone else and save your self the frustration.

I'm actually doing really well in this class, but ONLY bc I took AP calc in high school. Pollio's a nice guy but not a good teacher.  He reads his notes straight from the book so that sucks if you aren't a math person. (I know I never understood math theories in words- I always needed examples) Also I can't tell you how much useless information he teaches. It would be VERY difficult to pick out the basic concepts if not already learned it last year. Bottom line- if you have a background in calc- this class is an easy A. If you haven't, I wouldn't suggest it.
Jason Knapp is horrible, super duper horrible, no matter which class it is: math1210/1220, horrible horrible, drop it people! You regret or else!!!!!!

Jason Knapp was an okay teacher. He's not super enthusiastic but is pretty nice and always available for work. He's understanding and if you can't finish your web homework in time he will postpone it. Web work and class lectures did not always match midterms and finals but those were still manageable, especially if you had previous experience with Calculus. Not too much work and usually a lot of time given to work on Web assignments.

He absolutely does not curve. He is extremely arrogant and it was one of the worst experiences I've ever had at UVa. He absolutely had a hand in ruining my chances of getting into McIntire and fulfilling my Econ major requirements in time. DO NOT RECOMMEND

She is the most unorganized, unprofessional, and unintelligent teacher I've had at UVA. She forgets whats she's teaching and testing on on a regular basis. She cannot handle the job of being a teacher. Whatever you do, don't take this class. Out of all my friends in calculus I was the worst off with this teacher.
She's not very good at speaking English. Even worse, she's bad at understanding your questions. However, this is a good class if you've already taken Calculus. She's also very fair and helpful.
asd
She explains the concepts of calculus thoroughly and   is always available for help when needed.
She's explains everything pretty well and is nice. She makes herself available during office hours, too.
Shes very odd however friendly.  I found she graded way too harshly though.  Marked off for very unnecessary reasons

Constance is very good when it comes to explaining things, and will go back and explain in a different way if need be. She can also be pretty funny at times. However, she is a hard grader, and it is very important to put a lot of time into the written homework sets, as well as pay attention in class. Also, take advantage of office hours. They were very helpful for me. I ended up getting a B in the course with a lot of hard work

Taking this class was a HUGE MISTAKE. Figuring that I got an A in Math 1210, I thought that this class was going to be about the same level.  Turns out I was wrong.  Chris is NOT a good teacher whatsoever.  He is very monotone and awkward.  He may know his material, but he is not very good at explaining it to the class.  I quote: "I hate teaching Applied Calc II.  It's a terrible class."  I found lectures completely pointless to go to and utilized going to the Math Lounge or the Math Tutoring Lab-- that is how I learned the material that was supposed to be taught during class.  He gives out weekly quizzes so you are required to go to class even though he doesn't take attendance. If you HAVE to take 1220 with Chris, I would highly recommend going to the Lounge and Lab to supplement as well as collaborating with other students.  I would try and avoid Chris at all costs.

Chris is a terrible teacher. Do not take him. Grades harshly too. Weekly quizzes are harder than test questions. He will blame you, the student, for doing poorly, when in reality, it's his poor teaching. DONT TAKE APPLIED CALC II WITH CHRIS.

This guy is actually the worst teacher I've ever had.  He just puts examples on the board without explaining how he got them.  He wastes time teaching things we don't need to know and doesn't spend time on things we should.  Spent most of my time in the math study lounge, almost pointless to even go to class.  You are guaranteed not to learn a thing...AVOID THIS CLASS AT ALL COSTS
horrible teacher. AVOID.

I had Susan Mitchell as my instructor, but all the instructors teach the same material and grade each other's tests. Survey of Calc 2 is definitely easier than regular calc 2, but is unnecessarily difficult because you are expected to teach yourself at home before each class. Classes are meant to reinforce the material you learn through assigned videos and the textbook. Home grades don't count for too much of your grade, which is good because it's hard to get help on them when you need, especially if office hours don't fit your schedule. Prep and written homework assignments are a firm deadline, but the other homework can be extended. WebAssigns are nothing like the tests, its just a way to practice skills. Put extra emphasis on the practice tests, written homework, and class examples on the worksheets. Feeling confident on the other homework don't mean you'll do well on an exam. STUDY BEFORE THE WEEK OF EXAMS because office hours fill up on those weeks and its hard to get help or learn anything you don't understand last minute.

Dimou was a good teacher but the class was hard inherently. If you pay attention in lecture and do all the web assign homeworks without cheating, you will probably have a really good understanding of the concepts and be prepared for the exam. Make sure you stay on top of it as it is really easy to fall behind. The webassigns account for 12% of your grade and are assigned after every class and due before every class. There are also written homeworks every couple of weeks and quizzes every other week. There are two exams and one final exam.

I think my biggest mistake coming into this class was that I was cocky, having already taken calc 2 in high school and having done decently on the AP exam. What I didn't realize was that this course would go much further in depth and cover more topics than a high school calc course (should be obvious for UVA, but it took me too long to make that connection). Around the midpoint of the course, I started to see a significant decline in my grades, having not paid too much attention throughout. I did poorly on the second midterm, and really had to turn things around going into the final. Lectures in general were not helpful for me, as I thought Evangelos moved too fast. Going back to review lecture notes, doing the webassigns and trying to get 100%, and attending office hours with specific questions was what I found to be most helpful, which is unfortunate considering that obviously none of this was in-class work. I did very well on the final with very in-depth, extensive preparation, and ended up with a B in the class. I know there was a curve applied as well to everyone's final grades, although I'm not sure exactly how much that was. As for advice going in, I'd strongly recommend going to office hours and reviewing practice questions going into exams. Considering the fact that they always do a curve, it's really not too bad of class, but it can be stressful for sure.

Dimou is the best professor you can get for this class. However, the material in this class is very hard and stressful. Do not take this class unless you absolutely have to. If you have to, take it with Dimou. I had another professor at the beginning of the semester and switched to Dimou and Dimou was far better. Lectures move super super quickly but Dimou is very helpful and test questions reflect what we did in class. At home assignments count for a lot of your grade and help your average if you put time into them.

This class definitely covers a lot of material and moves quickly, but I do not think it deserves such bad reviews. Professor Dimou is very helpful and wants everyone in the class to understand. There are also in-class learning assistants and P2L sessions where you can catch up if you feel behind. I personally found Dimou easy to follow, and I thought he did a good job explaining the new topics. If you attend class regularly and pay attention, you should be able to understand the lessons. The majority of the grade was the exams, but each one had a large curve, and I felt as though a lot of the exam problems matched the in-class problems, practice exams, and homework. The written homeworks and Webassign homeworks were also a large chunk of the grade, so if you put in the time for both of those you can do well. Dimou was the MATH 1220 coordinator this semester, so I personally thought he was the best professor to take the class with.

I would not recommend taking this course if not required. While there were plently of office hours, MCLC, and  P2L sessions I found that often the LAs were not particularly helpful, nor were all of the instructors. Dimou was very knowledgeable, but not particularly welcoming. Class lecture was nearly pointless, as a flipped model was used. While the class is passable, an A is not easily attainable without putting in the work for it.

This class is so so hard and Professor Dimou is one of the meanest professors I've ever had at UVA. He doesn't explain concepts clearly and when students ask questions, he does a very poor job of answering them. He can't explain concepts in different ways which means if you don't understand it the way he's teaching, you're screwed unless you do your own learning online. There is a TA that comes to each class but my TA was also very unhelpful. Be prepared to work really hard to pass. #tCFS25

This class is clearly a weeder course, but Brianna makes it enjoyable (or at least as enjoyable as Calc II can be)! She actively tries to get to know her students well and goes out of her way to help them out. Also, she's consistently brimming with verve! Without her, I honestly couldn't get through this class. In all, I highly recommend you take this course with Brianna. Out of all the professors that are currently teaching this course, she is definitely the best!

Professor Kurtz was literally the only thing that made an 8 am calc 2 class bearable. The course itself was much harder than calc 1 at UVA in my opinion but she was an excellent professor and if you go to office hours she is very helpful and willing to explain confusing concepts. I don't know how she had so much energy at 8am but it helped keep everyone from drifting off.

I absolutely detested 1210 last semester, but Prof Kurtz made this class sooo much more enjoyable! Lectures were very engaging, and coming to class significantly helped with understanding the material. Prof Kurtz made an effort to get to know all of her students and was always very energetic and funny!! Homework was a massive pain in my ass, though-- I ended up doing fine on the first two exams, but I literally could never do the homework & it took so long. I'm writing this before the final, so I can't speak to that, but I'm fairly certain there is a curve (which my grade probably will need). If you have to take this class, it will be hard, but this is def the prof to have.

Ok so I actually took this class over the summer during session 3 of 2023 and it was fully online. It being online definitely made exams easier, but regardless of that I am writing this review to let everyone know that if you are going to take calc 2 for whatever reason, take it with Professor Kurtz. Calc 2 is a notoriously annoying GPA killer at UVA, however Professor Kurts makes it as bearable and interesting as is humanly possible and genuinely wants to see her students succeed. This is something that I was not expecting going into a class with MATH 1220's reputation, and I am incredibly glad that my expectations were subverted. With my class being online, anything I say regarding the workload and exam structure probably won't be applicable to most, but I should mention that she curves your class grade after the class is finished. TLDR: Brianna Kurtz is the goat and if you need this credit, I would say it is worth switching around your schedule to ensure that you can take this class with her.

Brianna is an amazing professor and does everything she can do include everyone in the class to deliver the best experience. She accommodates students' needs and understands that expanding your understanding of calculus for the first time is hard. If needed, she gladly takes the time to explain concepts again and works to meet in the middle to really grasp relevant topics. Only 4/5 enjoyability because calc is calc hah

If you have to take calc 2, you really have to take it with Professor Kurtz. She may just be the best math teacher I've ever had. She has unbelievable energy and is open to any questions about math or your grades. The way she teaches is also just very helpful in learning the material somehow. Please take Professor Kurtz's course if you have the option.

Ala Abdelbaki is a very funny and helpful professor. He often goes off on random, unrelated tangents during class. The majority of the class is only taking calculus to fulfill a requirement, such as econ. Not an easy topic, but he does a good job of teaching material. Class is made up of two midterms and a final and weekly webassign homeworks. The homework is easy to get 100% on. If you have to take calc II, take it with Ala.

At first I was skeptical of taking this class as I came in with a 5 on Calc. AB and was unsure if I was ready for Calc. II in college. I am extremely happy I took this class. Ala is a really funny and genuinely nice guy. A lot of people go into his class and sleep, but if you make any effort in the class you should perform well and earn his respect. The two tests aren't that easy, but the curve is kinda weird and works out pretty well for the most part. For whatever reason the averages on tests were never great, but most of my friends and I seemed to do well.
One note. It is a good and bad thing. There will be a class every now and then that he just doesn't give a crap and tells stories and messes around. This can be fun and entertaining if you understand the material, but frustrating if you don't. Thus, to get the most out of his class I would suggest coming in with a solid math background; nothing crazy, but enough so you are not always struggling. SOLID CLASS

Like everyone is  saying, Ala is a great guy but I found it very difficult to grasp an understanding of the material, especially because I've never taken calc before, not even in high school like most people here. He's the kind of person that would be great to chill and hangout with one on one, and he makes our class laugh hysterically but when I asked him questions he did not really answer them well, or he would go off on a tangent about something were not even talking about. If you end up with him due to scheduling conflicts, its not the end of the world. Just know you're going to have to do a lot of explaining and teaching to yourself. If you can, I recommend taking Brian Thomas, I had him for Applied Calc 1 and he is a little awkward one-on-one but his lectures are very organized, he gets to the point and answers any questions you may have.Also, like all lower level math classes here, the tests are in the evenings with all the sections in a huge lecture hall taking the exams. 2 midterms, 1 final and weekly homeworks. sometimes the homework can be very tedious, other times its pretty straightforward.

Applied Calc 2 is very difficult. I only took it to fulfill my Natural Math & Science requirement. If you don't have to take the class, don't!! But if you do, I'd recommend taking it with another professor. Like the others students mentioned. He is a great guy, can be funny at time, but he does go off on tangents and rants. He is constantly late to class. Be prepared for 20 minutes of jokes and to go through 2-3 sections per class. If you don't grasp everything in class, which 80% of the time, you won't, I'd suggest going to office hours. He is helpful 1 on 1, but office hours are always cramped. The grading is pretty fair and solid. There are curves here and there.

Ala was really great!! He was very kind and respectful when answering all of our questions. He genuinely wanted to see everyone succeed, and he truly means well. He is hilarious, and tries to keep the class interesting by incorporating some math history and theory and also introducing new topics in a way that was engaging. Ala always has a really positive attitude and never made us feel dumb for not understanding something. His lectures were clear and engaging, and is obviously competent with the material. He was also always very helpful and kind during office hours. I would recommend him to anyone who wants to take a math course.

Professor A is one of the best math professor's I've had. His teaching style is great, mostly because he goes straight to the point and explains every topic in a thorough manner. During class, uses relevant examples which are very useful for the tests/quizzes. He's a really funny guy as well which makes the class more entertaining. Office hours are a great bonus since he's always really approachable with any type of question. Overall, this professor truly cares about his students and wants them to do well in the class!!!

Professor A is a great teacher if you have prior experience to the material. I got an A- in the class after taking Calculus BC in high school, which was more than enough to do well in this class. He structures it pretty well by giving a lot of weight to the online homework, which is nice since a lot of this class is the exams and he only gives like one or two written homework assignments during the semester. The only thing I would make sure to do if you don't have a strong calculus background is to go to his office hours, they're usually packed but he is really good about making sure that everyone gets their questions answered.  Also he does show up late a lot which some other people have mentioned, but  don't worry about that because he makes sure to fit all the topics into class time. If you are taking this class definitely take it with Professor A!

If you have to take calc II, Ala is the best professor to do it with. He explains the concepts very well so that they make sense to people with non math brains. He is also entertaining and doesn't assign a lot of quizzes written homework outside of webassign. Would definitely recommend him!

What a guy. Honestly, I can't even begin to talk about how amazing Ala is. He's a diamond in the rough when it comes to the math department. I took him over the summer and so he may teach differently with the crunched time but I found his Applied Calc II to be a relatively easy course. I got over 100% on all the midterms and assignments except the final (I got a 95 on that), and I had never touched Calc II concepts before. He's unbelieveably funny. He had his own catch phrases  that he would say in his soft voice like "Yeah, we're not playing around anymore," when introducing a new topic and "Oh...man." His laugh always got me too. Honestly just do the webassign well, take good notes in class and really use the textbook to reinforce the lecture and you'll do well in Ala's class. I'm seriously considering taking MATH 1060  just because he teaches it. What an absolute legend. 10/10 please take him if you want to bring some life into your classes next semester.

I LOVE ALA! He is the best instructor you could have for the class. He is super understanding, helpful, and simply a great lecturer. He has quite a small voice so it could help if you sit in the front. Also, I had Christopher Leonard for MATH 1210: he was awful and I thought everyone in the math department sucked. However, Ala will change the way you think. Recommend 10/10. You will walk out of the class feeling like you actually learned something worth your tuition.

This course is considered to be a "weed out" course, but it isn't really all that bad if you attend class, pay attention, study, and go to office hours if you need help. I think a lot of it depends on your instructor, because they have graduate students teaching. Not every grad student is a great teacher, but I got lucky with mine so I had a positive experience. There is a considerable amount of homework, but it is comparable to that of MATH 1210. It's definitely not an easy class, but it's also not as bad as everyone says.

I took this course with Nicholas Collins. Overall, I didn't think this course was as hard as everyone said it was. I think who your GTA is made a huge difference. There aren't a lot of assignments each week except for webassigns which corresponded with the lectures. I took AP BC calc in high school and I thought the material in this class is pretty different. A bunch of topics is taught including integration, probability, partial derivatives, and series. If you are not a math-oriented person then I would say this class is challenging and take math 1190 instead if you have the choice. As a statistics major, I found this class to be engaging and challenging but nothing overly difficult. If you have the option, I recommend taking this class w Nick Collins. I thought he did a good job of explaining the material. However, he does make his quizzes a bit harder in order to better prepare you for the exams. This is a coordinated course so everyone takes the same exams and your GTA does not create them. It's a game of chance really. Sometimes the exams are hard but other times they are not OVERLY difficult. Definitely take the practice exams released before each of the exams, I found them to be very helpful. Also, GO TO OFFICE HOURS. I found office hours very helpful for clarifying confusing concepts.

This class is very challenging!! Not sure why the Spring 2019 reviews describe the class as relatively easy, coming from a Fall 2021 student it is absolutely not.
The format of the class a flipped classroom with the following dynamic:-You have to teach yourself the material at home from the calc textbook and provided YouTube videos-Complete some questions on the topic before coming into class-Instruction in class (which is confusing and hard to follow)-Homework assignment on the topic-Quiz on Friday-Written homeworks that are week-long every couple of weeks
This all leads up to VERY difficult material on the exams. It escalates quite a bit from the homework questions. I would say that if you have to take this course, as I did, try to take it as your only challenging class of the semester so you can really focus on it. It is a time commitment to really drill the concepts in. The average on the first exam was a 74 but the standard deviation was almost 20%. This tells me that the divide is huge - you're either acing or failing.

The instructor was not very effective. She made lots of mistakes in class to the point where sometimes you couldn't tell if she had made another mistake or if you actually needed help because you didn't understand. The student assistant helped me understand the topic more in 1 minute than the actual instructor did during the entire class. At times she doesn't seem to know what she's doing, and she didn't know the answer to most questions from students. The class itself isn't bad, but I would recommend taking it with a different instructor who will hopefully be better at actually teaching the material.

Jiajun is really nice and a good instructor. She is very helpful during office hours. For this class, we have prep assignments that are due before each class to prepare for the lectures. There are also homework afterwards on WebAssign. There are one quiz every two weeks and due to the short amount of time given (15 minutes), it is difficult. There's no time to check your work. My only complaint for this class has to be the quizzes because it's given at the end of a lecture. Sometimes the lecture run onto the quiz time. There are three exams with the third one being cumulative. Practice exams are provided. There are also 4 written homework that is collaborative. If you have to take a Survey to Calc 2 class, Jiajun is definitely the instructor to choose.

Wow. This dude is an actual psychopath. He's obviously very smart but cannot teach, is literally addicted to vaping. This man does not own an actual phone, hes "afraid of the government tracking him".  Hes incredibly condescending and rude, never take a class with him.

Ah Calculus 2 the biggest hurdle in anyone’s career at uva . Most failed course at the university and a prerequisite to all “good” majors at the university. I entered this course after achieving a B- in calc 1 and knew I had to put a lot of work in if I wanted to get that magical C+ I needed as a prerequisite for the econ major. My professor was Matt Gagne who honestly is one of the nicest people let alone professors I have ever met. He goes through content very quickly but gives examples of every question you will find on the exams and goes through Webassign problems in class on the board basically giving you the answers. He will cover a whole section of the book in one lecture then give you about 2 weeks to complete the relevant webassign and will over that period go through the toughest webassign problems.Do well on your webassign! It counts for 10% of your grade so it’s important if you need that C+ to come in clutch . The rest of the grade breakdown is 5% diagnostic quiz. 10% classwork/ quizzes. 20% midterm 1 , 25% midterm 2 , 30% final .Biggest advice get 100% on your webassigns and do well on classwork and quizzes this is an easy 1/4 of your grade you can secure.Study your ass off for midterm 1 and 2 unlike me who got below the average on both of these exam . And it was looking like a D+ was life for me . However in the last 3 weeks of school during finals I attended office hours with Matt Gagne and he blew my mind. He explains confusing topics in such simple terms and glazes over the stuff you don’t need to know. Also just a super interesting guy who is ridiculous smart.Overall I would strongly recommend taking Matt Gagne as a professor. At times you won’t know what he’s talking about but if you attend office hours he will explain it simply for you . Also do all the previous exams possible as they reuse questions all the time . And no matter how hard you’ve prepared the final is always impossible . I somehow managed to get my C+ and don’t really understand how.Attend Matts lectures they are fun and engaging and he usually lets you out early . Also he’s probably the only professor at UVA who vapes indoors so that’s a must see . Calc 2 is really a simple course which is just teaching you statements and methods of calculus then testing you to see if you understand them on the exams . If you just write down what they want to see and keep it simple you’ll do fine . Good luck my children !

calc 2 is a beast, not gonna lie. Obviously, don't  take this course if you dont have to. However, if you have to take this course because of your major, Matthew isn't a terrible teacher.  He does his best to answer your questions in class, but teaches pretty fast so pay attention. He'll do web assign problems on the board and basically give you the answers.  Since you don't have to do the webassign to do the webassign (i.e. practice another version) my biggest advice would be to actually try doing the webassigns on your own. This way you know exactly what you don't know and can ask him to go over it in class. The textbook is mildly helpful as well for the webassigns and you could always go to office hours. There are about two webassigns per week.  He also assigns written homeworks and classwork which he grades pretty leniently and you're allowed to work with others on these. I thought both midterms were pretty difficult and they weren't like the practice exams. I took math 1210 and if you did one practice exam, you were pretty much golden for the actual exam but that wasnt the case for 1220.  I got the average for both midterms and there was a pretty generous curve for both. When it came to the final I was really nervous, but it didnt end up being so bad and i was able to get a B in the class.

While I was really intimidated by calc 2 (esp with the math departments poor reputation on profs and Matt's earlier reviews) Matt was a genuinely great professor. He was a chill grader, relaxed in class, and would go through problems step by step if you asked. Ignore the earlier negative reviews. Matt's nice and wants you to do well. Take calc with him if you can.
This class has stuff due every week. Before tests, do the webassigns and practice tests multiple times and the real test will be similar. They tend to use the trick questions on exams, so don't skip them in practice thinking you'll be fine. There is a decent curve. Make a groupchat for a study group, and you'll end with a good grade

Ok, so I took math1210 with Dmitriy, not 1220 (he teaches this class though course forum for some reason doesn't have him listed) and let me tell you, this guy is the best professor. He is extremely kind, patient, and clearly loves teaching math. He comes off as timid and quiet at first (beware, he does have a very quiet voice and does't use a microphone, and that paired with his slight Russian accent can make class a little difficult sometimes) but he seriously will go above and beyond for his students. He is always encouraging us to ask whatever questions we have during class, and no matter the question, he will take the time to make sure it is answered and understood. If you email him or take the  time to go to office hours, he will do the absolute most he can to help you. I seriously believe that if you take the time to get help, there is no way that you won't end up with the grade you want in his class.  Also, you WILL understand math more from being taught by this guy, which was very very helpful for me, personally. 11/10 would recommend taking a math class with Dmitriy, ESPECIALLY if you are not a math person, and are just looking to get a requirement out of the way. If I had time next semester, math1220 with him would be my top choice, even though it's a 9:30, which I would normally try to avoid because I'm not a morning person.

Professor Sonkin is an alright teacher. He is tough to understand at first because of his thick Russian accent but you get used to it quickly. His style of teaching didn't work too well for me as pretty much all he does in lecture is very quickly write problems on the board and solve them without doing a ton of explaining. I had to use the textbook, office hours, and YouTube professors (Professor Leonard is GREAT), in order to really understand the material. Exam 1 is easy, but exam 2 is IMPOSSIBLE. The final was very fairly written. Based on experiences I have heard of with other professors, I would say you can't get much better than Dmitriy. He truly cares about each of his students and if you visit him in office hours you will understand the material better. He gives lots of quizzes but they help you understand the material really well and he ends up giving lots of extra credit, so don't worry about your quiz grade.

Professor Bowling is the best math Professor I've had by far. I took this class during session II Summer 2022 and was extremely nervous to learn all the material in 4 short weeks. Professor Bowling did a beyond amazing job of breaking down all of the content for us to understand and did a phenomenal job at teaching it. Everything was graded very fairly, with the grade breakdown being 22% HW and 26% for each of the 3 tests. I really wish he worked at UVA during the school year as well because he's an amazing teacher.
Save yourselves and don't take this course from this instructor
Awful teacher, awful class.  Very difficult to understand, and this is not a course where that is tolerable.
If you do well in this class with this professor it will be because you taught yourself everything. He mumbles and is very hard to understand

He is probably the worst math teacher that I have ever had in the 16 years that I have been in school. I am so lucky that math is my strongest subject, otherwise, I would have really suffered. He mumbles at the chalkboard when he teaches. He writes stuff on the chalkboard and you have to try and figure it out based on what is written. He is very unenthusiastic and very unconfident when he teaches. There were multiple times that we had to correct him because he made errors in his teaching. He is also late for class very often. In fact, he showed up 15 minutes late on the first day. If you have to take this class with this instructor, you should go to the coordinator Jim Rolf's office hours. Jim Rolf is very helpful and very responsible.

Supposedly, Professor Rolf was supposed to be the best of the calc II department but he was underwhelming to say the least. Class consisted of him giving us packets with practice problems on them and flinging us into breakout rooms to struggle together without really teaching the material beforehand. With that being said, as long as you show up to lecture and make sure to understand every problem in the packets after the fact, you will do well on exams it's just a matter of putting in the effort.

This class honestly wasn't too awful. Rolf is a pretty nice guy and he clearly cares about his students, but at the same time I feel like he thinks struggling is an integral part of learning. Besides that, he is very approachable in office hours and willing to help. While he is less likely to hand out answers in comparison to other profs, he tries to guide students to the answer. The hw isn't bad at all, but the class prep assignments are sometimes annoying. The worst part of the class is the problem sets, which take HOURS UPON HOURS. I definitely recommend working with other people, but once you're done with problem set, the answers seem a lot clearer and prepare you more for exams (the exam questions aren't as hard or as long but the problem sets help you understand the material more). Quizzes and exams aren't toooo bad. There may be an upward curve on quiz grades at the end of the semester because Rolf tends to give out harder quizzes, but they're doable. Exams suck but if you prepare e.g. do the hw, the class prep, go over quizzes and practice exams, you will be fine. The exams seemed comparable to the pain of math 1210. Personally, I thought the problem sets were the worst part of the class. Overall, calc 2 isn't the best but it's not the absolute worst. Rolf is a decent professor but I would recommend supplementing your knowledge with outside sources as well. For context, I got an A in this class and math is usually my worst subject.

Not the most exciting class, but she's a good teacher and knows her stuff. She does lots of examples in class and will always, without fail, go up until the final minute. You'll get the grade you need though, or at least do better than you would've done with some other teachers.

Absolutely do not take Applied Calc II with Weaver. During class, he'll barely get through two examples of the new material and then assign the most absurd webassigns and written homeworks. What ends up happening is half the class is sitting in his tiny office for office hours as he explains these other ways of doing the problems that he "meant to get around to in class." He grades the quizzes ruthlessly, taking off points for every little error whether it be a missing parentheses or not putting +- in front of a square root. This class is literally the bane of my existence. DO NOT TAKE.

So you think you are decent at math and are taking this course to fulfill your last math requirement. Taking Applied Calc II with Weaver is not an enjoyable experience. He grades his quizzes and written homework unnecessarily hard where at the end of the problem you wonder if there was even a point to getting the right answer when down the line you missed a notational point and it cascaded to you receiving 2/6 on the question. The only thing that can possibly save your grade in the class are the web-assign, midterms, and final which in comparison to his quizzes and written homework are an absolute cake wake.  Still getting a 95% > on all three combined assignments (make sure to keep your web-assign at 100% as it is an easy free booster) does not make up for the near 60% avg you will have on your written hw and quizzes (20% of your grade) so aiming for an A or A- is far from easy and essentially impossible.  Going to office hours for explanations on the written hw  is seemingly useless as despite going through every single problem with him for the written hw you would still end up with getting a C through F grade. The worst realization however is when you walk into the exams and chat with people in other classes and hear "what are you talking about? We don't get written homework and our web-assigns are generally  short, like around 15-20 questions." numbers and statements that I would have never associated with my Applied Calc II class with Weaver.

Weaver is good and bad in certain ways... His written homework and quizzes are very difficult. It is hard to maintain a B average in that section of the class. His web assigns are tough, but doable - can get an A in web assign portion of class if you work hard. While Weaver is tough in the things we do for his specific section, the Midterms and Final are much easier. He is very tough and makes this makes the actual exams (which are the same for all sections) a joke. His class is boring too, but I feel like all math classes are boring. Take Weaver if you think you are solid at math and can handle his in class quizzes and homeworks because he will get you a good grade on exams.

If you absolutely have to take A Survey of Calculus II, definitely take it with Gabe. He is super quirky and it makes lecture rather entertaining as well as enlightening. Moreover, he always tries to open up new office hours and highly encourages questions - he waits about 30 seconds after going through something complicated in order to give students time to process what just happened and thereby ask questions about it. His in-class quizzes are not too bad if you understand the Webassign homework due the Sunday before the quizzes are administered. Where this course really falters is the exams; they are not made by the students but rather the department. As a result, sometimes the material does not align and sometimes the applications on the exam are way beyond what we did in class. Ultimately, try to avoid this class if possible. However, if you need to, take it with Gabe no matter what.

I loved Brian! I had the weird emo guy for Applied Calc 1 and as a result hated it. Brian was really good about having his material organized and grading things fairly. If you have to take Applied Calc 2(which is in itself not the most fun) take it with Brian.

Brian Thomas is an awesome TA! Calc 2 is just the worst. Its a super hard class, and the exams tend to have confusing questions and low averages.  However, Brian was really good at explaining things and his quizzes were always very fair.  I really appreciated the group classwork we did once a week because when we got to more difficult sections,  it was nice to know that I wasn't the only one struggling with it.  And if other people in the class didn't seem to think things were hard, I would know to spend more time on those chapters.  The webassigns were pretty difficult for some chapters but they do prepare you for exams, so make sure you do all of them (they're easy points that you should take advantage of).  I would also recommend starting the practice exams as soon as they are posted because its really important that you get through all of them before taking the midterms/final so you know what to expect.  The practice exams were especially  helpful before the final because I was having a rough time with Taylor Series at the end of the semester (like everyone lol) and I spent a long time going over examples in the textbook and online.  The night before the final I did all the taylor series questions on the practice finals to make sure I knew how to do them.  Then, the actual final ended up having a ton of those kind of questions so I got really lucky,  Overall, this class can be super challenging at times but Brian was super approachable and really wanted all of us to do well.

Chris is a nice guy. No matter who you get for this class, the average is around a C+... this course includes multivariable and statistic calculus, so if you're just looking for Calc 2 math and not the application of it, you should take 1320

I thought this class wasn't really that bad. Chris was a nice guy and honestly he was there whenever you needed help. This class is just fast paced in general so for whatever TA you have it will be difficult to keep up with material sometimes. The scary thing about this class is that test scores were typically low (as they got progressively harder). HOWEVER, there is a MAJOR curve at the end which will make things better (I got a raw score of a C on the final yet ended up with an A in the class). This class is very straightforward: understand all the concepts, do all practice problems, ask for help when needed...and it is very possible to get an A!

George is a really great teacher. He definitely cared a lot about his students. While Math 1220 is definitely a difficult class, George presents the concepts in a straightforward way and goes back over particularly difficult concepts. He gives both homework and quizzes which can be a nice grade boost and has two points of extra credit on each quiz. He also drops the two lowest quiz grade to help your grade. Overall, I would recommend taking this class with George if you need to take calc 2.

Math 1220 itself is an incredibly difficult course, but if it is required for your major, definitely take it with Ross. He is great at explaining difficult concepts, gives relevant examples, and is always available to answer questions about the WebAssigns at office hours. It also feels like he's on your side, which is important for a course like this. Would not recommend Math 1220 unless you have to take it, but I definitely recommend Ross.

Curves are fairly generous and there isn't a ridiculous amount of work, but the content is super boring if you don't love math. The general consensus seemed to be that professors aren't the best, and exams are super hard. No real reason to take the class unless you like math or if it's a requirement for something.
He's a good guy, but his lectures are really boring.  His written homework are extremely hard, but he's incredible in office hours.

Zach is such an awesome professor. He knows exactly what he's talking about and really wants his students to succeed. Whenever a new chapter is covered in class you will probably have no idea what he's talking about but the material makes sense once you work through the webassign problem sets/visit office hours. Definitely go to his office hours, they are extremely helpful and will clear up any confusion you have. Definitely possible to at least get a B at the end of the course.

Calc 2 is always going to be a tricky subject regardless of who you take it with, but if you have the option, definitely take it with Zach Gates. He presents the topics clearly, goes over plenty of examples and is always willing to stop to answer questions, which is really as much as you could hope for with a math teacher. Be ready to take some time to do the webassigns before the day they are due so that you can ask questions if you get stuck on them, and if you struggle with the written homework he is very helpful in his office hours. If you go through the study guides and take all of the practice tests before each midterm/final you should perform to your potential. I found that they were pretty consistent in difficulty to the real ones. Definitely a challenging class but if you take it with Gates you will at least have a prof that cares about his students and is fair, unlike some of the horror stories I've heard about some of the other teachers.

Applied Calc. 2 is a hard class, but Mike makes it alright. He was very clear and his lectures were easy to follow. The written homework was helpful, and if you ever get confused, Mike is very accommodating in office hours. He was a very fair grader as well, and doesn't give an unreasonable amount of homework. If you have to take MATH 1220- I would recommend taking it with Mike Willis! Just make sure you do really well on the midterms because the cumulative final (same exam for all sections) is EXTREMELY HARD! Much harder than the midterms/homework/notes. (But there was a large curve this semester!)

Exams are as hard as possible, with an average of 77 and no curve. There are 3 exams with the goal of tricking you and making you do poorly. The math department doesn't care about you learning. They just throw random formulas at you and then you just use them on exams. You won't get anything out of this class so only take it if you have to for your major.Mark was alright though. He messes up a lot in class but never in a way to affect how well you can learn. He also has corny jokes that make him better than other grad students. Plus he's helpful if you visit him in office hours.

Mark is alright. He is knowledgeable but tends to try to explain things in an esoteric, fundamental way rather than employing simpler methods. He tries to make you understand the fundamental principles of the study of mathematics instead of telling you "the value doubles," or things of the such. Very helpful in office hours; math department makes the exams pretty tough.

Wow. It's only been a week and a half, and I think this class has been one the worst experiences I've had at UVA thus far (academically speaking). Every single day he has had connection issues and various other problems because he uses some old iPad to teach the class. Obviously there's a problem if every single day there is lag on the screenshare and a bunch of pop-ups blocking the screen. All you have to do is get on a computer????? Literally half the class we just sit here as he tries to figure it out. I already know we are going to be incredibly crunched for time in the future. As for actual class material, his notes are pretty bad. Absolutely bare-bones with minimal information and sometimes even misinformation with incorrectly calculated solutions. Thankfully I have some background knowledge on the class or I'd be screwed. Don't take unless you want to just sit there for 4 hours learning material by yourself every day. I'll update the review once we've had the first exam... can't wait for that. I'm sure you all are familiar with webassign so I dont even need to go into how bad that is. As for the homeworks he makes up, they make no sense. I sat down with 3 of my classmates and all 4 of us thought the problems made no sense. They were poorly worded and overly difficult with at least half of the problems almost unrelated to what we did during class time.  Also makes you go in blind to every single quiz and test. No reviews, no study sheets, no anything. At this point I might as well have taken regular calc 2. There seems to be no difference.

Bogdan is the epitome of a poor TA.  He doesn't know how to explain/teach material.  In class, he will often mess up an example and then spend the entire rest of class trying to figure out his mistake.  His office hours are the same.  I would not recommend him, especially to those who have had no prior experience of Calc II.  He is impatient and does not have the knowledge on how to help students succeed.
I liked Bogdan. He seemed pretty good compared to the other TAs. Some people in my class seemed like they didn't do very well, but it also looked like they didnt try very hard

John is not helpful. He doesn't know how to explain things well, and if you don't understand him, he won't know another way to explain it. He's a bad public speaker, and should not be teaching. Not sure he could have done anything to help me learn. I learned mostly from reading the textbook, and I've never been able to learn math from a textbook before. Just no. Just don't.

I think John was a good TA. I mean he taught the sections pretty well and gave a lot of examples as he taught. But I had already taken calc 2 in high school so I found most of the stuff to be just review and didn't need to go to office hours or anything. So I don't know how helpful/available he is in that regard. But the course in general is quite manageable if you already have experience with some calculus from before.

Overall, this was a pretty tough class. John is a decent teacher, but he is a lot more helpful during office hours than class time. His written homework assignments can be tough, but it' more to help you prepare for exams. No matter who your TA is, I recommend going to office hours for help, especially if you've never taken Calc 2 before.

John was really nice and made himself available to students. The course overall is just extremely difficult. I would definitely say that you should only take this class if you ABSOLUTELY have to. It's the lowest grade I've gotten at UVA, and I have a lot of friends that straight up failed it. It's a class that you can work extremely hard for and still do very poorly. That said, go to office hours as much as possible. John is very helpful in office hours and will take a lot of time to help you succeed. Written homeworks were super hard, but the quizzes and WebAssigns were manageable. Exams were awful. Grades on the final were horrible and the department didn't curve it. Just try to get points where you can on the test. If you don't have previous Calc 2 experience, this class will be a nightmare for you.

Hated this class with a passion.  The homework is impossible but he was great about being available to help.  Tests aren't too bad as long as you take all the practice tests they give and go to class.  Class itself is boring as anything but one benefit of taking it with Campbell is that he doesn't have an accent so you can actually understand what he says and don't have the added strain when trying to pay attention in class.

Most of the class examples were out of the book, so you couldn't go there to get more examples. He was helpful during office hours or when you ask him direct questions. Lectures were super boring. Big plus is that he doesn't have an accent so he's easy to understand compared to most of the other calc professors.

Literally the worst math professor I could have ever imagined. Switch out if you can.... He works on a simple problem for an hour, is very disorganized and treats students who are not doing well very poorly.

Nkemzi is a very shitty professor. Rarely actually covered anything in lecture, and he was very unresponsive to students' questions. I actually remember multiple instances where someone would ask if he would work out an example and he just said no. He's also pretty bad about telling you when he's uploaded homework assignments on collab and consistently forgets when the due dates are. Is the class that hard? No. Did I get an A while doing minimal work and having not so much as looked at calculus for 3 years prior to taking this class? Yes.  But do yourself a favor and take this class with someone else. Nkemzi is terribly inadequate and should not be teaching at the collegiate level.

MATH 1220 is not an easy course, but Kristin manages the material in a well organized and helpful way. She is very available with her office hours and structures her class to focus either on theory/practice problems based on what feedback she gets. If you are looking to take this class, I would recommend taking it with her.

Bryce came across as a sasshole at first, but as the semester went on, I came to realize that he was actually a pretty nice guy. He really knows his stuff and teaches the material really well - I think like everyone except 3 people in our class scored above the 1220 average on the second exam. He's always asking if anyone has questions, makes his office hours known throughout the semester, and even emailed me a couple times about webwork problems I was having trouble with without me asking for help. Especially since I've heard horror stories about other Applied Calc 2 instructors, I would highly recommend Bryce.

Do NOT take this class with Socolovksy. Unfortunately his accent and language-barrier makes the class very, very difficult. The lectures will become entirely useless and it's up to the students to learn the material themselves. Socolovsky definitely knows his stuff and is knowledgable when you go to his office hours, but the lectures are very dry, slow, and he has a hard time prioritizing what should be covered in class. The most mundane things get extra time getting covered in a single problem (like why he used chain rule), and then much harder sections of the same problem just get thrown up on the board without an explanation. He also has a tendency to either write out every single step (including very unnecessary ones) and then other times skipping steps and simplifying parts in his head. Again, throwing it on the board afterwards without an explanation.
