For the times when someone is able to flag him down to ask the necessary questions, the language barrier gets in the way again and he points to the wrong sections on the board, the student has to say "No, right, right, up, yes, that one" and he still somehow spends 20 minutes explaining the wrong step. At this point students give up on the question and move on. Repeat ad nauseam. He also spends a ridiculous amount of class time on proofs, and not enough time on the actual material and application of said material. I sat near the front of the class every lecture and talked to the other students who sat in the front and they all had a very difficult time understanding him. The ones who spent the time outside of class learning the material by themselves were the ones who got a good grade.
You may think this review is slightly exaggerated, but please take my word and don't take it with this professor. You will have a much easier and better time with a better professor. Taking him because he fit my schedule was a mistake, and I should've prioritized my calc class schedule over the others first.

Math1220 is going to be a difficult class no matter who your professor is, but I thought Mike Reeks did a great job of making the class bearable. He is a great instructor and teaches the material very well, and he's always happy and willing to meet you in office hours to go over material. He provides plenty of opportunities for practice problems before all 3 exams. He may be a bit boring but so would anybody who is teaching Calculus.
The class itself is really not all that difficult if you go to lecture and do the homework. There are 2 midterms worth 20% each and a final worth 30%. The rest of the grades come from online homework and 3-4 scheduled quizzes throughout the semester. The best way to study for the exams is definitely by using past exams with their solutions.

Bonventre is a great teacher, he makes sure everything is clear and he teaches in a way that is very easy to understand unlike most of the other 1220 teachers.This definitely shows in his test averages, which are usually higher than the other sections. I actually sat in on 2 other classes before I settled on his. The lectures aren't boring and they are easy to follow. There is a good amount of work, weekly WebAssign problem set & quiz, and written homework, but this will prepare you very well for the tests. I actually liked that the written homeworks were fairly difficult because they were much more representative of the questions on the exams than the WebAssign problems. He is also a fair grader, i.e: you won't get the whole problem wrong for mixing up a sign if you still do the rest of it right. All in all, if you are willing to put in some work you can get a good grade and you will definitely gain a good understanding of the material from him.

If you are going to take this class take it with Bonventre.  He is a really nice guy, good at explaining things, and a pretty lenient grader.  I sat in on other TA's classes like Weaver, who was all over the place.  I believe that Bonventre's students do much better on the exams than the other TA's students, so take it with him.  Although, the written hw assignments can be very difficult, I went to office hours every week for those and so it turned out okay.

If you are going to take this course, do yourself a favor and take it with Peter! He was an enthusiastic and knowledgable teacher. He really wanted us to understand the material, was very organized, and very willing to help outside of class. I had friends with other instructors for this class who said they had significantly less WebAssigns and Written Homeworks, but I honestly think it was beneficial to have these to boost my grade and help me understand the material better. Be warned that each week required about 5-7 hours of homework for me.
Just skip this guy, trust me. He's a smart guy, but not meant to be a teacher.

Although he is really smart and truly knows his stuff, he is just not meant to be a teacher. Hard to follow what he was doing in class and they were pretty dry. Homework grade is a definite booster, and he is a fair/generous test grader.

This class almost killed me Steve Hardy gives the most convoluted lectures and I could barely understand what was happening like when am I going to need to know how to calculate the volume of a shape with a parabola on one side and a sine wave on the other and geez what aint nobody got time for this after all this work and studying and office hours every week I got a lousy 64 on the final what a waste of my time

While the class was difficult and the weekly written homework dreadful, Mr. Hardy is incredibly helpful if you go to his office hours. He'll go over the written homework with you and help you solve the problems.

I recommend taking this class however I could barely understand the professor. If I hadn't taken Calculus before I would have been out of luck. Take with a different professor, the class is not difficult, but it is good to be able to understand what they're saying!

This class really isn't that bad and while Haunchen may be a bit difficult to understand, he's a fairly good teacher. He lectures fairly well and explains anything you would need to know for the exams or webwork and is very helpful in office hours. I went to office hours almost weekly and with his help, did well on the written homeworks and the exams as well. I ended up with an A in this class (massive curve) and am glad I took it. He sets a cushion of 25% homework grade which is also really helpful.
Horrible teacher. Leitmeyer is extremely boring and very confusing during his lectures. DO NOT TAKE THE CLASS WITH HIM.

Ilya is a really nice guy, but I would recommend against taking his math class. His lectures left a lot to be desired, and I often felt like I was going into the homework completely blind. Also, I didn't personally have this problem, but some people couldn't understand his accent.
Nice guy, but not a good professor. Really hard to understand him and read his hand writing. If you are not a math wiz, don't take it with him because you will barely learn anything in class.

If I had not taken BC Calculus in high school, I am sure I would be failing. He makes the topics harder than they are and his thick accent and bad handwriting make the class a lot more difficult than it needs to be. I went to his office hours a lot and while he was there to help and happy to help, he did not understand that you are there for the office hours because you do not understand the material. Getting him to explain topics that you do not understand was difficult. However, he grades fairly and is not a mean person.

I don't think this was necessarily a difficult class but he made it a lot harder than it needed to be. Spent a lot of time explaining what NOT to do in problems and then going back at the end of class and giving the actual explanation...felt confused during most of the class. Eventually I just ended up teaching myself most of the course. He's a nice guy just not a good teacher.
No, an absolute NO for Knapp's math122, NO

DO NOT TAKE IT WITH KNAPP! He does not teach the material well, and goes over the notes extremely fast. He is not easy to get a hold of outside class, and extremely arrogant. I took it with him, ended up putting a lot of effort to do well but the worst experience ever!

Jason was a great TA. From what I know from friends in different sections, he explains things much better than other TAs. Also, he makes sure you know everything you need to for the exams; however, we had to rush at the end of the year and cram some things in. Besides that, he makes himself readily available for office hours, and you can always email him or ask to meet about a question.

She does a really great job teaching and getting the point across during lecture! She has great office hours. There is webassign and written hw due every week but if your having trouble just go to office hours and she will explain everything very thoroughly! The only thing I would be cautious of is that she is a hard grader and very nitpicky about showing all  of your work.

I have a rather strong math background so I had very little trouble grasping the material for this class. Kochalski is very nice, does a good job teaching, and is VERY HELPFUL at office hours. She got through everything at a nice pace, and didn't have to cram at the end like of the other TAs. She is a bit picky about showing work, but then again, I think most math teachers are. Either way, she scales the grades for her students at the end of the course, so her being a harsh grader doesn't really hurt you as long as she is equally harsh on the whole class.
Great Teacher. Explains everything very clearly.

Dan teaches directly out of the book except for one technique. i found that i really didn't need to go to class to do well on the homework and tests. a very nitpicky grader- you can have points deducted for the wrong notations in your work even if you have the right answer.

Jing is really sweet and enthusiastic, but her lectures were a bit hard to understand at first because of her accent...But the material is really straight forward and perfect if you're looking for a quick calculus refresher course.

She has a VERY thick accent. Nice lady if you are a math person and don't need a ton of guidance with the material, but I found it was difficult material to begin with, and not being able to understand the professor made it just plain awful.

Professor Zhang is an alright lecturer. She has a heavy accent but is understandable and this adds a bit of a comedy element to the class. She doesn't explain concepts perfectly and goes somewhat fast, but she gets the point across.
JZ is the best. She's very funny, and provides good examples for the test. Sometimes she falls behind schedule, but she catches up. Genuinely cares about her students too.

Mr. Mccarty is a relatively dry professor but knows his stuff well and presents it in a coherent manner. accessible during office hours and tests are fair (he gives past exams out as reviews which are good study tools)

For some reason, it would not let me enter a review for Daniel James on fall23, but it does not really matter since (although he was the professor) I never saw him or heard him once. The class is taught be a graduate student, which is for starters a red flag. I appreciate them trying their best, but they are just not equipped with the knowledge and experience to teach a college level calc class to us. I 10000000% think if I had a real professor instead of a graduate student my grade would have been significantly higher. TO be honest, the undergrad TA is really the only reason I even passed this class. To summarize what she emphasized, exam questions are practically the same as the practice exam ones and the 'extra problems' in the notes, so be sure to do those. The one thing I really was pleased with in this class was that even if you did not know how to solve a problem, you can write what you know and what is relevant (literally just words) and receive partial credit for understanding.

As part of the prereqs to apply to the School of McIntire, you have to take a calculus course: "Calculus: MATH 1190, 1210, 1310 or higher level." I thought I could handle a harder calculus class, especially since I had taken AP Calculus AB in high school. I decided I'd take the "slightly harder" math course, MATH 1310. Big mistake.
If I could go back and choose my classes for this semester, I would have definitely chosen MATH 1190 or even 1210. Not to mention, I'm not sure if this was a problem unique to MATH 1310 Canvas page, but while a lot of resources were offered (practice worksheets and problems, uploaded class notes, etc.) everything was hard to find and disorganized making my experience in this course harder than it had to be. I hope they fix this for future students since many of my peers spoke up about it this semester.
Moreover, this course is overseen by the professor, Daniel James, who directs 3 other non-professor instructors. They all have their own classes that they teach, and I was one of the students placed under the instruction of a graduate student. I'm sure in some cases, classes taught by graduate students may be a good idea, but I wish I had been placed in the professor's class. Many, if not all, of the concepts in this class, were previously taught to me in high school, but I feel like the way things were taught in this course was more complicated than needed. Maybe it was because my instructor saw these concepts as simple as addition, making it easy to forget to break them down before moving on to the next problem.
Overall, I didn't have the best experience in this course. What I have learned, is that if you can take an easier course to fulfill a requirement, TAKE THE EASIER COURSE. If you do end up taking this class anyway, I recommend you never skip the professor's office hours (I felt that he explained everything the best) and DEFINITELY find a good study group early on!

I took this class with a background knowledge of taking AP Calc AB in high school. However, this is completely different. First off, I would have done so much better if Professor Daniel James was my actual professor. If you end up having Pedro, though he is a nice guy, he does not teach well at all. He is a graduate student and does not really know how to prepare his students for the assessments. Also the difference in standard and growth based is so unfair and I did not have a good experience with this class at all. I recommend taking the lower level calc class if you need it for a prerequisite. I never want to take a calc class ever again.
Again, Daniel James is great and his office hours were super helpful. But if you get one of the graduate student, you are stuck.

ONLY TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU *NEED* TO ... I took this class as a first year thinking that it was the same as MATH 1210, as they are both seemingly equal prerequisites for many popular majors such as Economics, Commerce, and Biology.
However, this is far from the case. This class is much more theoretical and trig-intensive in its approach to calculus, and it demands a much more nuanced knowledge of the subject than MATH 1210. TAKE MATH 1210 INSTEAD.
Every other problem on the exams is a multi-step application of topics in the course, while MATH 1210 problems are typically a slight variation of what is given in class. The graduate students that teach these classes are largely apathetic in lecture, so office hours are crucial. If possible, meet with Daniel James frequently. He is the course coordinator and is the best at clearly and patiently explaining the topics and helping students formulate an approach to studying that is best for their learning style. Most of the work in this class was associated with pre-class homeworks and WebAssign, but I spent the bulk of my time that was dedicated to this class by studying for exams.
This course is a far cry from high school math. I went into this class having taken math through linear algebra in high school and MATH 1310 severely humbled me. It is largely the same concepts as high school classes, but the way in which it is 'taught' (flipped classroom style) and the level of understanding they demand for students to show on exams is above and beyond what you will have seen in high school. TAKE MATH 1210.

I had credit for calc 1 from high school, and I can say that this class is 100% harder than high school calculus 1. The material isn't anything impossible, but it is all very in depth and you need a really good understanding of the material to do well. And because the class is taught by a grad student, I found my lectures to be nearly worthless. I basically taught myself everything I had to know from youtube and chat GPT. My grad student teaching the classes was a smart and nice guy, but he has no idea how to teach a class. Sometimes he would make mistakes on the board and we would have to correct him, sometimes he would write out long unnecessary proofs that would just confuse us even more.
The best way to do well is to have background knowledge from an actual teacher. If you don't, beware that you will probably need to teach yourself a lot on your own. Do the homeworks and really understand them, don't just get the answer without knowing why it is right. Getting an A is hard but not impossible.
#tCFFF24

Not sure why I'm not able to add instructor (Caelan Wang), but here goes:
This class is not for the weak. Would not recommend taking for an enjoyable math credit if you were a math person in high school. Not only is the class structure of talking at you called "interactive" and "engaging" by the professors, the outside help that sought for it made me less confident about my knowledge of the material. I personally would not recommend this if you have absolutely no experience in calculus like me, unless you are willing to do 90% of the teaching on your own. If you're struggling in this class, I would highly recommend using ChatGPT, Khan Academy, and P2L sessions to pick up the slack that the professors leave. Good luck!

Genuinely don't take this class; just take a survey of calc, 1210. It's not worth it; this class is 4 credits and will just tank your GPA if you literally haven't taken a harder than Calc class before. I took AP CALC BC and got an A; however, I wasn't able to take the exam due to personal reasons, and although the content of the class is the way they want you to answer each question for exams, it makes it near impossible to get all points, and with the harsh grading scale, it's not worth it. And please listen: if you have never taken Calc before, DO NOT take this course.

Genuinely don't take this class; just take a survey of calc, 1210. It's not worth it; this class is 4 credits and will just tank your GPA if you literally haven't taken a harder than Calc class before. I took AP CALC BC and got an A; however, I wasn't able to take the exam due to personal reasons, and although the content of the class is the way they want you to answer each question for exams, it makes it near impossible to get all points, and with the harsh grading scale, it's not worth it. And please listen: if you have never taken Calc before, DO NOT take this course.

I took Calc AB in high school and did end up getting an A in this course, however, it was the most in depth math class I have every taken. The grading scale is based off near-perfection, and although the course is said to be "growth based," the retakes are often completely different problems/types of problems then the original exam problems. Additionally, you need to earn almost all 4s on all learning targets by the end of the semester to get an A in the class. The final exam questions count as NEW questions (learning targets) which you can not retake, so you basically need to get 100% (all 4s) to have a shot/cushion at getting an A in the class, regardless of whether you're going into the final with all 4s or not. Further, there are "core targets" and you MUST have 4/4 on all 5 of them by the end of the semester, otherwise you will automatically be bumped down essentially a letter grade: if someone has 4 4/4 and 1 core target less than a 4, the highest grade you can earn in the course is a B+, regardless of whether or not all your other learning targets are prefect 4/4s.
An interesting change early on in the semester, was that the course coordinator did not allow instructors to see the exams before giving them. This was certainly interesting to us because the course coordinator teaches her own section of this class and can ultimately teach directly to the exams (that she creates) while other instructors can not. This is strange because the instructors are PhD students, and their reviews or student outcomes in their classes could potentially impact their success in their programs...???
If you need to take THIS SPECIFIC CLASS (and there is no way you can take an alternative like survey 1210) as a pre-req for your major, I would recommend doing the following: pay VERY close attention during class, ask a lot of questions and identify learning gaps as they come, NOT just right before exams, and study at least a week leading up to each exam by doing lots of different types of practice problems, since you never really can predict which type of example problem will be on the exams. Your instructors are ultimately here to help you and really do care about you, and they are knowledgable. DEVELOP STRONG RELATIONSHIPS WITH THEM!!!!!! It will really help you. If you have to take this class, you will succeed and you will be ok, but be prepared to do a substantial amount of studying and extra work outside of class.

This course is godawful.
I had a 96 in this class and got an A- due to the "growth-based" grading scale. You can technically get a 96 in this class and still get a D. Arguably, the work isn't even that hard, they just grade it so bizarrely and harshly, and you will probably end up tanking your GPA (esp. because 1310 is 4 credits rather than 1210, which is 3) if you can't take advantage of the slightly easier final.  Be prepared to submit a LOT of regrade requests and get a LOT of them denied. My instructor was a really nice guy who hated how the class was graded but couldn't do anything about it.
My school didn't do APs but I was good at math in highschool and this course KICKED MY ASS. Mostly because of the BS grading scale - prior to the final I had a C- with an 87%.
I don't know that 1210 is graded any differently, but just be warned to stay clear of any "growth-based grading" math class. There is no curve, what's in the syllabus is final.

Although you may have done well in calculus in high school, this class will not be a breeze. This course heavily enforces the theory and proofs behind the concepts.; the exams require you to apply a combination of ideas, theorems, and methods to be successful. I failed the first quiz and the first midterm because it took me time to adjust to the format. That being said, I still ended with a B. Professor James is a brilliant and quirky professor! His teaching is methodical and mathematical, and he sincerely cares about your success and understanding. I originally disliked his teaching style, but it grew on me -- so, give it time. In order to be successful in this class, you need to understand the concepts and ideas; you cannot memorize a formulaic approach to problems because the ones on the tests will be different from those done on homework and class activities.  This class will challenge you, so if you are not a STEM major, I would recommend you take Math 1210. If you do decide to take this course, take it with DJ!!

I came into this course not having any form of math proficiency and, consequently, struggled in the beginning of the semester. I completed it with an A and my two of my closest friends at UVA!
DJ, as he insisted we referred to him as, emphasized working towards a conceptual understanding of calculus (in opposition to simply arriving at the correct answer) throughout his course. I found his lectures concise and looked forward to attending class due to the numerous opportunities he created for collaboration. Although he did not go through each type of problem included in the class work packets, he was very approachable during office hours. The exams are not as high stress as you would expect due to the weighting of grades. Be sure to complete your class preps and homework (WebAssign) on time and participate in Poll Everywhere during class - it is easy to get a 100 in these assignments.
I put in a significant amount of effort into this class and found it most rewarding. If you're taking MATH 1310, I highly recommend DJ!

As hard as this class was, I definitely came out of it feeling the most rewarded. The math tested is conceptual and you are supposed to be able to answer theoretical or the 'whys' behind some of the concepts (ie. limits), which was definitely a different type of studying for me. Once I figured out how to study for the class though, it was fine because the tests are fairly consistent with rigor and types of questions. The professor is flexible and definitely passionate about helping students be successful, but classes could feel slow sometimes. This is a hard math class if CALC is not your thing, but if your other classes are not too demanding and you can realistically devote time, then you can get a good grade.

This class is not your average high-school calculus course. It demands a genuine understanding of course material rather than simple memorization of theorems and processes. IMPORTANT: there are multiple calc 1 courses, no one told me about survey of calc 1 (MATH 1210) at orientation, so I signed up for this class thinking it was the same thing...it is not. 1210 is a broader scope of calc 1 content and (from what I have heard) is easier than 1310. If you can take 1210, take 1210. I still do not quite understand the benefit of taking the more in depth course, so make sure to check it out/talk to an advisor before signing up.
That being said, DJ is an amazing professor. I attended a number of review sessions hosted throughout the semester that were run by some of the other professors and found their teaching methods far more confusing and indirect than DJs. I also found that DJ was genuinely interested in his students success. He gladly answers all questions, responds to emails in a timely manner, and never made me feel bad about asking him to repeat himself. In conclusion if you go for 1310, take it with DJ.
Now for the grading. This semester there were two different methods of grading, Traditional and Growth. At first everyone was freaking out about which grading method would result in getting a higher grade, but I honestly do not think it really mattered. There are pros and cons to each type of grading, so do not be too worried about ending up in one type vs. the other. I was in the traditional section which had 5 midterms in total ( 2 worth 20% each and 3 worth 1.6% each), a final exam (worth 25%), and the remaining percent was fluff (homework, preparation, etc.). I highly recommend taking the 1.6% midterms seriously since they do a good job of preparing you for the 20% midterms. To do well you should start studying AT LEAST a week in advance. The grading can be harsh and the problems are challenging. The graders also gave quite a bit of partial credit if you showed that you understood what was going on and made a viable attempt. While the midterms were hard, I didn't find anything unreasonable.

Calculus classes at UVA are exactly as hard as everyone says they are. I took 1310 as a non-STEM major because I thought I liked math -- this class changed my mind. HOWEVER, David was a fantastic instructor. I believe my class was the first one he had taught, and he did a phenomenal job. The fact that I do not look back on this class with pure regret is down to him. He's great at explaining math in a way that makes sense (which is NOT always true of grad students teaching math classes), and also just a really friendly and approachable guy. The growth-based system was still getting worked out when I took this class, but I think once they overhaul the way final grades are calculated it will work well (the way it was supposed to be calculated in Fall '22 was so harsh that they had to change it at the last minute). But I digress. Take a class with David if you can.

MATH 1310 really isn't so bad, but I think it definitely helps to have taken calculus before. The content is organized pretty well, but the flipped classroom structure (you learn the content initially as homework and review in class) is kind of annoying. The class has clear deadlines and structures and not too much homework though. I will say the exam structure is a little stupid. There are learning targets for each topic and on the exams, there is only one question per learning target, so you either show that you know it or it gives off the impression that you don't know it at all if you get the question wrong. Dounia was an alright professor, but I definitely wish I had a professor with more teaching experience (not her fault though; I think a lot of MATH 1310 professors this semester are grad students). She is very nice and understanding though, and the class environment is very chill. #tCFfall22

Hard class, if your major accepts 1210 take that instead. That being said 1310 wasn't terrible, the class and exams are curved so it isn't too difficult to get a grade in the B to A- range. Just do the homework.

This class takes a lot of work but Sarasij makes you fall in love with math. He is super passionate about the subject and knows how to explain difficult concepts well. He'll let you know what sections to watch out for and what usually trips students up. He is a star in the math department.

Professor Nguyen is honestly a good teacher. He's very funny without even trying, which is the best kind of humor. He goes pretty slow, and recaps the class before at the start of every class. My only complaint about him as a teacher is the discussion section is supposed to be for students to ask questions, and go over the most confusing part about the week, but he goes so slow during the week, that he turned our discussion into another lecture. That can be a pro to some people, or a con depending on how you see that. Now about the class, the exams are hard. They take the concepts learned in class and escalate them, but if you do the practice exams you should be okay. Just make sure to study a lot for them.#tCFspring2022

I believe that most of the professors for MATH 1310 are grad students, so keep in mind that my review is only specific to Don Phillips' class. He was a super nice and understanding instructor, and clearly enjoyed teaching. If he felt like he didn't do a good job in class or had an "off" day, he would type up an extra set of more thorough notes or re-explain during the next class just to make sure we didn't suffer from his self-perceived shortcomings. I swapped into his class from another, but even the other instructor had been super nice and entertaining. My friends who took MATH 1310 with other instructors also had great things to say about theirs, so I wouldn't worry too much about which instructor you choose, as most of the issues I describe seem to be a common trend among the majority of the school's Calculus instructors (even for the APMA calc courses).
The only classwork we had were questions in the notes (only collected for grading on occasion) and on WebAssign (some weeks had more assigned WebAssigns than others, but you can work ahead so it's not so unbearable. You can also request multiple automatic 24hr extensions on the site for every assignment that isn't class-prep for Don's class). You get a grade for taking notes on the class-prep assignments on WebAssign, and we had 3 quizzes during our worksop over the semester. We had 2 midterms and an exam. Most people I knew did pretty poorly on the first exam (65% or less with the curve), but they curved the grades on both. I hadn't studied on the first and got a 57% post-curve, and actually studied for the second to get an 81% post-curve (again, most people felt like they did pretty bad after this, but I did not compare grades with anyone on this exam so maybe they did better than expected). I took a year-round AP Calculus AB course in 11th grade, and this class was still pretty challenging since I'd forgotten how to work through most of the material. If you have no experience in Calculus, brace yourself.
As previously mentioned, so many people had a lot of difficulty with the exams which my peers and I chalked up to the structure of the classes. The whole MATH 1310 shares class notes (called "class activities") which is why this is a problem for a majority of classes regardless of which grad student you choose for an instructor. The class notes questions are usually very simple, and only the group questions (meant to be completed with your table) are thought-provoking. Don Phillips did a pretty nice job at explaining how to solve problems, but I felt like he lacked the "why" in solving problems. Because practice questions were so easy and the concepts weren't always discussed in-depth, the test questions would catch people completely off-guard. They required more conceptualization and a deeper understanding of the topics, which we did not get from notes and certainly did not get from the WebAssigns. However, the MATH 1310 department also publishes a ton of practice exams with keys on Collab, which is why I got an 81% on the second midterm. Walking out, everyone was complaining of the difficulty, but I had felt pretty confident (even though I did spend hours working through all of the published midterm 2 exams from previous years).
Overall, this class may be hard to succeed in since midterms and the final exam make up a combined 65% of your final grade, especially without previous experience in Calculus. If you need help, most of the instructors I met seemed extremely approachable and capable of offering help during office hours.

If you can, take this course with anyone else! For starters, he uses the free trial of some screenshare program which has pop-ups approximately every 5 minutes covering his notes, and he relies on students interrupting lecture to tell him to close them. Mark is also extremely unaccommodating and frankly rude in how he handles questions about both content and extensions. He takes about three to four days to respond to emails on average, and most of the time he keeps his responses very brief and vague. The only grades he posts on his gradebook are exam scores, and the rest of the grades are not accessible to students, even if you email him (he didn’t even bother to respond to my email about my final grade)! Overall, I do not recommend taking MATH 1310 with him to anyone, as although I ended up doing pretty well in his class, he single-handedly managed to ruin my calculus experience at UVA and is the reason I will not be continuing on to MATH 1320 next semester.
#tCF2020

I took this class in the spring of 2021, it just won't let me pick that. Anyway, Polstra is really good at explaining things, even better on a 1 to 1 basis. He offers a ton of extra credit so even if you don't quite understand things you can pass with a decent grade. Attend all the lectures, go to study group, do the extra credit opportunites, and do homework early for points and you will be fine.

If you need to take math 1310 (for your major, track, etc.) TAKE IT WITH VERONICA. She is extremely helpful in class and during office hours and genuinely cares about her students' success. There's a ton of extra credit opportunities offered in the class (it's tallied up into a formula and then added to each respective exam) and it's not that hard to get the extra points (doing weekly reflections, completing online homework at least 24 hours early, etc). That being said, the exams are relatively hard, testing you on APPLICATION of what you learned in class with a pretty fair curve.WARNING: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU HAVE NOT TAKEN CALCULUS IN HIGH SCHOOL BEFORE. You may be better suited in Math 1210 or a pre-calculus type of course here. Math 1310 is a theory-based Calculus course that goes beyond common concepts learned in high school. I definitely saw a lot of overlap between what I learned in Calc I in high school vs. Math 1310 here, however, you definitely build upon that prior knowledge with a lot of theory analysis on what seem like "common concepts." I STRONGLY SUGGEST you only take this course if you NEED IT--do some research on what you're looking at majoring in and if it requires you take Math 1310 (typically Math, Science-based majors...) then take it, if not, OPT FOR 1210 (if you even need Calc at all). I wish I knew this coming in, but ended up wanting to major in something that required 1310 as a prerequisite anyways, so I was lucky.All of that being said, if you NEED to take Math 1310 for any reason, TAKE IT WITH VERONICA. She really helped when I was struggling at the beginning given the pace of the course and even lets you redo assignments/give extensions if need be. She's super understanding and just wants to see her students succeed. She's also super passionate and attempts to make the class fun/interesting (whenever possible). I've heard friends with other Math 1310 instructors that haven't had quite as pleasant of an experience as me, and I really believe it has to do with Veronica. Super lenient and super enjoyable instructor, just be wary of how difficult the class can get and utilize her office hours!

Calc 1 is an absolute pain with the specificity, but it's not too bad. You have study guides and 3 prior exams to study for the 2 midterms and 1 final and the only thing that's terrible with the course is the 'Team HW' they make you do, but that's only 10% of your grade. You have weekly quizzes during discussion which aren't too bad and one is a problem you did in class and you get EC if you write piazza posts and if you turn in in-class worksheets from time to time. Veronica is really passionate about math and loves to teach it and explains everything very thoroughly. She is a tough grader on the quizzes but that's very helpful because then you learn about how specific you have to be on the tests and she wants you to excel. I probably put in maybe 2-3 hours a week during class and studied 30min prior to quizzes and a day or two before tests and ended up with an A so as long as you understand and decipher the material and go to class you'll do fine. Veronica's great, so take calc with her.

Math 1310 is required for many different majors, so you might just have to take it. I took Calc AB in high school so I thought this wouldn't be so bad. However, this calculus gets very specific and problems are heavy with trigonometry (instead of just taking the derivative of a function, the function has trig elements making it trickier). The grading is hard in the sense that if you forget certain things (like you do not carry the limit through your work) you lose points. The homework on WebAssign is tedious busy work that will take up time during your week. However, if you do it, it is an easy 100% for 10% of your grade. Another 10% comes from weekly quizzes that are short with two problems. If you study for these you can easily end up with a 90+% for this section. There are 5 "Written HW" that account for another 10% of your grade. These are much harder problems but can be done in a group. Go to office hours and you basically get the answers and 100%. The midterms and final are what tripped me up! The first midterm I overestimated my high school calculus knowledge and went into it blindly. TAKE THE PRACTICE EXAMS and STUDY! It will help you. I did better on the second midterm because I did this. The final was hard for everyone. If your teacher does exam credit points through in class worksheets or answering/asking questions on Piazza do that! Those exam credit points will save you! Even though I got 76% on the first midterm and final exam, I ended up with a B (almost a B+) just because I kept up with the workload for the other areas of the class.

I am not a math person and I only took this class because it was a prerequisite for my major. Still, this class wasn’t terrible. Veronica is super sweet and amazing. She’s good at explaining things and is clear about what she wants. There are lots of opportunities for extra credit (ex. Solving worksheet problems, posting on Piazza, turning in homework early) and the tests are curved generously (I’m not sure if that’s a math department decision or a professor decision). Piazza (discussion board) saved me. You get extra credit on exams for posting and answering questions, and it’s a great way to ask other students for help with homework. Also, the homework is online and most problems have tutorials. The grading and type of coursework is difficult to explain because when we switched from in-person to online, the types of assignments and their weights changed. There is an online reading and class prep assignment due before class each day. In class Veronica reviews what you learned in the class prep assignment, then the class gets into groups and works on practice problems. There is also written homework (about 3 or 4 of those) and online homework due every Sunday (complete the homework by midnight on Saturday and you get 10% extra credit on most problems). Originally, there were quizzes, two midterms, and a final. After the switch to Zoom, the quizzes and second midterm were combined into two Quests (so basically long quiz / short test). Exams were open note once we switched to the online format. Veronica puts solutions for class worksheets, quizzes, written homework, tests, and quests on Collab. She also provides practice problems to study for exams. DO THE PRACTICE PROBLEMS. I never did them, and my life would have been so much easier if I had practiced and studied more. But seriously, Veronica is amazing and if you take calc you should take it with her.

I never enjoyed math in high school, but I decided to give it another go in college to see if anything changed. I REALLY enjoyed this class and it has given me confidence to take more math classes in the future. You will get what you put into this class, and if you have any questions Prof Shalotenko is more than happy to help! I regret not attending more of her office hours but she is super friendly and sweet. 10/10 recommend taking it with her.There's a lot of room for extra credit, like attending study groups almost every Sunday and turning homework in early. You get plenty of time to do the study guides, and if you take the time to make sure you know the material outlined in the study guide, I honestly don't see how you can get below an A- on the exams.Long story short, Prof Shalotenko is one of the nicest professors I've had and take your time doing the assignments, it'll make the class more enjoyable!#tCF2020

The course itself functions on a flipped classroom, which works for some but doesn't for others. Prof. Dimou provides ample resources for students to ask questions and review course concepts. He also helps break down concepts once you ask a question. Overall, I would recommend taking a calculus course with Prof Dimou. #tCF2020
Gabe is really nice and explains the math really well in language that is easily understood.
Gabe explains concepts really well with examples that are easy to follow. He provides multiple examples and always makes sure that everyone understands. He is really nice!

He gets easily confused and is not good at explaining things. If you have never taken calculus before I would not recommend taking it with him. You will be stuck trying to teach yourself everything all semester.
Loved him!  Calc is a HARD class, but Gabe made it so much easier to understand.  He was also super helpful in office hours.

Ted is one awesome professor, making one of the worst math classes I've ever taken a much better experience. The course is extremely difficult. MATH 1310 is not for the faint of heart - I had taken Calc AB and BC in high school, and did decently on both. I expected this class to be easier as a result, but I was very wrong. It is very, very, theoretical and often borderline esoteric, making problems unnecessarily difficult and tests extremely hard.
If you must take this class, take it with Ted! He is an amazing teacher. He is caring, understanding, and always willing to help.  He's great at explaining and is genuinely there to help you get through and be the best at math you can be. Highly recommend Ted, do not recommend the class.

This class is taken primarily online, where you watch videos and complete class prep assignments before you get to class and then work on a group work assignment with your table to review the material. I absolutely detest this format and find it impossible to learn anything. A lot of the time, the prep assignments don't teach you what you need to know to succeed in the class and things are very rarely explained before you have to dive into group work together. Our teacher was great and really did his best (he's really great Ted is the best), but the class is meant to be very self driven and self taught and I personally found that impossible to manage. I have taken (and succeeded in) calculus before but found this class incredibly difficult to manage, and can't imagine being successful in it without that calculus background. But even then, I still only understand about 50% of the material we are presented with. I do not recommend taking this class unless you *absolutely* have to.

Hands down  the best professor! Be aware there'a flip version of this class which they first tested out in Fall 2017! I thought it was fine, some didn't. Nonetheless, Jon is super knowledgeable, approachable and overall an awesome teacher. If you're going to take CALC I, take it with him!

Only cared about his grad school requirement, Protect your GPA - DO NOT TAKE CLASS. Students would often have to come to the front of the class to help HIM solve a problem when another student initially asked the question. WebAssigns, classwork(assigned group work the entire class time instead of teaching), and homework(group p sets) did not even vaguely match up to exams. Didn’t care if students learned anything at all. He laughed multiple times at a student who was seriously sick and coughing loud enough for the entire auditorium to hear during an exam(they were told they couldn’t come in at a later date). Not sure how denying someone a reasonable request and laughing at them later is amusing in any sense of the imagination. Extremely unhelpful during office hours as he would spend hours trying to explain a convoluted p set he assigned students for homework, while it was not even correlated to exams or even a WebAssign at that. Not sure how he is still "teaching", recommend any of the other TAs. A lot worse reviews were previously here - guess things are getting deleted when they are a little too true? Students are PAYING for this, we should have legitimate professors.

Professor gates is great. He gives sooo many examples in class and is happy to answer any questions. I went to him a couple of times during office hours, and he was pretty helpful but not as much as his TA was. I would say he is one of the better calculus teachers.

Zachary Gates is an awesome teacher. He got better and better as the semester progressed and adapted to the needs of his students. He was very fun and understanding but still does not take it easy on you and wants to challenge you. WebAssign is the online homework and while it may be tedious it is very helpful. I would recommend having already taken Calc 1 in high school if you decide to take this course, it moves very quickly.

Kristin is a great teacher, but the class was very difficult. The class itself (quizzes, homework, activities) didn't really match the tests. Quizzes and homeworks were all super easy, but the tests were so so difficult- it didn't really match up. But Kristin is very smart and a very good teacher! Overall, I got a B- in the class, so not too too bad, but it definitely isn't an easy A.

Professor Mak (goes by Anthony) was an outstanding calculus teacher. If you have to take calc 1, he is a great option. He explains the material in a variety of ways and is approachable outside of class. There is hard work but that is expected in any calc class. He grades fairly and is, in my opinion, an excellent calc teacher to have here!

Trust me when I say do not take him. Without question,  worst teacher I ever had. Took Calc II fall 2016. Absolutely avoid at all costs. You are better off shooting yourself in the foot. please dear god I beg of you do not take any of his classes. You still have a chance to get out. I wasn't that lucky.

Joshua is the man! He is very knowledgeable in the subject and a good teacher. He can be quick sometimes but he makes himself readily available to answer any questions. He is a bit shy but a great guy overall.

Calculus is a hard subject but professor Campbell made it somewhat easier. While he was a little shy in class, and moved a little fast he was really good when you asked for help. Fair teacher, not incredibly exciting, but its math, what can you do?

Math 1310 is taught by GA's so they aren't really versed in how exactly to teach material. She did well with what we gave her and answered questions the best she could. practice problems on your own and do the practice exams. The final was not fair at all, and this is coming from someone who took ap calc but did not get credit from the university. Its not a fun class but calc is important.

Professor He spends the whole class writing examples on the board and doesn't stop to see if everyone is following (which normally they are not) until the very end. She then is not very good at explaining where the confusion is. That being said, she is a nice person and you can tell she wants you to do well.

There are 2 midterms for this class and a final. Written homework is due weekly along with online homework using WebAssign. Hardy is a really smart guy but is very unapproachable and a bit intimidating. He knows what he is talking about and is really smart. I was honestly kinda scared to go to office hours though.

Stephen is such a great guy. Knowledgeable, hilarious, approachable, and caring, I definitely think I was able to understand the material better with him as my instructor. Awesome guy, highly recommended that you take any class he teaches

The best calculus instructor you can possibly have! Very Nice! Very Funny! Take Calc with Hardy and you will learn a new word every class! Classes full of fun factors and organized explanations. Never screwed up any of the key points in class! Just Love him and his hairstyle!

I love Mr. Bourdon, but I am a strong math person (probably a math major). Also, I took previous calculus courses. He is extremely passionate about teaching, and definitely makes you think to uncover the answer. However, I can easily see that if you hadn't taken calculus before or aren't the strongest math person, that his teaching style can be confusing. His office hours are rather empty, I strongly recommend attending them. Put in the work and you'll be fine!
He is honestly a great professor. He will try his best to help you. If you don't understand anything in class, go to his office hours. He will go to lengths to help you.

I absolutely loved being in Arone's class. The professor appears to be socially awkward in the beginning but the humor grows on you and you end up enjoying the tiny jokes he makes. He grades part twos alot more leniently than the other teacher and tries to give you points. He tries his best to make sure everyone gets it, dont be afraid to ask questions, two, three, or four times (his hearing is a little impaired)

I really enjoyed this class. Professor Arone's accent is a little strong but he knows this and will make jokes, but he also communicates really well because of his accent. Other than that the class was pretty easy for me, the midterms were very easy, however, the final was really hard and brought my grade down a bit. Overall, a great class with a funny professor who really wants to teach you the information.

You're just going to dislike this guy as a person. Super annoying, rushes through the material, loves to go off on tangents and do math you don't need to know. Only take his class if you have no other option.

Franz, franz, franz. Thats the name of the game here. It was sort of an up and down year for me and Daniel. I wasn't a huge fan of his grading and the exams were difficult, but low and behold, Franz pulled through and hooked your boy up with a b-, which was pretty steep nonetheless. Do not take this class unless you have a fascination with the word Franz. That's my only bit of advice. Shoutout to ugly, weasley, and ori. I'm out.

Although I never actually took this course with Daniel Franz, I can honestly say that he has impacted my life. Whenever I'm feeling down, I think of Professor Franz and instantly I am inundated with bliss. On top of it all, Daniel made me fall in love with WebAssign. One day, I hope to be the CEO of WebAssign, and become a major shareholder in WebWork. Franz strikes again.
-Sprague

Sometimes homework can take 30 minutes, but usually it takes 3 hours or more. There is a quiz each week given during discussion, so you have to go to discussion. That's how they enforce its mandatory nature. There are two midterms. The first one is relatively easy, and the second one is extremely difficult. The average seemed to be at 70%. The final was on the same level as the second midterm. He never tells the average, but it was likely around 70%. There is a slight curve, but it is small. Don't rely on it. Lecture is extremely boring, and he tends to complicate things. If you are on a pre-comm track, just take Applied Calc 1. Don't be a fool and think that you are showing more effort by taking regular calc 1. It's not worth it.

He's a TA who cannot teach at all. He goes on tangents all the time during lecture and wastes time. Additionally, while doing an example, he'll stand there for a long time just trying to figure out how to even solve it. Get another TA if possible.
Basically, he writes the textbook in chalk during lecture.  But the discussions were helpful.  And the curve is definitely generous.

Not very hard class if you have any calc background and its also curved at the end.  I didn't attend class much, but when I did I felt Reed wasn't a very good teacher.  Smart, nice guy, but pretty much your stereotypical math-nerd grad student with a hint of awkwardness. One thing I can say about him is that I had way less HW than friends taking this class with other professors (usually only 10-15 problems a week!).  Brad Dorner was my TA and I would definitely recommend him! Really hope he teaches a class one day.

It was always really difficult to understand the material because he never really explained it well. Every aspect of the class was difficult including homework, quizzes, tests, and the final, but that wasnt the professors fault thats just the way the course is designed.
It's really a hard course and I always cannot understand what he is talking about on class...You have to spend much time to study by yourself...

He speaks really, really fast. First day of class is hard because of this, but you get used to it. This class is hard (unless you are a math wiz in which case do whatever you want). I'm not majoring in STEM and this class kicked my ass. You learn calc, so if that's what you want, do it. Take the homework seriously, you will need to put in a lot of effort if you are slightly above average at math like me. The lectures are important, but he goes so fast and doesn't label things so they are very, very hard to follow. My notes from lecture are pretty useless to me. You don't need to buy the book, you can if you want, but online math tutorials worked better for me. Take at your own peril because this isn't AP calc boys and girls.
I used to love math, but this class made me reevaluate.
Easy class. Should be no problem. Little disorganized, but with a Calc background, you'll be fine.
Socolovsky is a really nice guy but he is the worst at explaining the ideas. He spends most of his time staring at the board trying to figure out how he screwed up the example this time.
This was a good class but fairly difficult. It is better to have a previous calculus understanding before taking 131.

Tim is amazing! He makes calculus fun and understanding for everyone. There is a quiz every week during discussion but Tim only takes the ten highest grades. There is a homework assignment due each week online and a written homework assignment due on fridays at 5. Most of the problems are tricky but GO TO OFFICE HOURS!! Like legit! He will help you with whatever you need assistance on. Also don't leave your cell phone on in class unless you want to bring in two dozens of cookies :-)

Great guy, makes understanding calculus very easy.  There's a WebWork due every Tuesday as well as a short (~ 5 problem) written homework due every Friday.  The written homeworks are tricky, but you have ample opportunity to get help and work through them before they're due at the end of the week.  There are weekly quizzes every Thursday that are pretty easy.

Tim is very enthusiastic about the material and it is important to him that his class understands everything. That being said, the homework was unnecessarily difficult considering it's graded on accuracy. The webworks took forever compared to other classes. All in all he's a pretty good teacher.
Tim is so funny! He always brings cookie when we have midterms lol~ Although his written homework is really hard, his class is well-organized and clear. Recommended!!
Emerick is by far the best Math teacher I've ever had. A good grade in Calculus is possible with this teacher.
Yeah, you're taking this because you have to. Good luck. Quizzes in the discussions will be the hardest thing you do, exams right behind. Study hard.

Calc 2 is quite a difficult class, but Professor Rolf really does his best, and I found the flipped classroom setup helpful. Professor Rolf is very approachable in class and in office hours and wants you to succeed. I can't say that the class was always enjoyable, since it was rather brutal at times, but this was from the material itself and not because of Professor Rolf. In my experience I especially struggled with shell method integration at the beginning of the semester and Taylor series toward the end. You'll generally have two video lectures with short "prep problem" sets, two longer homework sets, in-class questions, and a quiz to do each week. Starting a few weeks into the semester you'll have written homework sets due every other week. If you're a STEM major, you most likely are required to take this class, but take it with Professor Rolf if you can to make things better.

ZACH IS THE MAAAAN! Calc II is a tough nut to crack, but Zach explains everything in such a digestible way and always encourages you stop and ask questions without judgment. The Prep Videos and WebAssigns are kind of annoying to keep up with, but they are helpful in the long run. We also had quizzes almost every week during the discussion sections, and his quizzes can be on the harder side sometimes, so make sure you prepare for them!
He holds extra office hours for us near exams season, and he tries to make himself available for us outside of his normal office hours as well! He is extremely patient and understanding, and genuinely cares about his students' success. Additionally, he tried to connect with students on a personal level as well -- he became more like a friend as the semester progressed. My calculus experience in high school was quite horrendous, but this was definitely my favorite class this semester, and all the credit goes to him. TAKE CALC II WITH ZACH! #tCFfall22

TAKE THIS CLASS WITH ZACH GATES!!!!! This course itself is difficult, but it was made extremely enjoyable by Professor Gates. He is a fantastic instructor, able to make complicated things seem simple. He listened to our input and really listened to our questions and answered them in detail. You will never feel like you don't belong in his classroom. Not only is he great at teaching the concepts, but he also values each and every one of his students for who they are as people. He truly wanted to get to know us and also cared about how we were doing as people, always understanding if we needed an extension or some extra help because we were sick or just in a bad place. This was my first semester in college, and I never could have imagined having a professor that cares so deeply about the students academically and as human beings. Beyond that, he makes class enjoyable with his sense of humor and teaching style. If you are able to, I highly recommend taking this class with Professor Gates.The class itself definitely poses some difficulty, and things like webassign and prep videos definitely got annoying, but class itself was always engaging and enjoyable. The exams are hard, so studying for those is important (I learned that the hard way) but it is definitely doable and the professors do try to make all of the work fair.Just to reiterate, ZACH GATES IS AMAZING AND YOU WILL LOVE TAKING THIS CLASS WITH HIM! Truly an amazing professor and human being.

Zach Gates is the best! Calculus II is a notoriously difficult course but Zach does a great job of making it understandable! He doesn't assume that you fully understand the topics from the prep-videos, and takes the time in class to answer questions and explain concepts. Most importantly, Zach creates a classroom environment in which everyone feels welcome and included. Outside of the classroom, Zach hosts frequent office hours to walk through homework, review assessments, or just talk. One of the best things about this course is that by the end of it I felt I truly knew Zach as a person and as a friend. You can really tell that he genuinely cares about his students. Don't be mistaken, the class is still a lot of work. It takes time and practice to master the concepts covered in the course. I routinely put 7+ hours a week into the class, between WebAssign homework and studying for the weekly quizzes. However it is very manageable if you work hard and plan it out, something Zach is more than willing to help you make happen.

Professor Sonkin was my favorite professor this semester!  Calc 2 is a difficult class to begin with, but Professor Sonkin's lectures definitely made the class go seamlessly.  Near the beginning of the semester, it was a little difficult to understand his voice under the mask plus his slight Russian accent, however, after a couple weeks I didn't seem to notice.  He knows his stuff, and always makes an effort to answer questions to the best of his ability. The exams are pretty difficult but doing the practice exams that the professor provides helps a LOT.  If you have a solid foundation in high school math and Calc 1, you will do well in this class.  Networking with your classmates is also a very beneficial way to make sure you understand the material to the best of your ability.  Also, make sure to keep up with the WebAssigns and the written homework, as they will help you tremendously on the weekly quizzes and exams.

Professor Sonkin is one of my favorite teachers ever and easily the best math teacher I have ever had. I came in on the first day and thought that I would be in for a rough semester, and though I was, Prof. Sonkin made it so much better. He is such a nice and funny guy and really tries to make sure that you understand everything. Not once did he make anyone feel inferior for asking clarification questions, he was always super supportive. Towards the end of the semester, around finals, I got sick and asked Prof. Sonkin what would happen if I was unable to take the final. He explained that there are other avenues we can work through if I am unable to take it during the allotted time. Luckily, I was able to take it in person, but what was so amazing is that Prof. Sonkin approached me in the final testing hall while passing out final exams and asked me if I was feeling better with a smile coming out from under the mask. Such a genuine guy, would absolutely recommend taking the course with him. As for the class itself, easily the hardest class I have ever taken (took it first semester of first year for reference), but when the teacher is fun and nice, it makes it way more tolerable. Prof. Sonkin is also a very reasonable grader. The tests were pretty difficult for me, though there are some people I know who did very well on all of them so it is definitely possible. If you have to take Calc 2, it's going to be difficult and time consuming, but this is definitely the guy to take it with. I can promise he'll make you smile every week.

This was a bearable class for calculus 2. Dmitry doesn't use printed class handouts each class, so it's important to take notes during classprep videos and during class. Classwork is always done in groups and sometimes it is submitted (just for completion or attempt at completion). Dmitry is a very nice and personable professor, and he clearly knows the subject very well; he is very helpful in office hours and in class answering questions. Overall the only downfall is not getting handouts to look over before exams (make sure to take good notes yourself!)

Professor Sonkin did a great job of explaining the concepts. It is a difficult class, but paying attention in class and doing the assignments really helps. The professor is also very approachable if you have questions during class/classwork. There are weekly quizzes, but you don't really need to prepare since he goes over the content right before the quizzes, so you're fine.

Sonkin had pros and cons. I went to Rolfs office hours once or twice and learned nothing - its clear Rolf is smart but he could not communicate anything to my level of understanding, and he made videos we had to watch for the course which I stopped watching bc they had nothing to do with the class. Sonkin says u dont need a textbook, but I LIVED by that thing. Would definitely recommend getting a paper textbook if u can afford it as the online one is hard to use. Before I decided to rent a textbook, I actually checked out a couple random calc books from the library bc they all teach similar ways and that was helpful I just had to search the books a little more since it wasnt what the prof used. So compared to Rolf, Sonkin is AMAZING. It took me a little bit to get used to his accent, but definitely don't let something as small as that discourage you. All calc ii classes move really quickly but I wish Sonkin involved us more in discussion instead of him quickly walking through it but hes always happy to answer questions and be available to help. U definitely have to be paying attention in lecture. He really cares about his students, but his quizzes are way harder than other professors, though he would drop hints during class like are you surreeeeee you dont have questions about this? He pushed harder, but I think I was more prepared for exams. Definitely do the practice exams before a real one...web assigns arent really related to the exam for some reason. I liked McCarthy's office hours (and I think his quizzes were more straightforward) and the Math Collaborative Learning Center (MCLC) - I went pretty much every day to work on my homework because that is where another student working at the MCLC would take more time to explain things (especially if Marco and Casia are there!). This class is just ridiculously hard for no reason. I would definitely say the lectures are supplementary in that if u don't figure out/understand basics before lecture (which I would do at the MCLC), you might get lost. Also, I hadn't taken calc ii before and it was clear some people had already taken ap calc bc in high school so ask the "dumb" questions because the person "easily" understanding it next to you is probably hearing it for the second time.

Professor McCarthy was a GREAT professor. He really tried to connect with his students if anyone was struggling with the material, he made everyone feel welcome to ask questions, and he went beyond teaching the content by showing us his own demos he created. Though the content could be hard at times, especially with starting sequences and series, it was nothing too too challenging and with some effort it's easy to get a good grade. There are a lot of webassigns, a few written homeworks, a quiz each week, and 3 exams. I would definitely recommend this professor and this class.

As far as I'm aware, Matt isn't teaching this class anymore, so I hope you're reading this Matt! 1320 is a really hard class. Like genuienly difficult. There is a lot of work and you have to do all of it. It'll often make zero sense. UVA offers a lot of support for math, so really take advantage of it. However, Matt is one of the nicest, most understanding teachers I've met. He teaches math pretty well and is entertaining in his own special Matt way. All the 1320 lecturers get to design their own quizzes, and Matt's are some of the easiest. This makes the class far less stressful. I'm really sad Matt is leaving (if that is true), but I hope he has a great time in whatever life brings him in the future!

i took fall 23 idk why its not showing up, yuan zhang the absolute goat, it can be confusing in the beginning but the structure makes a lot of sense and the workload is manageable. highly recommend taking with yuan! many hw assignments and pre class things that can help boost ur grade a bit, 3 exams with a higher weighting on the final. if you pay attention in class u will be fine, but there are also so many resources you can go to for extra help, and many practices to do before exams that really help.

This Math Department course proved enjoyable and accommodating, especially as my first with the department at this school. Initially appearing challenging, it required a review of Calculus I content. Despite the difficulty stemming from a lapse in memory, adapting to the lecture style and instructor's accent made the course more manageable over time.
The instructor initially presented concepts with convoluted explanations, but this perception changed after adjusting to the teaching style. Our Learning Assistant, Sydney, played a crucial role during lectures, providing alternative interpretations and solutions when needed. The course became a breeze once these adjustments were made.
Regular completion of WebAssign homework, despite occasional confusion, contributed to a deeper understanding of the concepts. Jim Rolf's supplemental videos and other assignments, such as problem sets and quizzes, were manageable with preparation. Connecting with classmates for questions and study sessions proved advantageous.
Exams, including two midterms with ample resources, were navigable. Additionally, a final (which I haven't taken yet) awaits. Office hours, MCLC, practice exams, P2L sessions, and Learning Assistant-led review sessions enhanced preparation.
I recommend taking the course with Yuan Zhang!Despite initial challenges, achieving a desirable grade is possible with consistent effort and proper completion of assignments.
#tCFF23

Matt is by far my favorite professor at UVA. He is nothing like what you would expect a professor to be like, but he is the best. Going to class was actually so fun because he always made so many jokes. I don't know if some of them were meant to be jokes but just is mannerisms were so fun. This class also is not that bad. The webassign homeworks are easy to get an 100 on, participation is easy, and written homeworks are easy. The weekly quizzes can be challenging because I personally never studied for them because they are so little of your grade. Also your lowest 3 get dropped. The exams are tough but fair. The professors give you old practice exams, and the exams they give you are just like the practice exams. They are more challenging than anything you do in class, but since they are just like the old ones I feel like its fair. I would just spend a lot of time studying for the exams and don't leave studying until the last minute, and you will be fine.#tCFspring2022

Coming into Calc II, I was worried about everything I'd heard about the difficulty. Luckily, this course wasn't as challenging as I expected it to be based on what I heard. Matt is an awesome professor and overall, I highly recommend taking Math 1320 with him. He made class fun and engaging, explained concepts well, and his overall demeanor was very conducive to learning. He is very approachable whenever you have questions, and I definitely recommend going to office hours — I only went once and regret not going more. In office hours, he is extremely helpful and I left much more knowledgable than I came in. Overall, I would highly recommend taking this course with Matt, but I would not sweat it if you are unable to find a spot in his section — instructor names are not usually available when registering for the course, and all sections take the same exams, complete the same prep questions, as well as the same homework.

Dimou was a pretty good professor. He would sometimes get frustrated with the class if no one answered a question and one on one he could be a little intimidating and also get frustrated if it seemed like you were asking a dumb question. However, he was very available in office hours (would definitely recommend going) and by email, and seemed to generally care about his students.  A lot of his class was tied to the same standards as the rest of the 1320 classes and I'm not quite sure what was unique to him and what every class had to do.  Before every class we had to watch a prep video and complete a prep "quiz" on webassign (these were pretty much the same format as the homeworks on webassign but shorter). We also typically had two homeworks on webassign a week. Webassign allows multiple tries per problem and often gives videos of similar problems to solve or you can hit "practice another" to solve a similar problem and not waste your attempts on the real one. Usually you do not lose points per attempt except for a few homeworks in the middle of the semester that were mainly multiple choice so be on the lookout for that.  Webassigns do take quite a bit of time to work through so plan for that.  It can be very frustrating if you just don't know how to do something (and a lot of the problems are much more difficult than what is done in class). I highly recommend getting ahead on your webassigns so you can go to the MCLC to help with these.  There were also a few written homeworks that were counted in the same category as quizzes so you definitely wanted to do well on these to boost that grade and going to MCLC was a great option for that (and even office hours if you can get it started early enough).  In class, Dimou would pretty much just go through and annotate notes (that you can print out beforehand) and solve a few practice problems. He used learning catalytics to ask questions to the whole class (but these were only graded for participation). He also let us in breakout rooms for a bit at the end of class to begin our homework. During discussion there were usually quizzes every week with some exceptions. I felt like these got easier as the year progressed and were okay on time although harder than the class problems usually (except when he started giving us content from the day before on the quizzes and made it easy because of that). Finally, for tests, these were made by the coordinator of 1320 and Dimou and the other instructors did not know what was on them. They were pretty hard (a lot of problems that were more conceptual and could be solved quickly if you saw it right away but otherwise were a bit of a time crunch). There were 4 exams (the fourth was a non-cumulative final worth just as much as the other exams). Overall, if you have to take calc 2, survey is probably easier, but taking with Dimou is not a bad option.

I hate this course, but that's expected from Calc 2. I'm really glad that I chose Prof. Maitra for this course. The material is actually not that difficult to grasp and professor Maitra is actually a GOOD professor in so many ways. He understands the material (going to OH was very helpful), is very lenient in grading, and genuinely cares for his students. There's about 2-3 Web-assign homework problem sets due Sunday/Monday nights that take a bit of time. However, I will say that you can do the 'practice another' to find the solution OR if you manage to find the textbook solutions like I did, they follow the problem number. There was one quiz every Friday morning, although he ended up giving everyone 10/10 on three of the quizzes; instead of giving us quizzes, we would all just go over more problems that day and they were participation points. He truly understands that we are in a pandemic and every student is struggling.
The real problem is with the exams. Prof. Maitra does not make the exam taken in this class (I believe none of the instructors do, but some of the math department faculties do instead) and they are DIFFICULT. There's 3 exams in total + a final exam each worth 17.5%. My score of each exam gradually went down although I did do a lot better than I expected on the final. The class quizzes and Web-Assign problems are time consuming but are not that difficult. But the exams are just indescribably difficult and make no sense most of the time. Even though they give you practice exams + the solutions, the actual exams are like 20000x harder than what's on the practice. Also, there's three written home work problem sets to help 'prep' you for the exam but they don't even help and those are incredibly difficult as well. Do not take this class by yourself - make sure to take it with a few friends. Also, if you can, I highly recommend taking it with Prof. Maitra because he goes over a lot of materials and gives a lot of partial credit. Just make sure you have your pi circle and trig functions memorized prior to taking this class! #tCF2020

This class is the utter bane of my existence. This class is so incoherent and Aleksander is not the best teacher in the world. He doesn't have organized lesson plans and he often asks a question and never answers it. This class is technically the reversed/flipped format that the math department is slowly integrating in. We spent half the semester in the flipped setup but I was often left wondering what exactly I was supposed to be getting from this class. You aren't sure what is expected of you and Aleksander never goes over the specific notations that you need to write in on the midterm. He always says "You'll have to show more work on the midterm" but then doesn't go into detail about what the work is or what it looks like. Sometimes Aleksander would spend 30 minutes showing a problem to then say, "Oh, sorry. Actually I did this problem wrong but no big deal..." Most recently, Aleksander notified us that the study guide for the exam that accounts for 25% of your grade was one that was mistakingly sent from a few years ago. This was literally the day before the exam!
I had Jiacheng Miao for my TA and he would give quizzes that hardly reflect what was even briefly talked about in lecture and he often refused to tell us what would be on the quiz until we got a few weeks into the semester. Please don't make my mistake and do not stick with this class. If you get either of these individuals, please switch sections or straight up drop the class. I've never had exposure to Calc II and this was the worst way possible.

Where do I begin? As someone who used to love math, this was enough to make me hate it. Still want to keep reading? Aleksander meant well, but he was often disorganized. We had no idea what to expect; even if our steps were correct, they weren't exactly what was on the key, and people would get docked left and right...more on that in the review of the TA (Jiacheng Miao). We never actually learned how to properly do problems. Aleksander also never used his UVA email; he kept using this email service called dcemail.com, and emails from him were often in my spam folder. He also used a bunch of other emails to contact us. Also, the flipped classroom concept was stupid and ineffective. Absolutely horrible.
