I can't imagine why someone thought this was a good idea, especially to teach people something like calculus. We moved to a regular setup later, but improvements were marginal. Horrible class that ruined my semester and like the review below, was the bane of my existence.

I had Jiacheng Miao for my TA and he would often present the wrong information on the board to the point that students would often be the ones pointing out mistakes he was making. He made simple mistakes like thinking that -2 + 3 was -5 to getting entire concepts wrong. He showed a blatantly wrong procedure for partial fractions. He would give quizzes that hardly reflect what was even briefly talked about in lecture and he often refused to tell us what would be on the quiz until we got a few weeks into the semester. My main teacher even briefly mentioned how Jiacheng would send the quizzes for approval less than an hour before discussion and then would go ahead with it anyways regardless of if the teacher had points of contention with it. It got so bad that main teacher now shows up to our discussions to make sure that Jiacheng isn't telling us total BS. Also, you'll never know what Jiacheng is taking points off for because he never explains it. It's truly such a reassuring thought to know that he is part of the grading process for the exams and indiscriminately takes off points with zero consistency between people. He'll take off a point on one person's exam but not at all on anothers.
If he's your TA, hope you have a good professor to balance out. If they're both bad, please drop. If, in some twisted way of fate, he is your main lecturer, DROP THIS CLASS and run!

Bad. Horrible. Awful. This may rehash the review below at times, but here we go. Diego was incompetent; his quizzes were nothing short of unfair and ill-timed. We never had adequate time to do it. His grading was unbelievably arbitrary. I compared my midterm with a friend in the course, and she got docked more points on a problem that he graded, even though we had the same steps. He never pointed out where points were lost either.   His mistakes were often in basic arithmetic; we corrected him often. He would ask us if he did problems right. Encouraging, is it now? He might be a better TA for a higher-level math course, but this one was bad. As I told my roommate after he asked me how a quiz or exam in this course went, it was not reflective of my abilities as a student. I like to think I know how to do calculus; this class turned me away from math.

Luis Pereira is one of the worst teachers I've ever had. He is definitely in his own world when he teaches, as he dismisses students as if they are a liability rather than his students. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH HIM. Our class average was almost 10% worse than the rest of the sections combined...THAT Is not a problem with the students, it is a problem with the teacher. HE is incoherent and most definitely incomprehensible. If it wasn't mid- November, I would withdraw...and if I could withdraw from this class I would. In all honesty, he's the worst Calc professor. I have gone to higher level math courses in my previous years, but he makes material so difficult to understand (material that I already know!). Thus, don't take Calc I with him, because there are far better professors out there that are willing to help his students. His accent and the speed with which he teaches classes makes it 100 times harder than it needs to be. HE's erratic, walking around during our exam, thinking and making huge hand gestures...it's distracting and unnecessary.
Just don't take 1310 with Luis.
He wasn't a bad teacher. He did his best to cover the large range of topics. Should probably take a calculus course prior to signing up for this class otherwise you might get a little lost.

Professor Pereira is a really great guy. If you go to his office hours, you'll find that he cares a lot if you understood the material.  But this is not an easy A class, so be prepared to put in work - which is expected of you.

This class is a great deal of work (44 homework problems a week, 40 hard ones online, 4 easier ones written). Atkinson is pretty good at explanations, but his lectures consist of copying the book to the board, which just won't work for some students as a teaching method, but it's at least adequate for seeing the book translated into a more consumable form. There are 10 minute quizzes at the end of discussion each week. Discussions are an opportunity to get more comfortable with the material with better explanations of the concepts. The TA, Mark Schrecengost, was really good at explanations and very helpful. There are three tests, which consist of two midterms and a final. The final was much harder than the previous two midterms. If you keep up with the homework, which can take a great deal of time to complete, and make sure you're comfortable with the material each week, you will do well on the tests.

Professor Atkinson was great at making the material understandable and was very helpful in office hours. The material was very difficult, and a lot of students struggled in the class. He also assigned an excessive amount of homework. However, all of that being said, the class was really fun with a great teacher overall.

I had Professor Bourdon for both Calculus 1 and 2. He is very passionate about the subject he teaches, and he is brilliant. Calculus 2 has never been easy but Mr. Bourdon presented it in an enthusiastic way to make it somewhat more manageable. Web assign, weekly written hw. He is very approachable and is willing to extend his office hours if you really need help. The whole MATH1320 staff writes the exams (not Bourdon himself) and they are not easy. Overall, strongly recommend Professor Bourdon!

I took MATH 1210 before this, but MATH 1220 is the usual prereq. I did ok, but Calc 2 is a very difficult class and I would recommend you only take this if you have a strong math background (or need to take it). Bourdon is a good teacher, very helpful with homework, and a fair grader. Exams are hard, no doubt about it, but he offers several study opportunities in advance for each one. I am not a particularly good math student, and I didn't do an outstanding amount of reading the textbook, but I went to class and discussion every single time and did all the homework to the best of my ability. I came out with a C, probably could have had a C+ if I really devoted myself to it. Tough course, but totally doable.
This class is as difficult and time consuming as people say. Essentially just work hard throughout the school year and try as hard as you can and the curve will help you out in the end.

Does not speak English very well. Assigns an absurd amount of homework, when brought her individual questions had to consult other students and the internet and the book to solve. Would not take this class unless required for major.

This class takes a lot of time and effort. There were 3 web homeworks, 1 written homework, and 1 quiz every single week. The material itself is not hard to understand, but the questions asked in the HWs, quizzes and exams really your understanding of the concepts. Essentially, it isn't sufficient to memorize the formula and apply it in the exams. This Calculus class requires you to recognize recurring patterns from different topics and apply them in a single setting/question.Scott himself isn't too good a lecturer. He mumbles often and the topics he explains are often disjointed.  Do yourself a favor and pre-read the textbook to gain better understanding of the material before coming to class.  Nonetheless, his explanations become clearer by almost tenfold when you attend his office hours, so I recommend you do that. I get the feeling that he is uncomfortable in large class situations with many eyes scrutinizing on him.

Daniel Franz is an excellent professor. His lectures are logical and clear, and he goes through proofs of many concepts so that his students can actually understand the logic behind calculus rather than just memorize formulas. He brings genuine excitement about calculus to the class and makes it interesting by explaining its historical origins and relevant by explaining its past and present applications to natural phenomena. He makes himself available in office hours many times a week and is patient and helpful if you come with questions.Calculus II itself is interesting but difficult. The homework and quizzes themselves are totally doable if you're dedicated and willing to get help at office hours. The homework assignments took me a long time, but I would often do them in one sitting. The exams though are wicked hard and much worse than the homework and quizzes, but they were curved by 20% or 30%. Work to get 100% on the homework and quizzes so that your exams don't wreck your grade.Conceptually, Calculus II is fascinating. As a class, it's difficult. Be ready to study hard for the exams because the questions are like challenge problems and don't just test concepts. If you love math, then take this class because  you'll probably love it. If you need calculus II as a requirement, then try to take Professor Franz because he's very good.

Daniel Franz is a great professor. His lectures are clear and full of good examples that are very helpful with the homework (which is pretty difficult). Although it is hard for him to actually teach for the tests, because someone else writes them, he still does an admirable job. The class is also made a little bit less tense by his engagement with students and occasional nerdy jokes!

Chun Ju was an awesome professor but probably won't teach this ever again. So if you're reading this, take applied Calc instead of MATH 1320. Seriously. Hardest class I have taken in my life and I took BC Calc in high school. Incredible amounts of work were poured into this class just to get a B. If you are a math genius, go for it. If you are moderately good at math but it's not your favorite, don't even think about it. The class had a generous curve and even then I was consistently doing poorly throughout despite hours of work being poured into this class every week. It most likely will not be kind to your GPA and there are easier ways of getting this requirement done for many people.  Seriously take applied.

Calc 2 was the hardest class during my semester however if you put in the proper work like I began to later in the semester you will get results.  I'd recommend office hours if anything is unclear but to do well in this class you need to do as many practice problems as possible as the midterms are fairly difficult and I remember many problems that stumped me for 10+ minutes.  Chun was very energetic and did well making sure that students in the class were following along but don't take Calculus 2 for fun. period.

He is a great professor and is really good at explaining things. He answers everyone's questions and replies to emails very quickly. The class material is difficult, but he does a good job preparing you for the exam. I would definitely recommend him!

People say that Calc 2 is one of the hardest classes at UVA, but don't let that deter you from taking this class. Speaking as someone who took AP Calc BC and Multivariable Calc/Differential Equations in high school, most of this class was a review so bring your old notes to college with you! Small warning: this class goes into depth on sequences and series, which is probably my least favorite unit of all time. Even so, the notes we take in class are really detailed and Prof. Wan is more than willing to meet outside of class. Even though I won't be majoring in mathematics, I'm glad I took this class because it wasn't overly difficult and the work was relatively straightforward. Homework is usually online and can be difficult at times when it doesn't quite match up with what we did in class, but it's do-able. Written homework occasionally, but don't freak out because Prof. Wan explains the problems ahead of time so you know what to do.

Mr. Wan is an excellent professor. He does a great job of explaining the different concepts and methods in Calculus II. Some of my classmates claimed to have difficulty understanding his English sometimes, although I rarely ran into this problem.

Professor Wan is awesome. He is really nice and was always available to help when I was struggling with concepts. My best advice is to go to office hours. I didn't enough and could probably have done better if I had gone. Bottom line the class is really hard, but the professor you take it with can make a difference, especially if they're as helpful as Professor Wan.

The weekly homework is really painful and time-consuming. The discussion is for quizzes, which are not quite difficult compared to the webwork. The final is really hard but there will usually be a generous curve. Professor Yen is not bad and quite helpful during office hours.
I think he is a great professor!  He explains all the material very well, very nice guy and is always willing to help students!
Kleski is a nice guy and very willing to help in office hours. Classes were often boring. Quizzes every week. Midterms were fairly difficult.

I got a 5 on AP Calc AB in high school, and expected to do just as well in college and maybe even major in math. This class changed all that. Kleski was fine, he knows the stuff and is organized and has really nice hand-writing. There was a online WebWork HW set every week in addition to a few harder written homework problems. Luckily I got 100% for the 30% of your final grade that HW is thanks to the Discussion section (seriously wouldn't have been able to do all the HW without it), but I ended up with a B+ in the class because there are tons of people in the class who have all seen the material before who mess up the one curve we got on a test, and the tests ask questions that were sometimes really unexpected and different than the HW and test review problems. I would REALLY suggest taking Applied Calc unless you absolutely can't because this class just isn't worth the pain.

This class was HARD.  No really- it's tough.  I took BC Calc in high school and expected to have no problem with calc 2...boy was I wrong.  Kleski was a really good teacher (moved quick but what can you expect) and Josh was incredibly helpful explaining the homework but the tests were impossible.  My advice would be to skip this course if you can...

To be honest, I had only taken AB in high school and thought about switching to 122 the after the first lecture, but I was glad I stayed with it. The TA helped a ton on the problem sets. The professor was great, but it was necessary to go to office hours since he moved pretty quickly. I think I had a better time in 132 than most of my friends did in 122 because you don't get a TA in 122 or as personalized instruction. Kleski is a really nice guy. Also, he is more than willing to go over midterms and help you prepare for the final.

Kleski is an amazing teacher, however, if you don't put in a lot of effort on your own time through practice and personal research, you WILL NOT DO GOOD. The tests really push the limits of your understanding of the concepts

Craig is a good teacher and he always makes time during his lecture to ask if everyone understands.  He never makes students feel stupid; however, the class if just hard.  The material is definitely not easy, I got a 5 on the AB Calc exam just last year and I struggled in this course.  However, Kleski is one of the best teachers here, considering it is one of the most failed classes at UVA.  Also:  if you fail the first exam, don't worry, it does get easier!  I wouldn't recommend the class but if necessary for a major, Kleski is a good choice.

Kleski is awesome.  He's really nice and he knows what he's talking about.  He is a very clear teacher and you will learn the material if you pay attention.  Very approachable for asking questions.  That being said, this is a difficult course and, while I really liked it, you won't if you don't like math.  Best math class I've taken thus far.

It's obvious that Kleski is very knowledgable in his field.  Also, he could quite possibly be one of the most intelligent people at this university.  That being said, his lectures are very informative (but he moves very fast).  Even if you consider yourself a math person, don't expect this to be easy by any means.  Homework sets can be grueling and tests are very tricky.  After taking this course, you'll see why it's the most failed class at UVA.

Only take Calc II with Kleski!  He is a really good teacher, and he is a really smart guy.  The exams themselves are standardized and extremely hard.  However, Kleski gives excellent curves (some other teachers don't give any curves in this class).  The material is hard and it takes a lot of practice to get good at it.  Do the homework, pay attention in class, and ask questions and you should end up with a decent grade, especially if you're near the top of your class.
Class was not easy but the faculty is very good at making you understand
The professor is really nice and fun to work with who would do anything to help you. TA is a pain specially at 8 in the morning and when you know he is doesnt know how to solve anything.

definitely the easiest calc2 teacher. wouldn't have gotten the good grade i did if i had another professor for this class. chandra's extremely nice and approachable and if you decide to take calc2, you definitely need to take it with chandra.

I was really apprehensive about CalcII because I heard it was a weed out course here, and I took AB Calculus in my junior year in high school, but this class was definitely easy! Emerick might explain a little better than Chandra, but you don't need to work really hard to get an A! Chandra is really enthusiastic and open during his office hours, and his review sessions are helpful. He grades extremely leniently, so even though I got stuff wrong on the test I was able to get over 100%! There are two midterms and one final exam, mymathlab assignments usually once a week, and three written homeworks over the course of the semester. however, only one written homework is counted, and the top 10 averaged mymathlabs too. As long as you keep up with the web assigns, you'll be fine. This was my highest grade in my first semester of first year, and I'm so glad I took it. But none of this applies with any other professor, so TAKE CHANDRA
He's a fair Calc II professor. He holds a lot of office hours. His lectures aren't exciting but they get the point across well enough. He's an easy grader in my experience.
Great teacher
Such a hard teacher

It's Calc 2, what should I say? Ajay's definitely the best teacher though.  We realized this when we had a sub one day, and all we wanted was for Ajay to come back.  He's a great guy and always willing to help.  We got more webwork than the other classes, but it just meant we were more prepared in the end :)

There's rumor that this is the most failed class in the college; don't buy it.  It's not easy, but if you do the work, you're definately not going to fail.  WebWork just like 131.  Giffen is very helpful and a fun prof.
She definitely knows her stuff but is not the best teacher.
hard subject but great teacher

I actually like math and am currently in Calc III, but I dropped her class because she was extremely arrogant and belittled people who asked legitimate questions.  Her favorite refrain was "I've been there, done that, and got an A."  Her new last name is Snider. Avoid her like the plague.
Got mad at us because we were going to bathroom, just like high school
Ms. Snider lacks enthusiasm and would spend entire lectures trying to solve one or two problems. The tests were a fair reflection of the material but not the lectures.

Professor Qi is a very kind and helpful professor who truly cares for the success and wellbeing of his students. While it can be stressful to have a midterm worth 30 percent of your grade and a final worth 40, he is very forgiving on grading these and gives problems that pretty much match exactly what you do in the homework and quizzes. At the end, our class had a curve such that an 85 was an A-, a 75- was a B- and so on, which was nice. If you forget to turn in homework once he usually takes it late anyways if you go to his office. Lowest quiz is dropped and for homework sets, he only takes off 1 point out of 100 for each wrong question (yes, that means if there's 20 questions and you show your work you'll at least get an 80 on it). I HIGHLY recommend reading the textbook thoroughly and doing extra problems from the same sections he assigns from. It's a short book, but it can basically teach you the material itself (what's covered in class doesn't really deviate from what's in the assigned reading at all).

Professor Qi is very calm and kind, and is great at teaching concepts through relatable metaphors. When you learn things like double and triple integrals, be sure to pay attention to the "bread loaf" method, since it's both fun and engaging. Professor Qi was also very helpful in office hours, and even if his regular hours don't work with your schedule, you can coordinate with him on other times. Ask him any question about the content and he will answer the best he can without being judgmental--he always welcomes questions, big or small. Weekly homework sets can be challenging but are very manageable if you go to office hours. The lowest two homework sets and quizzes are dropped. I am really glad I took Calc 3 with Professor Qi, and I highly recommend you take this class with him too if you can.

I stressed about this class more than I should have. At the beginning of the semester it seemed like it was going to be rough, but as it got going, Qi proved to be a pretty good professor. To be successful in this class, you definitely have to put effort outside of class. I found myself watching a lot of youtube to understand concepts better. The weekly homework isn't that bad, but the weekly quizzes in the discussion section are hard to prepare for and can be annoying. That being said, unless you don't answer the questions at all, you'll be fine on the quizzes. The TA for the class was not great. He wasn't great at answering questions or explaining concepts, but there were a couple important things that I gained from the discussion section. The final wasn't terrible if you understand the concepts in the course (just don't make silly mistakes!), and I got an A in the class with an 85 on the final. I got a 78 on the midterm, but luckily he offered a kind of dutch knockout system where the final was either worth 40% or 70%. Overall the class is fine, but I don't think it invigorates a passion for math.

This course was very insightful into the world of multivariable calculus and its applications.There was weekly HW assignments (WebAssign, ranged from 12-18 questions) and weekly quizzes in the discussion section (2 questions). The weekly HW assignments took about, on average, 3 hours to complete, and were not so difficult. Lectures were informative, but extra studying outside of class is necessary (especially for some of the geometry and visualizations).The professor was understanding and clarified doubts regularly, but sometimes the class would be a little too theoretical and there would be many examples of special cases of concepts rather than general cases.The TA was new this year and he was helpful in connecting concepts to applications (in physics especially). He was also a generous grader and open to any of our doubts.midterm was difficult and slightly unexpected, final wasn't so bad and expectedI would recommend this class if you're interested in calculus past calc 2, CS, physics, math, or finance. #tCFfall22

Was a nice person but a really bad teacher. Would overcomplicate any question no matter how simple and was generally unhelpful and lacked awareness of students' understanding. Exams were much harder then any content previously seen. Whole class did so badly on the midterms that he had to offer previously unplanned test corrections. Also serious disconnect from TA and teacher as the TA did not attend the classes but made our quizzes.

I cannot recommend taking this class with You Qi enough!
I am a BACS major, and I wanted to take more math to be closer to the degree in the e-school. But whether you are taking this class as a math major/minor or for simply rounding out your calculus understanding, I cannot recommend it enough. This class is a good bridge between more computational math and higher-level mathematics. You Qi focuses not just on computations but on actual understanding. He goes over proofs and has students do sort of pseudo-proofs on a few of the homework assignments.
This class takes a lot of time and is definitely hard, but it is ultimately very rewarding, and that is just the nature of the course. I recommend taking You Qi's advice and reading the sections of the book alongside the lectures. There is so much material, so sometimes the book is needed to supplement what is gone over in class. Also, don't feel bad if you feel lost sometimes in lecture. It does go really fast. But, office hours and the book make it very doable. And by the end, you will see how far you've come.
As for the tests, assessments in the course are quizzes, a midterm, and a final. Quizzes can be somewhat hard, and you really do only have ten minutes so reviewing the content from the week before taking them is helpful. But, they are ultimately fair and some are dropped. As for exams, these were more than fair. If you know the content going in, you will be fine. And You Qi let us have a cheat sheet as memorization is not the goal of the course. Further, I know in previous semesters when there were issues with exam difficulty, You Qi corrected them fairly. He is kind and generous.
Definitely take this course and take it with You Qi! Good luck on your math journey.

Like any Calc III class, you'll have to learn most of the content on your own. Nonetheless, Evangelos Dimou may be your best bet, since he's well-organized and will provide all the necessary tools for success. He teaches the textbook content in order, posts his worksheets and solutions online, and provides practice problems before midterms and exams. Additionally, instead of just solving random problems on the board each lecture, he provides everyone with a lesson sheet that teaches the valuable concepts and then reinforces them through simple practice problems. Besides that, there will be two weekly online hw assignments and a biweekly written hw. These will take about 30min - 1.5hr each to complete, but you'd probably have to study on your own otherwise, and they help ensure that you understand the content. Furthermore, the exams are straightforward, following similar problems to those done in class and being easier than the practice exam. The one caveat I have is that Mr. Dimou frequently asks the class simple questions as we're working along, like "What's 1+3", and if no one responds he'll abruptly stop and stare at the class like we're all idiots until someone responds. Nonetheless, this remains a fair and reasonable course, and although Mr. Dimou can't magically enlighten you with a calculus ability, he'll provide you with every necessary tool to learn it yourself.

At the time I wrote this, the professor name was not visible but I believe this is Lloyd West. Overall, he's a great professor. He might introduce difficult concepts but it will make sense at some point. During the first two weeks we talked about spherical/cylindrical coordinates and had us do homework that wanted us to draw objects in 3D. Don't panic because you don't need to master imagining these until the end. He introduces it at the beginning so you don't get shocked and can't do any of the actual calculus. His exams are REALLY FAIR and he tells you what to expect on it. Pay attention in lecture and don't skip or you will be completely lost.
Towards the end of the semester, he taught us an advanced method of doing the last few topics. He said that it will make calculations much simpler and it did. The way he teaches is great and if you go to office hours and ask questions he will try to explain things better.
If you ever confused, you can always send him an email and he will set an appointment with you but you have to take the initiative and start on the homework early so that you can ask him early on. Homeworks usually have one or two questions that are somewhat difficult and so start on the homework before the discussion session so you ask the TA questions.
Overall, West is a great professor and wants to help his students as much as possible. Take as many classes with him as possible.

Lloyd West taught the class. It was miserable. You learn theorems. All of which are in the book. You do not learn how to use the theorems in any useful manner. He is pretty arrogant. The homework and discussions are pointless. He gives you one practice problem per subject and expects you to master an entire topic with one problem. DO NOT take this class with him. He also has you write a research paper on math related topics for extra credit, only this extra credit assignment is worth 5% of your actual grade. The grade is based on two midterms a final and homework. I failed the two midterms but got a C+ in the class because of the curve.

This course is tough. It is all about visualizing 3-D spaces, which I am not particularly good at.There were 10 homeworks (about 1 per week with around 15 problems each), 3 pop quizzes during the discussion section (that really don't hurt your grade), and 3 midterms.  This class is a fair amount of work and self-teaching. Do NOT get behind and make sure you understand the early topics really well because they will come back to haunt you at the end.That being said, Prof. Petrov makes this class bearable and he is very helpful when you need it. He will literally respond to messages within seconds. He's a great guy and really understands the math so I would HIGHLY recommend taking Calculus III with him if he teaches it again.

Like with any math class, you're going to have to learn a lot of the material on your own. Initially, I was turned off by Petrov's teaching style, but grew to find him funny and knowledgeable. Midterms were graded generously, the final was a bit tougher than the midterms, but he curved it. Overall, I recommend Petrov, just be willing to do the work.

Prof. Petrov's lecture sometimes becomes fast, but he does explain everything necessary to succeeding in this course. Office hour is helpful. Midterms are not hard, while the final is a little bit but fair. Overall it is not an easy course, but you will definitely learn a great deal if you understand every point in lecture and assignment.
Before Final, I thought I was the master of Cal 3.I failed my final and missed two homework.I ended up with an A-.

I love Prof. Petrov... as a professor of course. He teaches incredible if you have already learned Calculus 3 before and teaches ok if you have not learned Calculus 3 before. His explainations and proofs for concepts are intuitive most of the time (although if asked to explain what he proofed after class you would likely be saying I am not sure). He does not explain the concepts like most teachers. For example, for curl and divergence, he explained the concepts using mathematical topography (I forgot what it was called), so instead of showing us the geometric/physical meaning of those concepts, he derived it mathematically. That is kind of cool (but also not helpful for learning it). It would be extremely useful to preview the materials beforehand and perhaps follow Khan Academy in learning the stuff first. Then, you would his Prof. Petrov's lecture a lot more rewarding and interesting.
His lectures are hard to follow for another reason — he raps a lot. What I mean is that he writes and calculates really, really fast in live time as he does not prepare lecture slides. The lack of lecture slides also means a lack of truly visualizing many of the 3D surfaces, so I really recommend seeing some Khan Academy videos early on to get a sense of the 3D objects that you will be dealing with. It is very satisfying to see his hand glide across the board like a figure skater, although you may not follow his calculations half the time. Moreover, he asks students to ask questions a lot of the time, but most of the time we cannot process what he taught us: he ends up thinking maybe that we understand the concept perfectly when in reality do not understand anything so we cannot ask anything.
Being in the A-School, I took Calculus 3 mostly for fun because I honestly found AP Calc BC incredible. Prof. Petrov's tests are incredibly fair because he almost only tests question types that you have definitely encountered before if you have done all the homework. Also, he has one-question quizzes in most weeks, and they are usually very basic, just a way to check for understand. In the two midterms, a very large proportion of people got 100. I always make small mistakes, so he graded harsher for any smaller mistakes made since too many people got full marks. I only went to his office hour once — and that is two hours before the final. He is relatively patient in explaining concepts; his temper will never grow foul, but his speed of explaination is usually really fast, like his lectures.
The biggest weakness in this class is when you get to the hard stuff at the end of the semester: line and surface integrals. In fact, those are the things Prof. Petrov uses the most in his research, but perhaps because of this fact, he teaches these concepts the worst. His thinking of these concepts are too advanced for students. In those lectures for especially Stoke's Theorem and Surface Integrals, he glosses over the concepts pretty fast despite them being very confusing. I got 6/10 for the Stoke's Theorem quiz but eventually understood the concept before the final. All-in-all, I did enjoy calc 3 with Prof. Petrov. He probably won't teach this class anytime soon, but here is my recommendation for the class.

You could get a really good grade if you actually put in work in this class. Syllabus clearly states all the things you need to do. Most work is just online homework and in-class quiz each week. Professor drops two lowest quiz and two lowest homework. Midterms are also in class and you could bring formula sheet. All the quizzes and tests are fairly easy.

For a hard class it wasn’t too bad. She was a solid professor and was helpful although we might not of gotten through all of the topics. The tests were fine and the webassign hw was fine. The only problem was the writing homework’s that she gave out were almost impossible to do by yourself and were time consuming. If you went to office hours she was really helpful but you had to do that or your grade would tank. Overall wasn’t a bad class for a hard topic.

DS is really nice and super helpful during office hours, but his lectures are usually confusing and disorganized as he is super fast and doesn't do many example problems. I wouldn't recommend taking Calc 3 with him unless you have some background from high school. He would probably be good at teaching higher-level math classes though. #tCFF23

#tCFF23I didn't take other calculus courses here at UVA to gauge how hard this class is compared to the others, but I still struggled a lot. The professor is really nice and friendly. He won't be the reason why you hate the course. His personality (sometimes) makes up for the way he teaches. If you are the type of person who learns best from quick lectures, then this class is for you. I found myself learning more from doing the homework than from the lectures because it was hard for me to retain all the information so quickly. Maybe it would have been easier to review after each lecture. He is also really understanding when you email him. He often extends deadlines or releases information when asked by a lot of students with good reasoning.The work will make you hate the course. The amount of work is a lot though if you leave the WebAssign homework till the end of the week. But they are really useful for learning. There are quizzes based on the assignments and textbook, so it was useful to review those beforehand. The exams, however, get progressively harder through the year. But that's because the topics become more complicated.My TA, Micheal O Cobhthaigh, during the discussions, was pretty intimidating to approach. He knows a lot, but it was hard to keep up when he explained. We also struggled to get his attention half the time whenever we needed help because a lot of other groups needed help as well.I felt like the course would have definitely been better if there had been more chances for the concepts to be explained. But that could have also been solved by going to more office hours. Also, don't leave studying for the final until the night before. This is not the course for that.

This class was...interesting. Professor Tsai is really welcoming and patient, but just sort of plowed through the material every class. We learned around six sections of a unit in one 75 minute class towards the end of the semester because we were behind. The homework can be long 50-100 questions, but you learn a lot and its heavily weighted and you have multiple attempts to solve it. The weekly quizzes were...ok. The TA was a grad student and took his quizzes out of a textbook that wasn't accessible to us, and made some of them proof based which I bombed because Prof. Tsai only did calculation examples in class. The first two exams were fine, but the final exam (though it wasn't cumulative) was impossible and so hard because Prof Tsai hadn't gone that deep into the unit or done the harder examples bc we were short on time. However, he did curve the exam and our grades hard after we gave him our feedback after the final. #tCFfall2021

I had a relatively enjoyable time in Professor Tsai's class in comparison to what I have heard about the other Calc III professors during the fall semester. Professor Tsai was extremely patient with his students, where he would pause every now and then in the middle of his lectures to ask if everyone understood the concept being taught or if anyone had any questions regarding the content. The homework was not too terrible, it was standard CENGAGE homework based on the notes taught in class (however there were times when there would be 50+ questions, but he would sometimes extend the deadline and the midterms were modeled after the homework and notes). The weekly quizzes were the only thing that impacted my grade but that was at fault of our TA, who used his personal textbook from 1960. Overall, I'd suggest forming study groups to excel in the class.

This is the guy you want to take Calc III with. Very to-the-point about what you need to know for class and clearly knows what he's talking about. A lot of the grade is homework and quizzes handed out in the TA section, and there's only a midterm and a final, both of which he is very explicit about how to prepare for.

Professor Olsen is a very good and thoughtful professor, but DO NOT take his class. He holds office hours twice a week for 2 hours. He makes sure to go slowly and unlike many other professors he does all of his lecturing on a blackboard instead of a powerpoint which I found really helpful. Here is where the class gets unfortunately bad. Here is the grade breakdown for the class: 10% Written HW, 6% Webassign, 20% Quizzes, 20% Midterm 1, 20% Midterm 2, 24% Final. You will have a Webassign, 3 page written homework, and a quiz every Thursday. The written homework and Webassign are not bad and are good practice for the quizzes. The average grade for the quizzes in the class was roughly 75%, the average grade on the first midterm was 70%, the average grade on the second midterm was 75%. I got 85% on quizzes, 83% Midterm 1, 84% Midterm 2, and a 71% on the final (don't know class average on final). THE CLASS WAS NOT CURVED UNLIKE EVERY OTHER MATH 2310 CLASS. Our lowest written homework and quiz were dropped, but thats all. This means the average grade for the class, at least to my knowledge was a C. I barely got a B and I felt I was in the top 25% of the class. If you want to keep a high GPA, do not take this class.

Bill is a great lecturer. Especially when compared to the average math professor at UVA, he does not bog his lectures down with proofs, has great handwriting, and writes everything out in a clear and concise way that translates very well into notes. He is also very kind, and will work to make sure you understand the material. It's also obvious that he is very passionate about Math, and oftentimes that passion is infectious in his lectures. However, his exams and written HWs are very challenging. Be sure to start the Written HW early and make friends in your class, as you'll definitely want to go over your answers (Wolfram Alpha is useful for checking work, but not if you fundamentally misunderstand the problem). You will also want to make sure you know all theorems from lecture and how to apply them to any problem, as you will likely see a new application of said theorems on the exam. While his exams are very challenging, and I often did not get the grade I would've hoped, I'm glad I took the course with Bill. This class made me a much better problem solver and studier, and I learned to think much more like a mathematician throughout the semester. If you don't care to really understand the math and are just taking this course for a pre-req, you're probably better off not taking the course with Bill. Otherwise I highly recommend him.

I had wanted to be a math major/minor for a long time, but a particularly bad math class my senior year of high school had made me reconsider wanting to be a math major.  Taking this course with Professor Mark made me love math and want to be a math major again!  Dr. Mark is fun, quirky and a great professor.  His lectures are helpful, the amount of homework he assigns is very reasonable, and his exams are more than fair.  He is also extremely kind and always willing to go the extra mile and help students.  He doesn’t often teach Calc III anymore, but if you have the chance to take it with him, do it!

Professor Mark is a nice guy, and a relatively fun professor. However, I found the way he teaches to be a bit problematic for me. Some of the topics he teaches differently from the text book, and when speaking to other students who have taken Calc 3, none of them have ever heard of his methods. This is one of the more difficult classes I have taken at UVA, and recommend trying to find a tutor at the beginning of the semester so you don't fall behind. Some of the other students in my class seemed to understand more, but they have mentioned taking similar courses in high school. I had no background in the Calc 3 material, so I felt a lot more behind than the rest of the class. Professor Mark is extremely intelligent, although I don't think he's the best when it comes to explaining things to a student who doesn't understand. Good luck!

Professor Mark is a fun and friendly professor. He is always willing to help out students who show interest. As a pro tip: always go to his office hours! He will guide you, especially with the written homework. His lectures focus a lot on general introductions and then in-depth examples. Where you will probably gain the most understanding through the homework. That's why I'd recommend spreading out practice and review throughout the week: try not to cram it all at once, or else you won't remember it adequately. Learning math takes a lot of practice and review. In fact, that's why cramming is probably the absolute worst thing you could do in this class. Especially since the theorems covered in Calculus III can be quite complex (ahem, Stokes Theorem particularly), you will have a horrible time if you don't make efforts to 1) attend office hours for help and 2) practice, practice, and practice over time to get a thorough understanding of the material.
As a side note: the lectures cover an alternate approach to Stokes Theorem that involve differential equations. This is different from the vector approach taken in the textbook. However, it is helpful to know both methods for the final exam (although you are free to use whichever method you prefer). So, make sure you are keeping up with the textbook reading throughout the semester. It is helpful to have read the textbook before the lectures, so that you come in with a basic understanding of what will be discussed.
Professor Mark is a very supportive instructor. If you are struggling with something or feel that the disparity between the lectures and textbook material is too great, reach out to him. He'll give you what you need in terms of extra material or reading. Hope that helps!

This class taught by Mr. Urasltsev is challenging. In the Fall, the grade breakdown was 50% problem sets, 35% open-book/notes tests, (Written Midterm 10%, Oral Midterm 10%, Final 15%), 15% misc (presentations, test reviews). The homework is often guided by example videos and take around 5 hrs/week: not too bad. The presentations are similar in difficulty and are often explained in office hours, which you should attend. The real challenge are the tests which are much more conceptual and have a low relative average (good curves, final averaged a 51%). Solid preparation with the textbook for several hours for a couple days did the trick. Understanding how to run through integrals without understanding the 3D geometry is what will do you in. Focus less on the arithmetic, more on what is happening with vectors and space. Biased review as I got an A+, but there were a couple A, A-, and a good number of B+ I think.

This class was a lot of work and very challenging. Two lectures a week + a discussion section that was sometimes group work, sometimes more lecture, and sometimes rather pointless. Weekly WebAssign homework (online textbook problems graded on competition) and Gradescope homework (free responses questions graded on accuracy). The WebAssign was time consuming but you had unlimited attempts. I'm not sure how you were supposed to do the Gradescope without going to office hours. Two timed, in-person midterms, one timed, take-home final. All were open-note but closed-internet. We also did three recorded group presentations which were kinda a pain to do but were graded on completion. Gennady clearly cares about his students and wants them to succeed, but doesn't hold back when it comes to assigned lots of difficult work. Some of his lectures were good, some you had no clue what was going on. TA Jun had potential but was often way underprepared when it came to answering homework questions. On the other hand, TA David was great and if anything over-explained answers. In the end, Gennady's grading scale was pretty generous -- the median grade was an 88.

Do not take this class unless you absolutely need to for your major/minor. I am writing this to save anyone thinking of taking it just cause.
Gennady is a very nice guy. However, this class has been the hardest and most stressful part of my week for the entire semester. As you might have noticed, I have not completed the class, and he curves grades at the end so I cannot say anything about my grade or the curve, but I can tell you about my experience in class.
The lectures are okay. I don't know anyone in my class so maybe that'd make it better. Gennady is definitely passionate about his work, but he's all over the place. It's very hard to follow along when you are taking notes, particularly on paper. Sometimes you'll understand, blink twice, and then he seems to be talking about something completely different, so you scramble to catch up, get confused, and then you find out it was a proof that you'll never see or use again in your life.
Grades are comprised of 50% HW, 35% on midterms and finals, and 15% on other such as presentations.
Midterms are okay ( the average on the first was 73% ), and I am yet to see how he grades presentations.
But the homework...Every week there is a WebAssign and written homework due on Tuesday. The WebAssign is definitely doable although it may take a lot of time and effort, but, you will finish it. The written homework is where the difficulty in this class is. The written homework is impossible, he takes easy concepts and makes them as difficult as humanely possible by making sure you have to use the most obscure formulas that you learned about for one day in middle school in order to solve them. I had a personal, professional tutor for this class, and they ended up quitting because it was too hard! You have to go to office hours to get the homework done, and what's the point of that? To just be given the answers? I mean ill take them but homework should not be hard enough that you don't even put it an effort.
In summary, don't even think about taking this class unless you have to. And if you do, good luck.

Prof Ultrasev is an incredibly smart teacher who knows a LOT and loves teaching. He makes the classes enjoyable (despite the topics not always being the most interesting), but as a student who generally likes math it was something I looked forward to. Don't get it wrong, the class is HARD. In fact, despite being a CS major i spent more time on this class than my cs class. The class is mostly hard because of the homeworks. Homework is broken down into webassigns and written homeworks. Webassigns are just guaranteed 100%'s, as you get infinite tries on the questions. The hard part comes with the written homeworks. They're quite hard and require a lot of deep understanding and complex thought to complete, and i can almost guarantee you that you won't be able to finish one completely without going to office hours. that being said, GO TO OFFICE HOURS. Ultimately, the reason i succeeded in the class was because i went to Gennady's office hours and the TA's office hours. This class is definitely a more-you-put-in-the-better-you-do-esque class - at a certain point, the more time you put in i think it almost directly correlates to your performance.On another note, Gennady is amazing and is incredibly hardworking. He's almost singlehandedly responding to all questions on Piazza and goes above and beyond to ensure that students are learning. He offers tons of resources, and the grading is generally leanient, as he drops something like 2 of the worst webassigns and written homeworks, and generally curves the exams. I'd recommend taking this class if you're interested in math, need to get this as a pre-req, or are looking to stretch your scope in math a little and be challenged while doing so.

Even though I did well in this course, I found it to be pretty stressful, especially since it was online. Two of our exams were "oral exams", which meant a 15-minute, one-on-one zoom call with Professor Sherman, where he posted questions and you had to write down your solutions and show them to him. We had weekly classwork, where we were put into small groups (on zoom) and had to submit problems by the end of class. There was online homework every week, written homework some weeks, and the occasional reading comprehension quiz. I read and took notes from the textbook, which helped me better understand the concepts, especially since we didn't cover everything in lectures. I think I learned the most from the online homework problems though. Overall, I feel like I was challenged in this course and learned a lot, but I am glad it's over.

Professor Ure is a great professor and I would definitely recommend taking her class! I got an A in the class with pretty minimal effort because she is such a great professor. Her lecture is very structured and she will review concepts from calc 1 and 2 to refresh your memory and tie them to the lesson that day. She really wants to make sure her students understand the material. She assigned 3 assignments on webassign per week and would even give a 10% bonus if you submitted it 24 hours before the deadline, which was not difficult to do. The webassigns were pretty much what we learned in class and provided a lot more types of problems to give more practice. I find the homework in this class very effective, not too time-consuming, and I would not consider it "busy work". As the semester progressed, some of the homeworks, especially towards the end, were more difficult and longer, but they still offered a lot of practice which helped with the more difficult content. Every couple of weeks we would have written homeworks that gave you a good idea of what the exam problems would look like. Her exams are very fair. If you understand the material in class and understand the homeworks, you will probably get a good grade on the exam. After the second exam, the material gets pretty difficult and confusing, but Professor Ure explains it really well and will also spend time explaining it in office hours if you need it. Even if her explanations aren't helping, the textbook is pretty good and gives good explanations and practice problems. There was a discussion portion of the class, but it wasn't really that helpful because the teacher mainly rushed through the topics and made a lot of algebraic mistakes in his work so it made it really difficult to follow. I still went because there were practice problems, but you don't really need to go, a lot of times I feel like I was wasting my time there when I could have been doing work for another class.

I liked math before this class. Bogdan assigns way too much homework and grades the written portion harshly. His lectures are confusing and I guess I learn a thing or two but not as much as I would like. The exams are very difficult unless you study hard for them and even then he would find a way to make it tough. When his lectures were not tough, they were mad boring. Bogdan is not a good teacher and doesn't seem to care for your grade.

The worst. Lectures were so confusing and he always would make simple mistakes then spend so much time trying to find his mistakes. He had weekly quizzes at discussion which were okay but the worksheet before the quiz usually had nothing to do with the quiz itself. On his homeworks he assigned 2-4 webassign problem sets a week in addition to written homework sets. He graded the written homeworks so tough and it's pretty hard to get a 100 for written hws. His exams were pretty insane. First exam average was like a 65. On a lot of questions he would take off points if you didn't show simple steps, but his exams were so long that writing out those steps would waste too much time. On a few problems I actually had the write final answer and I tried to ask him what was wrong and he just told me it's not worth arguing over. Really tough teacher who didn't care about whether his students were learning and he was really only at UVA for his PhD. Surprised if he comes back in the fall

This is the worst class I've ever taken. He teaches nothing in class and when people ask questions, he doesn't answer them. The written homeworks are graded very harshly for no reason. There's no reason to go to office hours or try to talk to him after class as he doesn't help at all. The exams were insanely hard even after studying for them for 20+ hours. His grading is confusing and he doesn't explain anything when asked. He does not care about students at all and doesn't even look back from the chalkboard during lecture. He just writes his notes on the board without caring if students are even following, which we weren't. I heard all the other calc III professors were good, please take it with anyone but this professor.

As far as UVA's crappy math dept. goes (at least for teaching) Krstic was not too bad. I sat in the front so I found it easy to focus and follow along; though he did speed up as the semester continued. There is a substantial amount of webassigns for this course (like between 25 and 50 questions a week),  plus a weekly written homework assignment with questions from the textbook. I found this class frustrating, however, I did improve by the end of the semester. He is helpful at office hours if you have a specific question from homework or something like that, conceptually ... just read through your notes and/or the online textbook.  Much better than my calc2 prof.

Professor Krstic was an ok lecturer but was also willing to answer questions and explain anything. The first exams in this class were kind of tough but there was a curve, although it wasn't always very helpful. My main issue with this class was the amount of work. The WebAssign and the written homework easily took over 4 hours. But the extra 10% credit for each WebAssign makes it a bit more worthwhile so I guess it was a fair trade-off. The written homework was graded a little harshly sometimes but other than that just be ready to work a little harder than for some of the other professors.

Liron was a really cool and nice professor, but I think I learned the entire course on my own from the textbook. He just went way too fast in lecture and nobody really knew what was going on the whole time. He presented the material clearly and was very thorough in answering questions, he just went really fast.

If you are not a very stronger conceptual math learner than I would strongly suggest that you do not take this course. It was primarily teaching yourself because lectures were just copying problems and the textbook. I came in having never really needing to have studied before for math. This class quickly changed that. It is curved at the end which is the biggest blessing since tests were a little unfair since the weekly quizzes written by the TA were much easier giving you a false sense of confidence.

Webassign and hw every week -takes about 2 hours and is not incredibly hard. Weekly quizzes are not bad just do hw before discussion to prepare. first exam was pretty easy if you studied (review web assign and notes). have not taken second midterm but reviewing for anyone considering class next semester. I had friends in Thomas mark's class who said homework was 40% of grade making tests weighted less. that is also a good option. do not take with jinbo ten (heard horrible things ab him). Liron is not a bad prof; honestly he explains things pretty simply, it just might seem confusing because of notation. read textbook before lectures and you will understand. as I said first test was fair and based off of webassign and notes.

Jinbo is basically incapable of teaching students calculus, so do not take his class at all. He speaks in a very formal manner and does not explain anything that he teaches. His office hours are very unhelpful and when I went to them he made me feel stupid for not understanding some of the concepts and would not explain anything unless I specifically asked him about each and every step; he also proceeded during this time to talk to the other student next to me in mandarin the whole time and laugh, which made me feel like he was making fun of me. His grading is very harsh and has taken many, many points off of my tests and quizzes for work even when it was all totally correct, and then he would refuse to give me any credit back for it (he even admitted that the answers were correct). He left for a week of lectures and then on the following quiz took of points when I did things a different way than he did them, even though that is how I was taught to do it by another professor. None of the homeworks reflect how hard the tests are and he gives quizzes at random times (once was on the last day of the reading days when everyone was traveling home and had it due the next day). Jinbo does not have much common sense in the way of social skills and is not a good professor.

He said that we will limit what we study to R3........and then he gave us a R4 question in the next quiz.......hahahahaha. Of course I dont know how to do it and start writing this review. He is teaching OK and I think I understand what he is doing except for his assignments. They are like HELL.

Jinbo was a very bad lecturer, and the only way that I learned anything was if I taught myself. His assignments are extremely hard to complete and nothing like what we do in class or in homework. Everybody fails his tests and he thinks thats ok because he curves them. He is a very smart guy but should never teach a class again.
Good professor. Very good at explaining concepts.
Absolute beast of a human being. Highly recommend.
Cool dude, taught course conceptually. Tests were fair in that they focused on whether you understood the general ideas, not necessarily super difficult examples.

Prasit is a great teacher and a funny and cool guy. He made the first exam extremely hard, the average was like a 60 and everybody was really mad, but he realized that and said that if you do better on the final, it replaces the first exam. The average on the second midterm and final were both about 90%, as the tests were extremely doable if you understood how to do the material. I ended up with an A+ after bombing the first exam and I think he rounded up a little at the end also. I highly recommend this class, Prasit is a great dude who loves his Jacobians. My favorite day in class was when he wore a sweatshirt with a giant triangle cut in the back for some reason and no shirt underneath.

I took this class with Prasit my first year, just having come out of Calc BC from high school. Let me tell you... this is the first math class I've taken that has truly challenged me. However, do NOT shy away from this class. The first two weeks were stressful, but trying to visualize math in three dimensions takes time; admittedly, I almost tried to move down to calc 1320 the first week because I was so stressed. My advisor (who was run the math department) told me to give it a week before I made any decisions. I'm so glad I stayed in the class, because it has been so foundational. The first midterm's average was a 69, but honestly it wasn't that hard-- a lot of kids in my class didnt come to lecture or actually review. As someone who was horrible at visualizing/ graphing functions in R3, I got a 95 on both midterms just by reviewing all his notes frequently and doing tremendous amounts of practice problems. The only way to do well in this class is to sit down and grind out a bunch of problems from the textbook (which is where Prasit gets all his in class examples from). Overall, not a really difficult class if you're willing to put in the effort; those who didn't certainly didnt do well.

Prasit is a good lecturer, and makes sure to emphasize important concepts during class. Even though he doesn’t take attendance, you should go to every class, because it is fast-paced (on average, we learn two sections in the book per day). You get homework problems from the textbook that you have to submit every week, and he also gives you worksheet problems, which you don’t submit but are assigned so that you can practice learning the necessary concepts. However, I didn’t like the homework and textbook problems because they were unnecessarily nasty and required too much algebraic/numeric computation. But you still should do them because they help you learn the underlying concepts.
Even though Prasit is good at lecturing, he’s not really that great at explaining individual math problems (e.g. if you’re struggling to do a particular problem). That’s why I found it kind of awkward to go to his office hours, and he’s really not that approachable and sociable as a person. So if you’re not that great at math and if you struggle a lot, Prasit is probably not the best teacher. However, if you want to take the class, try to get Matt McCarthy as your TA. He’s really good and explains the concepts well during discussions.
Other than that, Prasit is a pretty funny and quirky guy. He always wears these colored socks to class every day. One day he biked to class, and came in with some type of bike/athletic clothes.

I took this course with an 18 credit course load, and it was...a lot. That being said, I would recommend taking this course if you're not taking many tough classes. Towards the end of the term, Prasit was going way too fast through the material and a lot of people ended up having to teach themselves everything before the midterms. The homework questions were unnecessarily long and you would have to spend hours just doing the calculations. As for the final, it was also ridiculous in that there were a gazillion typos. Also, office hours just weren't helpful because everyone was there and he doesn't tend to explain problems well.  He's not approachable and kind of scary, not gonna lie.

I will preface this by saying that I didn't do as well in this course as I would have liked, but I don't think this is a particularly good course. This prof is cool (climbing through windows and making math jokes), but as far as instructors go, he is not the most effective and often fails to adequately answer questions. He often dismisses material as being "intuitive" and doesn't go into depth with it as a result, which can make lectures confusing. The lectures themselves consist of Dr. Bhattacharya simply reviewing an outline he made of the textbook without any additional insight or other problems for explanation. Homework consisted of ten practice problems for the week, which were often extremely easy and did not particularly help as practice. The worksheet problems were similarly useless as it was unlikely that much of the material from those problems would make it into the exams.Overall, I'm very disappointed in this class because Calc 3 has some incredibly interesting topics to teach, but Dr. Bhattacharya manages to make it boring and painful, and often presents it as trivial. I would recommend taking this course with a different professor or maybe at community college instead to find a better teacher. Dr. Bhattacharya may be a genius, but it seems like he has difficulty explaining concepts at a level that undergraduates can understand.The one consistent good about the course was the grad TA, Matt McCarthy. He was an excellent TA and explained things really well. It was unfortunate that his office hours overlapped with the class lecture, but I wish he would have taken that opportunity to just go to lecture with us and help out explaining things. I really wish he had been our prof because I believe I would have been better able to understand the material if he was given more time to explain it to us.All that being said, it is very easy to do well in this class because of the grade inflation, but don't expect to get the most out of it.

I did well in the class, but found it extremely difficult. I had a hard time following Prasit's lectures because he didn't explain topics in depth, and he wasn't very helpful when seeking explanations of topics in office hours or after class. The pace was also much faster than other sections of Calc III.The homework was tedious and lengthy, but helped clear up concepts. Exams were fair (uncurved); the first exam was harder than the second. The final was difficult but curved.I had McCarthy as a TA. He really helped to explain things, and his quizzes were super simple. However, the discussion often did not keep pace with lecture.

stay on top of the work at ALL times. If you make sure you do all of the worksheet problems on time and read the textbook ahead of time, you will be fine. Do not skip lecture, trying to catch up just via textbook is pretty tough. During class, Prasit's lectures are clear and he is more than willing to answer questions.

At first, he honestly seemed incredibly intimidating to me. However, as the semester goes on, I ended up appreciating and even liking Prasit. He has a good sense of humor, and he employs this skill to use at least once a class. With that said, he does go very fast. I remember being a chapter ahead of my friends who took Calc III with other professors. I was often incredibly confused coming out of lecture. Try to pay attention the best you can even though it can sometimes get boring and difficult. However, if I stared at the problems, textbooks, and notes long enough, I eventually understood the material and what Prasit was talking about. Also, don't be dumb like me and not do the optional  worksheet problems; those help a lot in terms of understanding what you go over in lecture. All in all, if you're motivated enough to take the time outside of class to learn and understand the material thoroughly, Prasit is for you.

Go to every single class - it's worth it to hear Xiang explain the material, because he's a fantastic teacher that really knows his stuff and can actually make the topics understandable. He's easily one of the best teachers I've ever had because he's both an interesting lecturer and an interesting person. There will be a lot of time consuming homework, but if you master those questions then you will easily be able to tackle the tests, which will challenge your knowledge conceptually but shouldn't be nearly as heavy computationally.

Cal3 is mainly just computational stuff, not real math. This class has even fewer "proof"-like exercises  than Cal2. The derivative section is very easy, while the vector related sections and integration could get a tad tricky sometimes.
XW is a very clear and good instructor who puts teaching as one of his top priorities, but sometimes can be bogged down in trivial computational details.

Xiang was one of the better math teachers I've had. He went above and beyond when it came to trying to ensure students understood the material. I wish he'd gone over more difficult problems in class. Sometimes it seemed like everything made sense in class, but then when I tried doing the homework it made no sense. Overall, I loved the material, and Xiang was a decent teacher. It would've been nice if we'd spent more time on vector calculus -- the material isn't too bad most of the semester, but everyone agrees that the last few weeks of the class (where we learn vector calc) were the hardest.

Lloyd is the best professor at UVA. Super chill and just all around a nice guy. Doesn't really care about grades (in a good way) and is just really passionate about math and wants his students to learn. His accent is wonderful, and he's pretty funny. If you need to take calc 3, or just want to, take it with lloyd.

Professor Krushkal is very clear and explains the material well.  He is also approachable and cares whether you understand or not.  The textbook is good in this class and definitely helps in clarifying lecture material.

Krushkal is a genuinely very nice guy. He'll answer questions and always had helpful practice tests and reviews before exams. His mannerisms are a bit odd once in awhile, but can be pretty entertaining. The class in general isn't that hard, but you can't fall too behind. BTW, I took this class without ever taking Calc II formally and didn't really have any problems. It draws mainly from Calc I and Krushkal usually reviewed the basic principals as it applied to Calc III.

The class is fairly difficult but Professor Krushkal is very good and teaches by giving numerous example problems.  For every section that we did, Krushkal went through the process of solving the problems in a step by step manner which made the material much more understandable.  The tests were a little bit harder than the hw but not by much.
Slava is really smart and a pretty fair teacher.  My issue with him was that he was too smart to explain some of the concepts clearly.  Other than that, he is good.

Best math professor I've had at UVA. His accent is a little hard to understand but once you get used to it, you'll hardly notice it. He's very clear, gives lots of examples, and will answer any questions you have after class or in office hours. Also gives practice tests before every exam which are VERY useful.

Krushkal does a good job of relating a fairly difficult course material to the class.  The homework is not excessive, and he does a good job of making sure everyone knows what the exam will cover.  I would recommend him to anyone taking this class.
Class isn't bad, but grading can be a little harsh. Not good with awarding partial credit.

Slava is a fairly good lecturer for Calc III and I hardly found myself losing focus in his class.  His quizzes are easy if you pay attention in the discussion but the hws are annoying.  Overall good class.

Prof. Krushkal was always really helpful in and out of class! He did a lot of examples in class and was diligent in making sure everyone understood the material. Tests were a little hard, but doing the homework helps a lot!

Kruskal is a pretty good math teacher for calculus III. He is a little bit awkward about answering questions and can sometimes come off as a little bit harsh when someone asks a stupid question, but I think he generally is a nice guy. The quizzes were much more difficult than the tests and the homework is pretty standard for math homework.

I struggled to under the material when Professor Zhang taught the material but usually got it through the homework assignments. However, Calculus 3 is a really interesting subject, probably the best in the series, and I highly recommend taking it because it looks good for a variety of majors, and it was honestly just really fun.

Gives lots of homework that is pretty difficult, but the questions on the tests are far simpler than the ones that you see on the homework. If you put in the time to figure out each homework problem, you will do very well on the exams.

I would look for a different professor if you want to take this class. Professor Zhang goes really fast through the course and confuses people a lot. Mid-semester I noticed that a lot of people were reading the textbook in class instead of paying attention, and I actually did this too. Many of the students had already taken the class before, so he made the final intentionally harder because he didn't want a lot of people to get As. Also, sometimes when I went to office hours for a topic I didn't understand he would look at me confused and would just continue to confuse me. If you want a good grade in this class, you need to study a lot and read the textbook! Going to office hours helps when tests are coming up because he gives hints about what to expect.

Calc III is hard, don't let people tell you otherwise. It can be tricky in terms of knowing how to set up problems and working through long integrals. Unlike in Calc II where you spent a lot of time doing mostly the same kinds of things (integration of various forms) in Calc III you move very quickly through many topics that are inter-related, but still you really have to go to class and do the HW to be up to speed. You're probably taking this because it's a requirement and professor Farhat is a really good choice for it. I thought she was a really great lecturer and was clear about concepts. I always felt I could learn by simply going to class and while I would read over the book too, it wasn't necessary. She covers a lot of material and writes difficult exams that really test your knowledge, but she is fair in grading and the process makes you really understand what you covered.  I've had her for 2 classes and her style is to not collect/grade HW, but rather each class there is a 5-10 minute quiz on the last HW material which you can do fine on if you did the assigned problems.

Your grade for this course truly depends on the professor. Office hours are really important for that extra help, and Professor Farhat wasn't super helpful during these. She is a super fast lecturer and doesn't really know how to answer questions. I'd advise picking another professor.

Ramanujan is the meme man. He was funny in class, and was largely understandable. Homework wasn't too bad, and tests were good at checking understanding rather than your ability to compute an integral.

I'm currently enrolled in this class right now, but I felt the need to do a review just because of how great Professor Obus is.
Here the thing, calc three isn't easy but it also isn't hard. Concepts build on concepts of Calc 2, so remember your trig functions and how to derive and integrate. The first two exams weren't bad if you studied (I did chapter review problems in the book, redid webworks and made a study sheet to remember formulas). The homework are a little long because there are 5-7 book problems with about 18 webworks problems. It doesn't seem like much but it takes a while.Discussion is a joke-don't go. It's a 5-5:50 class so it took a lot for me to get out after having finished my classes for so long, and I regretted it every time. The TA was awful and the discussion didn't coincide with how the concepts were taught in class.
Professor Obus is literally amazing. He explains everything in a way that makes it so understandable. He writes everything down on the board so you don't miss anything-I've gone to every class and I don't regret it at all. He's sort of a goofball but he's probably the smartest person you'll ever meet. If you look at his CV it's literally 5 pages wrong. His teaching is impeccable-he can answer all of your questions because he not only understands everything he's talking about he goes above and beyond to make are you understand everything. His lectures are very well organized because he has a composition notebook (lol I haven't even touched one since elementary school) of his plans for the lectures which he does previous to every class.If you don't have to take this class for your major or you're not math oriented I wouldn't take this class, but if you do take it with Andrew. He also teaches upper level math courses so look for him cause he's probably the best professor I've had so far tied with Dave Kittlesen.

The class is really simple. I stopped going to class as all that is required is to read the book and your golden.
Though the class / homework is easy the midterms seem to be brutal. There are 5 questions on each, and for having 2 of them the averages were 68%/82% (he allowed a retake), and 68%. No curve.

This is a fantastic math class. At the beginning of the semester it seemed tough, but weekly quizzes come straight from the practice problems and once you figure that out it's not bad at all. If you do them ahead of time you'll be set. Homework can be tough, but get it done before discussion so you can ask questions or just go to the TA's office hours for help. The averages on the tests were pretty bad, but the tests themselves were surprisingly easy. The test questions were a lot like the practice problems and basically just tested your understanding and ability to apply fundamental concepts. Also, he keeps the lectures interesting by using applications in physics.
This class was a lot of fun and Herbst is an awesome professor. If I could take it again, I would.

Herbst is very intelligent, he clearly understands the subject, however--he assumes you do, too. There were many times that he would start difficult problems then just go "...clearly, [answer]" because it was clear to only him. The tests were very difficult, 5 or so questions in total.
Midterms and final are not difficult. Easy class.
Herbst is one of the most terrible lectures i have endured while at UVa. the types of problems assigned for homework do not correlate with those on the test.

Herbst was one of the worst professors I've had in the Math department.  Class is fair, but his lectures can be difficult to determine what he really wants you to take out of the class.  Be prepared to study the textbooks and any example problems very closely.
